PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make two short statements in relation to the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances considered the ACT Imperial Acts (Repeal) Ordinance 1988. This was the third ordinance in a package intended to reform the law with respect to imperial legislation in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). This ordinance repealed various old Acts such as the Evidence of Barbarous and Uncivilised People Destitute of the Knowledge of God Act. It also repealed Acts which obviously were never actually observed in the Australian Capital Territory even though they may have been in force, such as the Wine to be Sold at Reasonable Price Act 1330.

SPEECH.PARA: On a more serious note, the Committee looked long and hard at this ordinance, which repealed many Acts, none of which were expressly listed, by a law made by the Executive. At the end of 1985, at the instigation of the Committee, the Senate actually disallowed a similar ordinance made in respect of obsolete New South Wales Acts; another example of the Senate asserting the primacy of the Parliament. Subsequently, the Committee held a hearing with senior officials of the Attorney-General's Department to try to avoid a similar fate for the proposed Imperial Acts (Repeal) Ordinance. The Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, MP, then undertook to meet the concerns of the Committee by providing in the explanatory statement to re-enact any repealed Imperial Act which either House resolved should be re-enacted.

The Committee accepted this undertaking as the result would be that the Senate could, in effect, recall a repealed Act. The Committee wrote to the Minister that when the ordinance was made it would report to the Senate that its form was acceptable because of this undertaking.

The eventual ordinance was not tabled in the Senate until this year, when it was again closely examined by the Committee. There was a strong feeling in the Committee that the subject matter of the ordinance might be better dealt with by the new ACT Legislative Assembly. Legal advice was obtained, however, which indicated some of the Acts concerned were outside the jurisdiction of the Legislative Assembly. Had this not been the case, it is possible the Committee may have recommended that the matter be dealt with by the new legislature. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate a short summary of the Committee's scrutiny of this ordinance.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
IMPERIAL ACTS (REPEAL) ORDINANCE 1988

The New South Wales Acts Application Ordinance 1985, ACT Ordinance No. 25 of 1985, repealed over 100 New South Wales Acts in their application to the ACT, without listing the actual Acts. The result was that a Senator wishing to object to the repeal of a particular Act was obliged to move to disallow the repeal of all the Acts, including those in which the Senator had no interest.

The Committee moved for disallowance of the Ordinance on 11 October 1985 and when the Senate rose on 28 November 1985 the Ordinance was deemed to have been disallowed. The disallowance was reported on in the Seventy-Sixth Report of the Committee, December 1985.

The Imperial Acts (Substituted Provisions) Ordinance 1986, ACT Ordinance No. 19 of 1986, was intended as the first of three stages in the reform of Imperial Acts which applied in the ACT. That Ordinance terminated the operations of 26 Imperial Acts in the ACT and substituted new provisions in their place.

The Imperial Acts Application Ordinance 1986, ACT Ordinance No. 93 of 1986, was the second stage of the reforms. It expressly preserved certain Imperial Acts, such as Magna Carta, the Petition of Right and the Bill of Rights.
The Third stage would be the eventual Imperial Acts (Repeal) Ordinance, intended to repeal unnecessary and obsolete Imperial Acts in their application to the ACT.

The Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen MP, then advised the Committee that he had concluded it would not be possible to include a list of Acts to be repealed in the repealing legislation, as recommended by the Committee in its Seventy-Sixth Report. This was because a complete and accurate list could not be provided and because an incomplete list would be inconvenient and uncertain. Nevertheless, the Attorney-General emphasised that he wished to ensure that specific Acts could be taken out of the repeal process if either House wished. Accordingly, the Attorney-General suggested a meeting between the Committee and senior officials of his department. The Committee held an in camera hearing with these officials on 20 November 1986.

Following the hearing the Chairman wrote to the Attorney-General on 26 November 1986, confirming that the concern of the Committee was that the Senate should have the same control over the executive unmaking of laws as it had over the executive making of laws. The Chairman then advised that following the hearing the Committee accepted the proposal that rather than list Acts in a repealing Schedule, the Attorney-General would undertake to re-enact any repealed Imperial Act which either House resolved should be preserved. The Chairman added that when the Ordinance was eventually tabled the Committee would report to the Senate that its form was acceptable because of this undertaking.

The Imperial Acts (Repeal) Ordinance 1988, ACT Ordinance No. 94 of 1988, was made on 15 December 1988 and tabled in the Senate on 28 February 1989. It repealed all Imperial Acts in force in the ACT except those expressly preserved by the 2 earlier related ordinances. No Act was expressly mentioned in the Ordinance, although an extensive list of such Acts was included in the Explanatory Statement. A passage in the Explanatory Statement also asserted that if either House resolved that an Imperial Act repealed by the Ordinance should be preserved, that Act would by Ordinance be restored to be in force as it was before the Ordinance. (This Ordinance differed from the disallowed New South Wales Acts Application Ordinance 1985 in that with the former the Imperial Acts affected were not known with certainty, while with the latter there was a limited and definitive number of Acts each of which was certain and known).

The Committee examined the Ordinance at its Meetings of 2 March, 9 March and 6 April 1989. Because of the length of time involved in the making of the Ordinance and the subsequent passage of Acts with respect to an ACT Legislative Assembly the Committee felt it may be more appropriate for the matter to be dealt with by that legislature. The Committee received advice, however, that the ACT Legislative Assembly did not have power to make laws with respect to some of the matters dealt with by the repealed Acts. After full discussion over a number of meetings of different alternatives such as additional Commonwealth legislation or complementary Commonwealth and ACT legislation the Committee resolved to accept the Ordinance and to report to the Senate that its form was acceptable due to the undertaking of the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of us would be aware that today the Legislative Assembly for the ACT meets for the first time and Commonwealth statutory provisions will be proclaimed under which most ACT legislation will become the responsibility of that Assembly and will be administered through ACT Ministers. This means that those ACT Ordinances, and the Regulations and other instruments made under them, will no longer be tabled in the Parliament or be subject to disallowance. The relevant ACT Ordinances will be deemed Acts and any future amendments or new legislation will be made by a legislature and not by executive law makers. Regulations and other instruments made under the new Acts will be made by ACT rather than Commonwealth Ministers. Many of the ordinances which today pass from the control of the Commonwealth Parliament have been improved by the technical scrutiny performed by the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years scrutiny by the Committee has resulted in many ministerial undertakings to amend ACT legislation to provide, for example, for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review rights, for elimination of strict liability offences and for tabling in Parliament of important instruments. Some of the more recent undertakings given to the Committee have not yet been implemented and there is some correspondence outstanding. This matter was addressed some time ago and on 31 August 1988 the then Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch MP, wrote to the Chairman undertaking to direct his departmental staff to do everything possible to clear outstanding undertakings. Should this not be possible before the coming of self-government the Minister undertook to recommend to the new ACT government that appropriate and urgent amendments be made. On behalf of the Committee I have written to the present Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding MP, reminding him of this undertaking.

At this point I emphasise that, as honourable senators know, it is not all ACT Ordinances and related instruments which are being transferred to the new Legislative Assembly. A few ACT laws will continue to be made by the Commonwealth at least for the time being, particularly those on matters which are the responsibility of the Attorney-General. The Committee will, of course, continue to examine the technical aspects of Ordinances of other Territories of the Commonwealth.

Finally I inform the Senate that on behalf of the Committee I shall be writing to the new Speaker of the Legislative Assembly for the ACT, when he or she is appointed, offering the best wishes of the Committee for its future and inviting a delegation of members of the Assembly to attend a lunch jointly hosted by the Committee and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The purpose of this meeting will be to discuss the process of technical legislative scrutiny by parliamentary committees with a view to encouraging our ACT colleagues to adopt similar machinery if they consider it to be appropriate for their chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a message from the House of Representatives requesting the concurrence of the Senate in the appointment of a Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in the following terms:

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr President,...Message No. 429

The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day, and requests that the Senate concur and take action accordingly:
(1) That a joint committee be appointed to inquire into and report on-

(a) all proposals for modifications or variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette on 19 November 1925, as previously modified or varied, which are referred to the committee by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories; and
(b) such matters relating to the Australian Capital Territory as may be referred to it by-
(i) resolution of either House of the Parliament, or
(ii) the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory.

(2) That the committee consist of 8 members, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate.
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6) That 3 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(7) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(8) That the committee have power to move from place to place.
(9) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.

(10) That the committee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the Joint Committees on the Australian Capital Territory appointed during previous Parliaments and of the House of Representatives and Senate Standing Committees on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure when sitting as a joint committee on matters relating to the Australian Capital Territory.

(11) That the resolutions of the House of Representatives of 2 November 1987 and 5 November 1987 and of the Senate of 26 October 1987 and 3 November 1987 relating to consideration of Australian Capital Territory matters by the House of Representatives and Senate Standing Committees on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure be rescinded.
(12) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.

From the time that this Committee existed, and certainly when it was last appointed in 1984, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate appointed two senators to this Committee, which is a fair and reasonable number given our representation in the Senate. I am pleased that, at last, the Government recognises that it has not been properly workable for this Committee to not exist and for its work to have been dealt with in the way mentioned by the infrastructure committees. AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1989

The Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 is the second and final stage of legislative changes to implement the Government's reform package for Telecom, announced in the Ministerial statement of 25 May 1988 ``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises''. The first stage was implemented by the Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988.

A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs.

The GBEs within the Transport and Communications Portfolio, in addition to producing final goods and services for consumers, also produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, with a resulting impact on Australia's overall cost structures and the ability of Australian businesses to compete internationally. Telecommunications is an increasingly important input factor in the production of other goods and services by Australian business for supply to domestic and international markets.

The Government sees the commercialisation of GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as Telecom are being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with private sector competitors, and subjecting them increasingly to the disciplines of the marketplace.

Implementation of the Telecom reform package, together with real reductions in the average price of a basket of basic telecommunications services through the price control formula CPI-X, will bring about increased efficiencies and economies in the provision of telecommunications services by the public sector.

As announced in the 25 May 1988 Statement, the reform package strategy for Telecom has as its key elements the implementation of a new corporate and financial structure, establishment of new planning and accountability mechanisms, modification of major strategic controls and removal of day-to-day ministerial controls.

The Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988 was principally concerned with putting in place the new corporate structure and removing ministerial controls. In particular, from 1 January 1989 the Australian Telecommunications Commission (Telecom) was renamed the Australian Telecommunications Commission Corporation. Telecom became a statutory corporation, with a separate Board of Directors, instead of Commissioners who were members of the Commission.

This structural change did not change Telecom's legal identity or status, but the separation of the enteprise and the Board assisted in a clearer definition of the roles of the Government as owner, the Board accountable for performance and Telecom management responsible for operations.

In line with the philosophy of moving from oversight of the proceeds to an emphasis on results, the Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988 also removed a range of controls over day-to-day activities such as approval of individual contract and borrowing proposals. These are now appropriately the responsibility of the Board.

This Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 replaces the Telecommunications Act 1975 under which Telecom is established, with a new Act, planned to operate from 1 July 1989. The provisions in the Telecommunications Act dealing with regulatory issues are now contained in the Telecommunications Bill 1989, which establishes the new regulatory body AUSTEL.

The Australian Telecommunications Corporation is continued in operation, again with no change of legal identity or legal status. The provisions in the Bill relating to appointment of directors and meetings of the Board, appointment of the Managing Director, and employment conditions for Telecom staff repeat, without significant changes, the new provisions inserted by the Telecommunications Amendment Act 1988.

Telecom's functions and powers have been redefined. The Bill emphasises Telecom's principal role as a provider of domestic telecommunications services, but it has subsidiary functions to allow it to engage in other business or activities within and outside Australia, related to telecommunications, and incidental functions allowing it to conduct other business in the course of fulfilling its principal role. The Bill provides Telecom with all the powers necessary to carry out its functions.

The Bill places commercial, community service and general obligations on Telecom, to perform its functions in a manner consistent with sound commercial practice. It is an integral feature of the reform packages for GBEs that commercial performance is the primary responsibility of the enterprises. However, this does not detract from Telecom's social responsibility to provide universal service, that is to deliver its community service obligations (CSOs).

Telecom's statutory CSO is the supply of a standard telephone service as efficiently and economically as practicable, reasonably accessible to all people, on an equitable basis wherever they reside or carry out business within Australia. Also there is a requirement that service performance standards must reasonably meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian community.

The importance of meeting CSOs is evident in the corporate planning process I describe below. Telecom's plan for, and delivery of, CSOs are part of the accountability measures of the Board. The costs involved will be separately identified and will be taken into account in fixing the financial target Telecom is expected to meet. AUSTEL has the function of monitoring and reporting on Telecom's delivery of its CSOs.
Telecom is also required to comply with directions by the Minister and, where these are notified in writing, government policies.

The Bill also provides for the remaining key elements of the reform strategy, that is the implementation of a new capital and financial structure and establishment of new planning and accountability mechanisms.

The Bill provides for Telecom's initial capital to be determined by the Minister for Transport and Communications as soon as possible after commencement, which will involve conversion of some part of existing Commonwealth loans to capital. Telecom's assets will be revalued before 1 July 1989. Following this, the Government will determine an appropriate debt to equity ratio for Telecom on a basis com- parable to leading telecommunications companies in other parts of the world. Telecom's assets will be revalued at least once every five years in accordance with normal commercial practice.
The Bill gives Telecom a commercially oriented financial structure with the usual commercial obligations to pay taxes and charges and appropriate dividends on owner's equity.

The removal of day-to-day controls means Telecom is no longer subject to routine oversight by Government of the way it carries on business. This Bill provides for more structured oversight by the Government, as owner, of the objectives and strategies proposed by Telecom and for the Government to indicate the financial target it expects Telecom to achieve.

The Board of Telecom will be required to prepare and revise a corporate plan for a period of between 3 and 5 years, the first plan commencing 1 July 1989. The corporate plan will set out the objectives of Telecom and its subsidiaries and outline the overall strategies and policies to be followed to achieve those objectives, including meeting its CSOs.

Financial matters to be included in the corporate plan include an overall financial target to be agreed with by the Minister, overall pricing, investment and borrowing strategies and estimates of the costs of carrying out CSOs and general governmental obligations.

The Board is to provide the Minister with a copy of the corporate plan and the Minister can direct the Board, within 30 days, to vary the financial target or the strategies and policies to meet its CSOs, or both.

The Bill also provides other accountability requirements including timely presentation of annual reports and financial statements audited by the Auditor-General, disclosure of the objectives, strategies, policies, operations and performance of Telecom and its subsidiaries, and details relating to CSOs. The Board will also be required to give the Minister prior notification of significant business activities in which Telecom and its subsidiaries propose to engage or cease to participate.

Telecom will be subject to taxation under State and Territory laws from 1 July 1989. Transitional provisions are set out in the accompanying Telecommunications and Postal Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. Telecom's current exemption from other State and Territory laws will continue until a sunset provision in the Bill comes into force on 30 December 1990. This can be extended by regulation, generally or for particular laws or classes of laws.
With the enactment of this Bill the Government will have substantially completed the implementation of the key elements of the Telecom reform package.

Some other aspects of reforms have been completed, such as revised industrial relations monitoring arrangements. Controls relating to Telecom's borrowings, executive remuneration and superannuation are under progressive review.

The Government has put in place the key elements of its reform strategy for Telecom including planning and accountability mechanisms. These, in conjunction with the measures reflected in the Telecommunications Bill 1989, will significantly change the Australian telecommunications industry.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN POSTAL CORPORATION BILL 1989

The Australian Postal Corporation Bill 1989 is the second and final stage of legislative changes to implement the Government's reform package for Australia Post, announced in the Ministerial statement of 25 May 1988 ``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises''. The first stage was implemented by the Australia Postal Services Amendment Act 1988.

A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs.

The GBEs within the Transport and Communications Portfolio, in addition to producing final goods and services for consumers, also produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, with a resulting impact on Australia's overall cost structures and the ability of Australian businesses to compete internationally. Australia Post's services are an increasingly important input factor in the production of other goods and services by Australian business for supply to domestic and international markets.

The Government sees the commercialisation of GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as Australia Post are being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with private sector competitors, and subjecting them increasingly to the disciplines of the marketplace.

As announced in the 25 May 1988 Statement, the reform package strategy for Australia Post has as its key elements the implementation of a new corporate and financial structure, establishment of new planning and accountability mechanisms, modification of major strategic controls and removal of day-to-day ministerial controls.

The Postal Services Amendment Act 1988 was principally concerned with putting in place the new corporate structure and removing ministerial controls. In particular, from 1 January 1989 the Australian Postal Commission (Australia Post) was renamed the Australian Postal Corporation. Australia Post became a statutory corporation, with a separate Board of Directors, instead of Commissioners who were members of the Commission.

This structural change did not change Australia Post's legal identity or status, but the separation of the enterprise and the Board assisted in a clearer definition of the roles of the Government as owner, the Board accountable for performance and Australia Post management responsible for operations.

In line with the philosophy of moving from oversight of the process to an emphasis on results, the Australia Postal Services Amendment Act 1988 also removed a range of controls over day-to-day activities such as approval of individual contract and borrowing proposals. These are now appropriately the responsibility of the Board.
This Australian Postal Corporation Bill 1989 replaces the Postal Services Act 1975 under which Australia Post is established, with a new Act, planned to operate from 1 July 1989.

The Australian Postal Corporation is continued in operation, again with no change of legal identity or legal status. The provisions in the Bill relating to appointment of directors and meetings of the Board, appointment of the Managing Director, and employment conditions for Australia Post staff repeat, without significant changes, the new provisions inserted by the Australia Postal Services Amendment Act 1988.

Australia Post's functions and powers have been redefined. The Bill emphasises Australia Post's principal role as a provider of domestic postal services, but it has subsidiary functions to allow it to engage in other business or activities within and outside Australia, related to postal services, and incidental functions allowing it to conduct other business in the course of fulfilling its principal role. The Bill provides Australia Post with all the powers necessary to carry out its functions.

The Bill places commercial, community service and general obligations on Australia Post, to perform its functions in a manner consistent with sound commercial practice. It is an integral feature of the reform packages for GBEs that commercial performance is the primary responsibility of the enterprises. However, it does not detract from Australia Post's social responsibility to provide universal service, that is, to deliver its community service obligations (CSOs). Australia Post's statutory CSOs are the provision of a letter service available at a single uniform rate of postage for carriage within Australia, by ordinary post, of letters that are standard postal articles. Also there is a requirement that service performance standards must reasonably meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian community.

The importance of meeting CSOs is evident in the corporate planning process I describe below. Australia Post's plans for, and delivery of, CSOs are part of the accountability measures of the Board. The costs involved will be separately identified and will be taken into account in fixing the financial target Australia Post is expected to meet.

This Bill changes significantly the way reserved services are handled compared with the Postal Services Act 1975. In that Act it was a criminal offence for anyone, other than Post to carry a letter for reward (with some exceptions). ``Letter'' was not defined and this has made it difficult to mount prosecutions.

In the Corporation bill ``letter'' is defined broadly, Post is given the exclusive right to carry letters in Australia and between Australia and overseas but there is a number of exceptions to that exclusive right.

Australia Post's power to enforce the reserved services provisions will be through the ability to seek an injunction, damages or an account of profits in the Federal Court. This should have two advantages; the issue will be dealt with in one superior court; it should allow more consideration by the court of the justification for reserved services and the effects of an infringement on the capacity of Post to meet its CSOs.
Post also has the exclusive right to issue postage stamps but no monopoly on their sale.
Australia Post is also required to comply with directions by the Minister and, where these are notified in writing, government policies.
The Bill also provides for the remaining key elements of the reform strategy, implementation of a new capital and financial structure and establishment of new planning and accountability mechanisms.

The Bill provides for Australia Post's initial capital to be determined by the Minister for Transport and Communications as soon as possible after commencement, which will involve conversion of some part of existing Commonwealth loans to capital. Australia Post's assets will be revalued before 1 July 1989. Following this, the Government will determine an appropriate debt to equity ratio for Australia Post. Australia Post's assets will be revalued at least once every five years in accordance with normal commercial practice.
The Bill gives Australia Post a commercially oriented financial structure with the usual commercial obligations to pay taxes and charges and appropriate dividends on owner's equity.

The removal of day-to-day controls means Australia Post is no longer subject to routine oversight by Government of the way it carries on business. This Bill provides for more structured oversight by the Government, as owner, of the objectives and strategies proposed by Australia Post and for the Government to indicate the financial target it expects Australia Post to achieve.

The Board of Australia Post will be required to prepare and revise a corporate plan for a period of between 3 and 5 years, the first plan commencing 1 July 1989. The corporate plan will set out the objectives of Australia Post and its subsidiaries and outline the overall strategies and policies to be followed to achieve those objectives, including meeting its CSOs.

Financial matters to be included in the corporate plan include an overall financial target to be agreed with the Minister, overall pricing, investment and borrowing strategies and estimates of the costs of carrying out CSOs and general governmental obligations.

The Board is to provide the Minister with a copy of the corporate plan and the Minister can direct the Board, within 30 days, to vary the financial target or the strategies and policies to meet its CSOs, or both.

The Bill also provides other accountability requirements including timely presentation of annual reports and financial statements audited by the Auditor-General, disclosure of the objectives, strategies, policies, operations and performance of Australia Post and its subsidiaries, and details relating to CSOs. The Board will also be required to give the Minister prior notification of significant business activities in which Australia Post and its subsidiaries propose to engage or cease to participate.

Australia Post will be subject to taxation under State and Territory laws from 1 July 1989. Transitional provisions are set out in the accompanying Telecommunications and Postal Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. Australia Post's current exemption from other State and Territory laws will continue until a sunset provision in the Bill comes into force on 30 December 1990. This can be extended by regulation, generally or for particular laws or classes of laws.
With the enactment of this Bill the Government will have substantially completed the implementation of the key elements of the Australia Post reform package.

Some other aspects of reforms have been completed, such as revised industrial relations monitoring arrangements. Controls relating to Australia Post's borrowings, executive remuneration and superannuation are under progressive review.

The Government has put in place the key elements of its reform strategy for Australia Post including planning and accountability mechanisms. These measures, in conjunction with the efficiency gains that will derive from a more commercial enterprise should result in a substantially improved postal service in Australia.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND POSTAL SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989
This Bill is related to the Telecommunications Bill 1989, the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill 1989 and the Australian Postal Corporation Bill 1989.

It repeals the Telecommunications Act 1975 and the Postal Services Act 1975, which are replaced by the new legislation and makes consequential amendments to other Acts. It also includes transitional provisions for the imposition of income tax and State and Territory taxes and charges, and for other purposes.

The Bill inserts new Parts in the Crimes Act 1914 covering postal and telecommunications offences, covering the same ground as in the existing legislation. However, the opportunity has been taken to revise the offences, taking into account developments since 1975 and treating Australia Post and the three carriers (Telecom, OTC and AUSSAT) consistently.

In some cases the existing Telecom and Australia Post offences are adequately covered by general Crimes Act provisions and have not been repeated. The consistent treatment of the three carriers is desirable because of the national importance of the telecommunications network and services and an exception has been made to the general classification of Commonwealth bodies for the Crimes Act. OTC and AUSSAT will be deemed to be public authorities for all purposes under the Crimes Act, and their employees, including people who perform services for and on behalf of AUSSAT and OTC and their employees, will be treated in the same way as Commonwealth officers.

This inclusion of OTC and AUSSAT within the Crimes Act umbrella is a temporary measure only and is subject to the Government's decision about which, if any, of its business enterprises should be so protected.

At present, Telecom and Post security personnel investigate offences under their Acts in co-operation with the Australian Federal Police, under guidelines about the break-up of responsibilities. This situation will continue. However, we have made one important change. Under the existing legislation, Telecom and Australia Post employees and any other person are given a power of arrest without warrant for certain property offences. There will be no such powers conferred under the new legislation.

The Bill repeals redundant provisions in the OTC and Satellite Communications Acts to be covered in the new Telecommunications Act and makes minor consequential amendments to bring the language into line with the language in the Telecom and Australia Post Acts.

Australia Post and Telecom will be subjected to State taxes and charges from commencement, planned for 1 July 1989. The Bill provides that the enterprises will not be subject to stamp duty or similar duties on property acquired, transactions entered into or securities issued, before the commencing day.

The transitional taxation provisions in the Bill complement the details of the imposition of income tax on Australia Post and Telecom from the 1990-91 year of income, and provide for arrangements to apply in respect of valuation of trading stock, capital gains tax and depreciation.

Austel established by the new Telecommunications Act, will investigate complaints about failure to provide telecommunications services, connect customer equipment or perform cabling work. The Bill amends the Ombudsman Act 1976 to give the Ombudsman a discretion not to investigate such complaints where Austel would deal with them more effectively, and for the transfer of the complaints.

In deciding whether or not to issue licences under the Radiocommunications Act 1983 and when imposing conditions on such licences, the Minister for Transport and Communications will now be able to take into account the policy for the regulation of telecommunications networks stated in Division 1 of Part 3 of the new Telecommunications Act.

Part 8 of the Bill contains a number of consequential amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. That Act currently affords protection from interception to communications passing over telecommunications systems provided by or with the authority of Telecom. The Act also provides for the interception of such communications in the limited circumstances specified in the Act, such as under a warrant or in connection with the operation or maintenance of the telecommunications system.

However, with the enactment of the Telecommunications Act 1989, both OTC and AUSSAT will be able to supply certain domestic telecommunications services. The amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act take account of these changes to the telecommunications industry. They are designed to preserve the ambit of the Act's prohibition on interception of communications, the scope of the provisions allowing for interceptions and the communication of information obtained thereby, in specified circumstances.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1989

On 25 May 1988 the Government released a policy statement outlining a new framework for telecommunications services in Australia. This was an integral part of the Government's third term microeconomic agenda, which emphasised the need to improve the efficiency of our economic infrastructure. The new arrangements for telecommunications were designed as part of a process of structural adjustment of key industries, with a view to establishing and sustaining longer term economic growth.
Also, the Government will continue to serve the significant social objectives associated with the important role in the Australian community of access to telephone services.

The Australian telecommunications industry is of strategic importance to both the manufacturing and service sectors of the Australian economy. It is a key to export led growth. The importance of information industries in the world economy is growing. The world's telecommunications market is currently estimated at around $400 billion per annum, more than computing, pharmaceuticals or air travel. The Australian market is about 2.5 per cent of the world market or $10 billion. Australia's telecommunications industry must be established on a sound and efficient basis, so that it can adapt to changing technologies and user needs. This will contribute to Australia's ability to compete effectively in the rapidly growing world market. Greater efficiency and competitiveness are also required if the Australian people are to continue to receive high standard communication facilities, provided efficiently, economically and on an equitable basis.

Significant reforms are being undertaken by the Government to achieve these goals. Changes to the structural frameworks of the telecommunications carriers-Telecom, OTC and AUSSAT-are being implemented separately. These changes will ensure that these Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) are more efficient, responsive and accountable to both government and Australian users of telecommunications services.

New regulatory arrangements, introduced in this Telecommunications Bill, will separate the technical and regulatory functions from the operations of the carriers and place these responsibilities in the hands of an independent industry regulator, the Australian Telecommunications Authority (Austel). Austel will also be responsible for consumer protection, promotion of competition in the industry, and monitoring the efficiency and adequacy of the services provided by carriers.

This is the most significant reform in Australian telecommunications since 1975, when the Whitlam Labor Government created two major public enterprises, Telecom and Australia Post, from the former Postmaster-General's Department.
There are five key elements in the Telecommunications Bill now before the House:
The establishment of the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, as the telecommunications industry regulator, with both technical and economic regulatory functions;
the definition of those telecommunications services which will, for reasons of network development and social objectives, be reserved to Telecom, OTC and AUSSAT;

the creation of a streamlined licensing regime for other services which, combined with safeguards against discriminatory behaviour by the carriers, will allow free and fair competition in the provision of value added services and the efficient operation of approved private networks;
the assurance of fair and open competition in the customer equipment market; and
the provision of mechanisms to ensure that consumer interests are protected and the Government's social objectives are achieved by the telecommunications industry.
Austel

As the new industry regulator, Austel will encourage the right environment for growth in the telecommunications industry. In addition to administering the provisions which define the boundaries of the monopoly, Austel will take over from Telecom the function of approving equipment for connection to the public-switched telephone network. Industry will play a major role in the development of appropriate technical standards which will be administered by Austel. There will be close co-operation between Austel and the Standards Association of Australia in the development of both mandatory and voluntary standards for the telecommunications industry.
As well as being the technical regulator, Austel will have an economic regulation role.

Austel will operate with a chair and two other statutory office holders. Austel will have approximately 70 additional staff, and the cost of running the authority is estimated to be $5 million per annum. It is our aim to have Austel operational on July 1, 1989.

It is intended for Austel to develop close links with the Trade Practices Commission, in order to assist both bodies in their respective roles of ensuring that the carriers do not misuse their monopoly powers in competitive markets. The Government intends to appoint the chair and one other member as part-time associate members of the Trade Practices Commission.

The Bill contains mechanisms to ensure that those affected by an Austel decision have the right to seek reconsideration by Austel or review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is not the intent of the Government to foster legalistic processes which could be used to thwart Austel's legitimate decision-making processes, but to ensure that those involved receive natural justice. If the appeals machinery is abused or proves too cumbersome in practice, I will move to amend the legislation as necessary.

As for other similar statutory authorities, the Government expects Austel to seek to recover some of its costs of operation from the industry. A companion piece of legislation to this Bill, the Telecommunications (Applications Fees) Bill 1989, provides for the setting of fees for a range of Austel services such as applications for variations to class licences and applications for permits to attach equipment to the network. These fees will be set to recover direct costs only and Austel will be asked to report to Government, following consultation with the industry, on the practicalities of recovering some of the other costs of its operations from the industry.

Provision has been made for a power of ministerial direction over Austel, but only as regards policy matters. This power of direction will not extend to specific decisions in individual cases. The Minister will also be able to request reports from the authority on a broad range of issues.

In this regard, I will shortly be writing to the chair of Austel to seek reports on matters affecting both the operations of Austel and the wider operations of the Telecommunications service industry. As foreshadowed in the 1988 May statement, these will include a report on the implications of licensing an additional operator of public mobile telephone services and a report on the appropriateness of the current policy on the joint use of private networks by ``common interest'' groups.
Basic Network Services

After reviewing Telecommunications policy early in 1988, the Government decided that certain services should be reserved for provision by the three established carriers only. One reason for this was network development. There is a clear need to secure the orderly and efficient development of the basic Telecommunications network by taking advantage of the economies of scale and scope that exist in the industry, and by avoiding costly and uneconomic duplication of facilities that can be most efficiently provided by a single supplier.

The other reason is the important need for universal service, which is a particular community service obligation placed on Telecom. The Government expects Telecom to provide equitable access to standard telephone services as efficiently and economically as practicable. It is therefore necessary to allow for Telecom to average its prices and practise some cross subsidy. Telecom will be specifically accountable to the Government, through Austel, which will monitor the efficiency with which Telecom meets its obligations.

This legislation provides for the continuation of a monopoly by the carriers in the provision of Telecommunications facilities. It also specifies certain services which can be provided on those facilities only by designated carriers. Telecom will be the sole domestic provider of public-switched voice, data and video services, public switched integrated services digital networks (ISDN), non-satellite leased circuits and public mobile telephone services. OTC will be the sole provider of these services internationally, and Aussat will be the sole provider of satellite facilities within Australia and is given extended scope to provide private network facilities to and from Australia. Third party carriage, or the shared use and resale of leased circuits, will continue to be prohibited.

The legislation also includes provisions to ensure equity within the industry and to encourage the efficient utilisation of our Telecommunications infrastructure. These provisions require the carriers to supply capacity on a non-discriminatory basis to all valid customers: residential or business users, private network operators or value added service providers.
Value Added Services

Beyond the reserved services, the legislation provides for full and free competition in the provision of value added services, or VAS. This Bill creates a licensing regime for VAS which will minimise Government intervention in routine commercial activities. The introduction of a class licence, subject to standard conditions, will provide for the operation of all currently approved forms of VAS. There will be no need for a VAS provider to obtain specific approval for a service which clearly falls within the class licence. A person who wishes to introduce an innovative service which is not already covered in the class licence may apply to Austel for a specific authorisation. No authorisation will be given to a service which infringes on the reserved services. If it does not infringe, the class licence will then be amended to encompass provision of the new service by any VAS operator. In this way, the costly and burdensome practice of individual licensing can be avoided.

Austel, and not the carriers, will be the arbiter of what is a value added service. Austel will thus administer the boundary determined by this legislation between the reserved services and the competitive services.

Provisions in the legislation require carriers to provide carriage for all authorised VAS, and to ensure that there is no price discrimination. The carriers will be required to maintain separate accounting arrangements for their own VAS activities, to provide a level playing field for competition in these services. This Bill maintains the status quo with regard to video and audio information and entertainment services (VAIES), but should the current review of the broadcasting legislation require amendments to this legislation, then I will move them as necessary.
Customer Equipment

With the exception of the first phone, steps have already been taken to liberalise the provision and maintenance of customer equipment. These are formally recognised in this Bill, and in conjunction with the new regime for value added services, they will open up new opportunities for Australian industry to develop and expand. The encouragement of active competition provided by this legislation is a major step towards making the Telecommunications sector stronger and more able to compete on an international level.

There is provision in the legislation to give effect to the Government's new industry development arrangements for the customer equipment manufacturing sector. These were announced in December last year and are aimed at making the industry internationally competitive. I will be directing Austel, under the legislation, to ensure that all relevant customer equipment complies with these arrangements.
Consumer Protection and Social Obligations

One of Austel's prime roles will be as a consumer watchdog, reporting on the performance of the carriers in their delivery of reserved services. It will administer the Government's formula for the price capping of basic services, which will ensure that the average price of a basket of basic telecommunications services will fall in real terms.

The legislation also provides a power for the Minister to declare that a specified reserved service charge is to be subject to notification and disallowance. This will provide an additional safeguard for consumers and Austel will be able to give advice to the Minister on pricing practices for carrier reserved services.

Austel will also report to Government on the performance of Telecom in meeting its community service obligations, including its responsibility to provide universal service and other socially necessary services such as public telephones.

With regard to consumer complaints, Austel may deal with them itself if general regulatory considerations are involved, or it may direct them to the Trade Practices Commission or the Federal Ombudsman. It is not intended that Austel will take over any of the Ombudsman's current activities regarding the investigation of individual complaints. Appropriate arrangements will be developed to coordinate the work of Austel and the Ombudsman's office. Austel will, however, have a responsibility to investigate complaints that raise regulatory questions, and it will work closely with the Ombudsman's office to ensure that complaints against the carriers are investigated promptly and that any necessary follow-up action is taken.

It is intended that there will be a review of the respective roles of Austel and the Ombudsman within two years of Austel's creation to ensure that consumer complaints are being handled as effectively as possible.

The Government is confident that these measures-establishing an independent regulator, defining specific community service obligations for Telecom, guaranteeing that average price rises for basic telecommunications services fall in real terms, introducing new accountability arrangements for the carriers-will protect the rights of consumers and ensure that the Telecommunications industry fulfils important social obligations and contributes to national economic growth.

This Bill has widespread support within both the telecommunications services industry and the general community. There was extensive consultation with interested groups before the Government's decisions relating to telecommunications reform were announced in May 1988, and this consultation has continued. A draft of this Bill was made available to the industry for comment and a wide range of interested groups responded. While this legislation incorporates the results of these consultations, the Bill does not simply reflect the demands of sectional interests.

This Bill is an important element in the Government's program of microeconomic reform. It serves the interests of the telecommunications industry and at the same time it legislates for the continuation of universal service. It will benefit all members of the Australian community.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (APPLICATION FEES) BILL 1989

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1989 and provides for the setting of fees for a range of applications to the Australian Telecommunications Authority. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON PAPER PULP MILLS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Paper Pulp Mills in Australia, be established to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the environmental, economic and social impact of the establishment of additional paper pulp mills in Australia; and
(b) the feasibility of paper recycling and the use of alternative materials and processes to extend timber resources and reduce pollution.
(2) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and that the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of two or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee present its final report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in October 1989.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and, in that event:
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

This motion deals with the establishment of a select committee to examine paper pulp mills in Australia. Paper pulp mills will be very much on the Australian political and environmental agenda in the near future, as they have been in the recent past. What is happening, of course, is that the paper pulp producers in the Northern Hemisphere, having depleted their resource and having so aroused the ire of the populace that they are no longer able to operate there without environmental pollution controls, are coming to Australia to use our resources and our hitherto lax environmental laws to their advantage. These pulp mills are coming. There is no way they will stop coming. It is as if we are sitting in the middle of a railway track and a locomotive is coming at us with a big headlight, it is very apparent, and we are not doing anything about it. If we do not get off that track we will get run over by that locomotive. Politicians and society in general-but I suppose politicians more than most-look for simple solutions. They think that by merely making a statement about pulp mills the problem will go away. There is no such thing in the real world as a simple solution. Aiding and abetting the wish of a simple solution by the politicians is the media. The media also likes to simplify things.

There is a lot of confusion at the moment over pulp mills-what they mean, what they may produce in terms of wealth for this country and what the disadvantages are. There is so much confusion over this issue that as I stand here speaking I have not been told officially by either the Opposition or the Government what the outcome of this discussion will be. I do not know whether they are for this committee or against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they know?

—As Senator Haines says, do they know? I am not sure that they do. The Opposition is very much in disarray at the moment. A journalist told me-I only have this second-hand-that the Opposition would like to defer this issue until after the Budget.
—After the Tasmanian election.

—After the Tasmanian election, as Senator Haines says, and further down into the never-never. It has already been delayed far too much. This is an issue of very great importance and the Opposition is using it as a political football. I do not know what the Government's attitude is, although I suspect that it will not support this matter. I will go into the reasons why I think the Government will not support it a little later. There is a tremendous amount of confusion over pulp mills in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The first issue which was raised was dioxins. I think we owe North Broken Hill Peko Ltd and Noranda Forest Inc. a great debt of gratitude for raising the issue as ineptly as they did. They actually did the nation a service because they focused the nation's attention on pulp mills. They were very ham- fisted and dictatorial in the way they did it, which is the way they operate. They forced the Gray Government to do backflips over their requirements and then they tried to force the Federal Government to do the same thing. I think that this points out the need for an inquiry.

The Federal Government knew so little about pulp mills at the time that even though it wanted to give the go ahead to Noranda and North Broken Hill, it made it impossible for Noranda to go ahead because it set guidelines which Noranda could not possibly accept. The Government wishes to give the go ahead to a project, but because it knew so little about it, it actually squashed the project by asking Noranda to do what was technologically feasible and possible in terms of controlling effluent. Noranda could not afford to do that because if it produced a relatively environmentally pollution-free plant in Tasmania it would have to do so in Canada and it did not want to do that with its many mills in Canada. It wants to run them wide open at great detriment to the environment.

The net result of all this is that there is a lot of confusion over what is an environmentally clean pulp mill. Somehow the argument runs that as long as it does not use chlorine bleaches it is clean. This is absolutely false. Chlorine, of course, does introduce a great number of pollutants into the environment. The dioxins which were discussed in the Wesley Vale issue are not the only things that a pulp mill produces. The kraft process which the Wesley Vale mill and many mills around the world use is a very old process which uses sulphate chemicals to break down the fibres of wood. It has great environmental problems. If honourable senators go to any pulp mill town in the northern hemisphere they will be immediately assaulted by the smell of sulphur in the air. The water and the air are polluted. Just having an unbleached paper mill is not the solution to the problem, but that is the way the argument seems to be running at the moment. There is an article in yesterday's Hobart Mercury entitled `Can do unbleached: ANM'. It states:
Australian Newsprint Mills at Boyer said it was able to supply all the Federal Government's needs for unbleached paper.
ANM's marketing manager, Mr Rocky Wells, said Boyer already made newsprint and other publication papers using pulps other than the chlorine-bleached chemical pulps used by most other papermakers.
Last Saturday the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, announced a feasibility study on an unbleached-paper mill-
unbleached, again-
with a promise that the Federal Government would switch to such paper.
Mr Wells said the government could avoid using chlorine-bleached paper by using ANM's papers for many purposes including circulars.
Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd (ANM) has killed the Derwent River with pollution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—With rubbish, as Senator Calvert says. ANM has killed the Derwent River with pollution, with its sludge. It has caused so much pollution that its stretch of the Derwent is almost devoid of healthy marine life. Merely having a mechanical process, as ANM does, does not necessarily produce a clean environment. So unbleached paper is not in itself the answer. Nevertheless, the opinion in the community seems to be that it is. An article headed `Company may build unbleached paper mill' in the Australian of 10 May 1989 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A private company considering building a paper mill at Grafton on the NSW north coast might produce unbleached paper, the NSW Parliament heard yesterday.

The NSW Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Causley, said the company, Daishowa International- our friends from the south-east New South Wales forests; they want to expand into the northern part of the State-
had made it clear it would consider building an unbleached paper mill, and take pulp to Japan, if a bleached paper mill was unacceptable to local people.

There is now the impression that merely having an unbleached paper mill is the solution. Of course, it is not. Other problems are ignored and the select committee would cover them. I refer, for example, to problems with the resource itself. Is the resource available? Are the trees available? What about alternatives to trees? What about agricultural crops such as kino, hemp and other fibre crops? What about the use of recycling in pulp mills? These things are not covered by the simple minded pursuit of an unbleached mill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you see a great future for hemp, Senator?

—There is a great future for hemp. There always has been. As Senator Puplick knows, the first paper actually came from hemp and its derivatives. It makes a wonderful fibre. It facilitates the use of the thermo-mechanical process, incidentally.
—You can read it and then smoke it, is that it?

—Whatever turns you on, Senator. There is a Government reluctance to have this industry. I contacted the Minister for primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, over this and he said, `Oh, such an inquiry might jeopardise existing mills'. If it does, what is wrong with that? If these mills are operating in such a manner as to harm the environment, why should they not be jeopardised? Why should they not clean up as well?

SPEECH.PARA: We need environment friendly processes. The environment movement is not for closing down society and going out in the scrub, eating muesli and ignoring all the problems of employment and all that, as has been portrayed by the Opposition and some members of the Government. In fact, we do look for viable downstream processing of our trees, of all of our resources. There are ways to produce paper which are environmentally friendly. One way is by use of the thermo-mechanical processes which have been developed in Sweden. Thermo-mechanical processes are not new. Newsprint is always made this way. But as we can see from any newspaper, the paper is yellow and rather fuzzy. The Swedes have developed processes to make the paper suitable for the best quality paper, computer grade paper. This high grade paper can now be made with the thermo-mechanical process, using steam-brute force and ignorance, if you want, rather than chemicals-and bleaching with hydrogen peroxide which liberates no chloride into the atmosphere or into the water.

I have read accounts in the Australian press that our paper manufacturers say that this is impossible. Of course it is not impossible; it is done overseas. I note that the Government is sending experts overseas to look at this very thing. That is fine. But I reiterate that the Government does not really have its money where its mouth is if it is going to vote against the inquiry into the pulp mills. The Government has it about half right when it talks about the environmental pollution aspects of pulp mills.

The other issue, which they are not looking at, is the use of the resource. Thermal mechanical pulping uses half the number of trees as a chemical mill to produce the equivalent amount of paper. The Government has not mentioned this. I do not know if it intends to look at it, but it is a very important factor. The kraft process, the chemical process which these high-flying international paper companies are trying to foist off on Australia, is as dead as a dodo. Nobody is building kraft process mills anywhere in the world. Everybody is going to thermo-mechanical processes. This Government still seems ready to entertain the emplacement of kraft process mills.

I do not know how the vote will go on this matter. I will learn very shortly from the Government and the Opposition. But I still have the very basic feeling that neither the Government nor the Opposition is taking this issue seriously enough. Our environment obviously is too important to be left in the hands of politicians. Our politicians are simply incapable of looking after our future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issues which this motion has raised are indeed important issues. I can assure Senator Sanders that the Opposition takes this matter seriously. For that reason I wish to indicate that we will be seeking to adjourn this debate for further consideration. At the conclusion of my speech Senator Reid will be moving that this matter be adjourned and that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in August. The purpose of our doing that is that the Government, as Senator Sanders has indicated, has now responded to some of the concerns about the impact of paper pulp mills in Australia by commissioning a team of experts from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to travel to Scandinavia and, I believe, subsequently to Canada to undertake certain investigations on two matters. They will cover some of the technical standards dealing with paper pulp mills in terms of their environmental impact and also the team will examine the processes which are put in place for the development and approval of such proposals. Presumably they will be focusing, for example, on the operations of the Swedish Franchising Board arrangements where a series of well-established processes now provide for the analysis, public examination and environmental consideration of proposals. They provide a certainty, not of outcome but of process.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been critical of the uncertainty of process which has been involved in the series of decisions made about these issues, culminating in the decision which this Government announced not to approve the development of the Wesley Vale facility. There are significant issues, including the question of dioxin emission, the emissions other than dioxin from kraft mill operations and processes and the problems which are associated with unbleached pulp production in terms of both the alternatives to the way in which we currently produce paper and paper products and the availability of resources to establish new mills. It is certainly also true that on both sides of the argument there is a commitment to try to do something about producing a greater value added component in our forestry industry and forest products industry. The consequences of the $1.6 billion annual deficit in forest products are something taken seriously by everybody in terms of both their economic impact and the necessary integration of these with proper environmental standards and requirements. Therefore I do not want to go into the specific details of the issues which such an inquiry could address other than to repeat that the matters which Senator Sanders and others have raised are taken very seriously by the Opposition.

We indicated at an early stage our general support for the examination of these matters. We indicated, in a press statement which I issued on 21 March, our general support for an inquiry into establishing the facts of these matters. On 6 April, together with Mr Howard, I put out a statement which indicated that we wanted to examine this matter in the light of the Government's response to calls that had been widely made for the publication of development guidelines, both in terms of technical standards and in terms of processes for evaluating pulp mill proposals. We said we would be interested to see that information no later than 2 May. On 2 May Senator Button, Mr Kerin and Senator Richardson issued a joint statement in which they announced the establishment and dispatch of the CSIRO mission to which I have referred. That press statement said:
A report on technical issues will be provided as soon as possible and not later than June 30.
We believe it is necessary to see that report before this matter is finally determined by the Senate.

Senator Sanders has indicated the importance of sending this mission overseas. He described it as `fine'; I think that was his word. We believe that the information which will be gained by that inquiry needs to be part of the public record and debate. If that leads to adequate satisfaction of the technical issues which have been raised, and if it leads to the adequate establishment of guidelines in terms of processes, which is the other part of the equation with which the Opposition is particularly concerned, then we will be able to determine whether or not a further inquiry is necessary. We are not in a position to make that determination at this stage, and it is for that reason-in order to have the CSIRO report available to us-that we are seeking to have this matter put off until the first sitting day after 30 June, which happens to be the first sitting day of the Budget session.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are hopeful!

—I acknowledge the Minister's interjection, and take no comfort from it whatsoever. Let us assume that commonsense prevails-which is not always a valid assumption in this place-and the first sitting day after 30 June is, in fact, the first sitting day in the August Budget session. It is for those reasons that my colleague, Senator Reid, will now move to adjourn the debate to that date, and I understand that we will have the support of the Government in that endeavour.

That the debate be now adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Reid) agreed to:
