CHAIRMAN-The Committee is dealing now with the section of the Bills on the structure and role of the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In respect of the Australian Securities Commission Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 7, subclause 9 (1), lines 30 and 31, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``9. (1) The Commission shall consist of 7 or 8 members.''.
(3) Page 7, subclause 9 (3), lines 34 to 36, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(3) Of the members, 3 shall be appointed as full-time members and the others shall be appointed as part-time members.''.
(4) Page 8, subclause 9 (5), lines 4 to 8, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:

``(5) The performance of the functions or the exercise of the powers of the Commission is not affected merely because its membership is not as prescribed by subsections (1) and (3), unless a continuous period of 3 months has elapsed since its membership ceased to be as so prescribed.''.

These amendments deal with the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation concerning the composition of the panel and the relationship between full time and part time members. The Committee heard a great deal of evidence in regard to this matter and, as that is contained in its report, I do not intend to rehearse those arguments again. Extremely strong support was provided by the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) for the continuation of the notion of members' part time involvement. On a number of occasions he made it very clear in his evidence that those part time members had played a most valuable role in the Commission's operations in linking the Commission to the business world. Those part time members had brought an enormous amount of expertise and day to day practical advice which enhanced the Commission's task far more than would have been the case if those people who had been employed were detached from or were outside the mainstream of the business community. That very strong endorsement from the Chairman of the NCSC and other evidence that was taken by the Committee led the Committee to recommend unanimously in favour of the continuation of the majority of members of the Commission as part time members. These amendments would implement that recommendation of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats in regard to this recommendation. However, we accept the thrust of the Committee's proposal that the Australian Securities Commission has access to input from expert business opinion as this is vital for the viable operation of the ASC. However, we do not accept this amendment and we ask honourable senators to take into account other changes that were recommended by the Committee to meet the policy objectives. Clause 9 of the proposed legislation is identical to the NCSC Act in that it provides that the ASC will consist of between three and eight members, at least three of whom will be appointed full time. This proposal in the ASC legislation does not deviate from the current system where, at the moment, five part time members are appointed in the structure. However, recognising the need for expert business opinion and for flexibility to be inherent in the legislation, the Government believes that the Committee's intention will be partly met by three-year terms for full time members of the ASC-members with a high level of business and market expertise. This shorter term should go some way towards meeting the objective of having people with experience in the commercial sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the other problem that arises, which honourable senators should take into account, is that the Government also recognises that whereas, on the one hand, part time members are important, on the other hand, it is vitally important to have people who will devote their full time attention to the job at hand. That is important not only in terms of their input but also in terms of their oversight of the bureaucracy. The Government also recognises that, in terms of full time appointments as opposed to part time appointments, there is some merit in having full time members who are detached from the day to day operations of business activities which may be subject to the operations of the ASC.
In summary, we support the rationale behind the recommendation, but we believe that we need flexibility and our proposals will accommodate the need for commercial expertise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, obviously we have considered this matter carefully and, on reflection, we have decided to support the Government's position. By doing so, we are not in any way indicating that we are not supportive of part time members; in fact, we are, but we think there is sufficient scope within the existing legislation to allow for that. The existing section states that there should be not fewer than three or more than eight members and that at least three of the members should be appointed as full time members. So there is scope in the existing provision for possibly five part time members. On that basis we do not think it is necessary to write into law the constraint that was recommended by the Committee. We think that the provision that exists at the moment can meet the spirit of the Committee's recommendation without the strictures that would be provided by the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In respect of the Australian Securities Commission Bill I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 8, after subclause 11 (2), insert the following new subclause:

``(2a) The Commission may, on its own initiative or when requested by the Minister, advise the Minister, and make to the Minister such recommendations as it thinks fit, about any matter of a kind referred to in section 148.''.
(6) Page 9, subclause 11 (4), line 1, leave out ``subsection (3),'', insert ``subsection (2a) or (3),''.

This was a matter of continuing discussion yesterday. Our drafting differed somewhat from that on which the Government had advice. We were happy to concede to the Government's drafting in this matter in that it was more elegant than our own. However, the intent is the same-that is, that the Commission would be provided with power to make recommendations to the Minister but it would not be obliged to do so. In other words, there is no intent in this amendment to require the Commission to spend any money or consider it part of its statutory functions to have to make recommendations. This amendment would provide the Commission with the ability to make a recommendation if it wanted to do so. At the lowest level that makes clear what the Commission wants-that is, to have the ability to talk to the Minister about some matter that it may feel deeply about without necessarily going to the Advisory Committee. It seems to us that there are no problems with that. This amendment addresses the problem that the Government put up-that the Commission would have to spend money analysing policy which, quite rightly, is the function of the Advisory Committee. We do not want the Commission to be doing that. Clearly, the intent of this amendment is merely to allow the Commission, if it wishes, to speak to the Minister about a matter without going to the Advisory Committee. We believe that it is not likely that this would occur frequently, particularly because of the Government's intention to put a member of the Commission on the Advisory Committee. We certainly endorse that second position of the Minister, and we feel that this would fill out the powers of the Commission. We see no sensible reason why the Commission, if it feels deeply about some matter, should not be able to talk directly to the Minister or give advice and direction to the Minister on any matter that it desires under section 148.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Australian Democrats' amendment in this regard as we think the existing provision is unduly restrictive. The amendment makes sense to us and will improve the legislative package. As Senator Macklin has said, we do not anticipate that this will become a major function of the Commission. But to give the Commission simply this capacity or power seems to us to be a sensible addition; therefore it has our support.

(7) Page 81, before Part 13, insert the following new Part:
``PART 12B-THE PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE
Establishment and membership

``230fa. (1) As soon as practicable after the commencement of this Part and after the commencement of the first session of each Parliament, a joint committee of members of the Parliament, to be known as the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, shall be appointed.
``(2) The Parliamentary Committee shall consist of 10 members, of whom:
(a) 5 shall be senators appointed by the Senate; and
(b) 5 shall be members of the House of Representatives appointed by that House.
``(3) The appointment of members by a House shall be in accordance with that House's practice relating to the appointment of members of that house to serve on joint select committees of both Houses.
``(4) A person is not eligible for appointment as a member if he or she is:
(a) a Minister;
(b) the President of the Senate;
(c) the Speaker of the House of Representatives;
(d) the Deputy-President and Chairman of Committees of the Senate; or
(e) the Chairman of Committees of the House of Representatives.
``(5) A member ceases to hold office;
(a) when the House of Representatives expires or is dissolved;
(b) if he or she becomes the holder of an office referred to in a paragraph of subsection (4);
(c) if he or she ceases to be a member of the House by which he or she was appointed; or
(d) if he or she resigns his or her office as provided by subsection (6) or (7), as the case requires.
``(6) A member appointed by the Senate may resign his or her office by writing signed and delivered to the President of the Senate.
``(7) A member appointed by the House of Representatives may resign his or her office by writing signed and delivered to the Speaker of that House.
``(8) A House may appoint one of its members to fill a vacancy among the members of the Parliament Committee appointed by that House.
Powers and proceedings
``230fb. Subject to this Act, all matters relating to the Parliamentary Committee's powers and proceedings shall be determined by resolution of both Houses.
Duties
``230fc. (1) The Parliamentary Committee's duties are:
(a) to inquire into, and report to both Houses on:
(i) activities of the Commission or the Panel, or matters connected with such activities, to which, in the Parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed; or

(ii) the operation of any national scheme law, or of any other law of the Commonwealth, of a State or Territory or of a foreign country that appears to the Parliamentary Committee to affect significantly the operation of a national scheme law;

(b) to examine each annual report that is prepared by a body established by this Act and of which a copy has been laid before a House, and to report to both Houses on matters that appear in, or arise out of, that annual report and to which, in the Parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed; and
(c) to inquire into any question in connection with its duties that is referred to it by a House, and to report to that House on that question.
``(2) The Parliamentary Committee shall not:
(a) investigate a matter that the Commission has investigated or is investigating, or that the Panel or the Disciplinary Board has considered, is considering or is about to consider;
(b) require a person to give to the Parliamentary Committee information about:
(i) an investigation that the Commission is making; or
(ii) a hearing before the Commission, the Panel or the Disciplinary Board that is taking place in private; or

(c) reconsider an act, omission, decision or finding that the Commission, the Panel or the Disciplinary Board has done or made in the performance or exercise, in relation to a particular case, of any of its functions and powers.
Findings of Parliamentary Committee not to be evidence in proceedings
``230FD. In a proceeding:
(a) the fact that the Parliamentary Committee has found a fact or matter to exist is not evidence of that fact or matter; and
(b) evidence of a finding by the Parliamentary Committee is not admissible for the purpose of proving a fact or matter that the Parliamentary Committee has found to exist.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have two amendments, Nos 7 and 8, rather than amendments Nos 6 and 7 as listed, to proposed amendment No. 7. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 3, proposed subsection 230fc (2), leave out the proposed subsection.
(8) Page 3, proposed section 230fd, leave out the proposed section.

I am not sure that these amendments need to be debated at length. It is fortuitous that both the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and Senator Hill are as familiar as I am with the proposition governing this area, because a similar problem arose in the interpretation of the law with regard to the establishment of the parliamentary committee which dealt with the National Crimes Authority (NCA).

Undoubtedly, in terms of the drafting provided by the Government, proposed section 230fc (2) and proposed section 230fd were both included in an abundance of caution or an abundance of something else. Whatever it was, a little of the history of the NCA committee would have rapidly disabused the minds of those who put them in of the problem that they perceived to be existing, which is not there, that is, that the parliamentary committee in no way will seek to inhibit, prevent or get in the way of the legitimate operation of the Commission, the panel or the disciplinary board. The role of the parliamentary committee will, in fact, be far more a supportive mechanism, an investigatory mechanism, so that it can report to Parliament on whether or not any changes in the law should occur.

The difficulty with the way this is drafted is that it says that it is not allowed to investigate a matter-again both the Minister and Senator Hill know it depends on what is meant by `investigate'-that has been investigated or is to be investigated or is about to be considered or has been considered or is being considered. It is also stated that there can be no reconsideration of an act, an omission, a decision or a finding. The NCA committee soon found that, if that is interpreted literally, all the committee can do is actually meet. It could not actually do anything that would be of any use to the Parliament. Our parliamentary committees will, in future, be as responsible as they have been in the past. There is no need for proposed section 230fc (2) because it is restrictive in a way that could render the work of the Committee totally ineffective.

Secondly, section 230fd is a most extraordinary proposition. It says that the fact that the parliamentary committee has found a fact or matter to exist is not evidence of that fact or matter. As it has never been evidence of a fact or matter under any rules of evidence I do not know why that is there. It could have application to a tribunal not bound by the rules of evidence but, quite frankly, it is highly unlikely that any tribunal could admit as evidence a finding of fact by a parliamentary committee.

My real concern about 230fd is paragraph (b). I have served on the Joint Committee on Parliamentary Privilege and hence have a continuing interest in this matter. I was the person in this place who made the suggestion that we should break the log jam on this matter by getting the Presiding Officers to introduce the Parliamentary Privileges Bill, which they eventually did. I believe that 230fd (b) could be a very dangerous proposition. It is not something of minor concern but rather it is something that is very dangerous to the Parliament. It seeks to prohibit something that section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 already does. The difficulty is that section 16 defines the proceedings in Parliament to include a report of a parliamentary committee, hence it is relevant to this, and prohibits the admission of evidence concerning proceedings in Parliament for the purpose of, amongst other things, drawing, or inviting the drawing of, inferences or conclusions from those proceedings in Parliament.

Apart from any new provisions being redundant because the matter is already covered, the view could be taken in subsequent litigation that, because the Parliament had passed that new provision, it had made some interpretation of section 16. One interpretation could be that the Parliament did not intend section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act to prohibit the admission of evidence concerning a finding by a parliamentary committee. Those people who were involved in the privileges legislation know how crucial section 16 is to us. Some court findings prompted this Parliament finally to take action. An interpretation of what proceedings of the Parliament or its committees can or cannot be admitted in a court is vitally important for our freedom as parliamentarians so that we can act in a way we believe is proper and in the general interest. That freedom should not be circumscribed in any fashion by any court.

To go down the path suggested here with, as it were, a throw-away line in the legislation now before us could be quite dangerous. The Parliament should not contemplate for an instant the passage of legislation which brings into doubt some part of the Parliamentary Privileges Act which was passed by this place, after 87 years of federation, with a great deal of blood, sweat and tears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin was right when he said that he and I, together with Senator Hill, had served on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and had been able to experience first hand some of the frustrations on that Committee. In opposing, at least, the deletion of proposed subsection 230fc (2), I would like to say that I have also served on other parliamentary committees that have gone out of control because there was no restraint on their role of investigation. I am sure that Senator Hill can remember one or two committees that investigated matters that were at the same time under investigation by law enforcement officers.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it is very fair to say that the Government position is that we support the idea of a parliamentary committee with a viable function. But we are concerned, particularly if subclause 230fc (2) is deleted, that a number of problems would emanate. If one looks at paragraphs (a) and (b) of that particular subclause one will find a prohibition on the committee to:
. . . investigate a matter that the Commission . . . or that the Panel or Disciplinary Board . . . is considering.

Those two paragraphs are basically intended by the Government to ensure that the parliamentary Committee does not interfere with current investigative or deliberative activities of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) or the Corporations and Securities Panel and so on. I would be surprised to hear anyone in this place disagreeing with that proposition.

Paragraph (c) is also important in that it ensures that the proposed parliamentary Committee does not function as an alternative avenue of appeal against decisions of the Panel or the ASC. In principle, members of parliament would agree that they would not want a parliamentary Committee to be seen as an avenue of appeal in cases that have been adjudicated or deliberated upon. Having accepted those two particular principles and the fact that even Senator Macklin acknowledged that he does not think the parliamentary Committee would interfere with current investigations or deliberations or would be seen as an alternative avenue of appeal, for us not to agree to these particular provisions may leave the intention of the Parliament blurred to the extent that a committee may in the future see itself as having an open charter. We think there are inherent dangers in not retaining sub-clause 230fc (2). As a consequence, we oppose the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party had circulated an amendment in similar terms to the first of these amendments but the Chairman chose to call the Australian Democrats first. It will not, therefore, surprise the chamber that, as our amendment is in exactly the same terms, we will now be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment. Although we did not have an amendment with regard to the second, we nevertheless will support that also. If I had spoken first I would have said very much the same things as Senator Macklin said in support of his amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the first amendment, the Government is unduly worried about the operations of this parliamentary Committee, unlike apparently the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) since he has assumed his higher role. It is my view that parliamentary committees act responsibly. There is no reason to believe that this Committee would do other than act responsibly. There can be no concern in relation to the second of the committee's duties as set out in the legislation, that is, to inquire into and report to both Houses on the operation of any national scheme law.

I presume that that duty is not an area of concern to the Minister. So the area of concern must be the first of its duties, which is to inquire into and report to both Houses on activities of the Australian Securities Commission or the Corporations and Securities Panel, or matters connected with such activity, to which, in the parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed. The Committee is charged, where necessary, to inquire into and report on the activities of the Commission or the Panel, or matters connected with such activity.

The Minister says that we need to incorporate within the legislation specific prohibitions on the Committee, in effect meddling with investigations being carried on by the Commission or the Panel. That seems to me to be unnecessary. The terms of duties suggest that the Committee is not interested in the detail of the investigation or in second guessing the work of those two bodies. Its responsibility is basically to report to and advise the Houses if problems are developing in relation to the operation of the Commission or the Panel. It seems to the Opposition, therefore, that it is unnecessary to add these restrictions that the Government has sought to add by its subsection (2). One can even envisage situations where it could significantly inhibit the work of the Committee in areas in which I would not have thought the Government had any concerns. Although a matter may be current, some investigations by the Commission or the Panel may last for a very long time and include within them many individual matters. In relation to one of those individual matters there may be some abuse of natural justice or some concern by an individual as to whether reasonable rights are being afforded. The Committee may well receive representations from that individual. On the Government's restrictive wording it would mean that the Committee could not address those specific concerns until the investigation had been completed, which might be a year or two later.

We therefore oppose the restrictive wording, but we do so not in any way envisaging that the parliamentary Committee will abuse the responsibilities that are given to it under this charter. It is included as a safeguard for the benefit of all who are subjected to this legislation-that is, the total community. We would like to see the parliamentary Committee given the widest possible powers to meet the responsibility as set out under the heading `Duties' in this particular clause. We therefore would support the Democrats in this instance in relation to both their amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be seen as teaching the Minister for Consumer Affairs or Senator Hill how to suck eggs because I think that their skills in counting numbers are much more honed than mine, as they have to use them far more often. If the Minister looks at amendment No. 2 in proposed new section 230fa, he will notice that the structure of the Committee is 10 members, five from the Senate and five from the House of Representatives. By definition, if an alternative majority in the Senate appointed five non-government senators, the Government, which controls the House of Representatives, could retaliate by appointing five members of its own Party from the House of Representatives. Therefore there would be a break-even number and the Committee would be unable to function at all. The government of the day ought have no concerns that the Committee will get out of control. I think that that type of number exercise would never have to be used but ultimately, if it actually makes anybody feel any better, it is fairly obvious that the Committee will be working within the constraints of the parliamentary majorities which are available.

The question is that Democrat amendment No. 7 to Government amendment No. 8 be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very familiar with the tracing argument. It has been the subject of some negotiation. I believe I have some amendments in the form of a draft which the Government, as a result of our negotiations, had prepared today, and which we would seek to adopt. I am quite happy to move the Government's draft if the Chair has it.
—You had better be more precise as to the wording and heading of it. I have your amendments, but not your version of the Government's amendments. Perhaps Senator Bolkus can help us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill is right; we have had some discussions on this and a proposal was drafted for the consideration of the Joint Standing Committee, which proposal has been amended to accommodate another part of it. I have a copy of that now. My understanding was that Senator Hill, rather than the Government, would move it this morning. That is where the confusion has arisen.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, the proposal is to allow companies to trace beneficial ownership, but to do so they would have to pay a prescribed fee. I understand that Senator Hill will now move the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to describe clearly what the amendment is, Senator Hill. I am not clear at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While discussion is going on, I make a contribution on this point. The Joint Select Committee of Corporations Legislation, in terms of tracing beneficial ownership, made a recommendation that would allow the continuation of the status quo. The problem, however, with the continuation of the status quo is fairly obvious. A company can be in receipt of a notice to provide the requisite registers and listings of ownership, without any cost being provided by the person who asked for that information. Over time, a number of companies as a matter of course each day asked for these ongoing exercises to be undertaken by some other company at that other company's expense. Prior to the consideration, I indicated that if the Opposition were minded to move that amendment, the Australian Democrats would support it. It is my understanding that in subsequent discussions the notion of trying to trace beneficial ownership-that is, the current context-might be modified by putting in a fee structure.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a fee structure, it is thought that at least companies will be mindful that they are paying the costs rather than the persons doing the search. The hope flowing from that, I suppose, is that the amount of paperwork might be materially reduced. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I indicate that that approach would certainly also have our support. I hope that Senator Hill and the Minister have come to an agreement along those lines. I have not been privy to that discussion, but any such agreement was made after the early discussions we had on this matter. If that is the approach that it is proposed to take, I indicate that it would have our support.

The approach could not be objected to by industry. As all parties are aware, there is a split in industry on this matter. If industry has in one way or another to meet these payments, it is obvious as a matter of fairness and justice that the people who are seeking the information should meet them. There is one other item in this area, in that the existing Commission has the power to trace beneficial ownership at the request of a company. I assume that it is proposed that that remain, because undoubtedly that is another avenue and one which, as the Government in previous debates has rightly pointed out, would probably also remove most of the abuses. With both of those in tow, I would have thought that a mechanism of payment, while still allowing a company to undertake a search on its own cognisance, would probably be the optimal way to go and would be a reasonable and effective compromise, considering the contending interests in this area. I hope that is the type of amendment that is now being proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Committee has reached a stage of some confusion, so I will clarify what is going on. As I understand it, this new set of amendments, which will be substituted for Government amendments Nos. 19 to 29, consists of 17 amendments. Senator Bolkus has already moved Government amendments Nos. 19 to 29. This draft to which Senator Hill referred is not in the form of an amendment to Senator Bolkus's amendment. If the Opposition wishes to pursue its amendments, if it is the wish of the Committee it will have to move to negative Senator Bolkus's amendments and then move its amendments as a substitute.
—Senator Bolkus might wish to withdraw his amendments.
—He does not wish to withdraw them, he has said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow that I will move certain amendments as a substitute for Government Nos. 19 to 29. Much of them is common. What is not common is the capacity for a corporation to search, and the difference that has been negotiated by the Government, the Australian Democrats and us is to include the safeguard of a fee. In other words, obviously we are all looking for a reasonable solution to this matter. Certainly the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have the view that there should be a right of search. On the other hand, we recognise that that can be abused and we want a mechanism to avoid abuse. The mechanism which seemed to us most sensible was a fee basis. There are other alternatives, such as including a specified number of shares, a specified percentage of shares, or a specified percentage of the capital of a company, all of which we thought were less satisfactory than simply allowing for a fee.

SPEECH.PARA: The fee would be prescribed by regulation and payable to the company that meets the requirement, the idea being that therefore the company that has to provide the information is recompensed for at least a reasonable proportion of its costs in doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is mindful that the Corporations Bill before the Committee limits the power of companies to trace beneficial ownership. However, we have proposed an amendment to provide that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) has the capacity to do that on the payment of a prescribed fee and when it is not of the view that it is unreasonable to request the person to whom a notice may be addressed to respond to those matters. Essentially, the Government is concerned about this abuse of the system. Such abuse quite often means that a great degree of expense is incurred by corporations and also often means obtaining strategically important information, beneficial only to a board of directors rather than corporate interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, recognising the will of the Senate, also recognises that one important mechanism in terms of curtailing abuse will be the provision that a requesting party pay a prescribed fee in order to get that particular corporation to trace beneficial ownership and, as such, sees the Liberal amendment as much more positive with the fee than without it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, we are talking about the tracing provisions and the changes that are being proposed to what is, in effect, section 261 of the old Companies Act. So far as I can see, I really do not understand the reasons for the changes that are being proposed by the Government to that tracing provision, having lived some time in the corporate world myself. I would say that the ability of a company itself to initiate a trace rather than having to work through any third party-in this case, the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) or the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) poses very considerable constraints on the company. I do not understand the reasons for that requirement. It is possible, I guess, that the tracing provisions can be abused in terms of overuse. On the other hand, there is nothing more important to a company than its ability to know as of right who are its main shareholders and which significant transactions are taking place at any particular time on its register.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Government's proposals, as I understand them, is to prevent the company from doing that, to take away what I think is a quite fundamental right of a company. The question of fees for tracing, matters pertaining to that and other provisions possibly required to prevent abuse of the procedure are matters which may well require looking at but I do not understand why the change of the quite significant nature that is being proposed is necessary in order to deal with those other points. I seek clarification from the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) as to what specifically are the reasons why a company should not be able directly to request a trace of its shareholding and significant changes in its shareholding. It takes away a quite fundamental right that a company should have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly in response to Senator Short, I think honourable senators should be mindful of the fact that the Government has had somewhat unanimous representation from the business community in respect to this proposal. Concern has been that even with minor movement of shares, such as daily movement--
—I would be surprised if it was unanimous since the business organisations have written to us and, undoubtedly, to you.

—Let us say that the representations made to us have been unanimous. The concern has been that even a minor movement of shares-as I said, movement which could be a daily movement-has led to some particular players on the field sending out daily notices seeking information, information which has been quite costly to the corporate sector to produce. That is why the Government did propose the mechanism of having the ASC to vet, basically as a safety valve matter. If one looks at the Government's proposal, it is a pretty broad one. The ASC would give permission but would deny permission in circumstances where a test of unreasonability would come into it. We see that sort of mechanism as providing us with a pressure valve to protect efficiency in the corporate sector from misuse and abuse of this access or this right to seek beneficial ownership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) for that answer. It does not fully satisfy me because I would have thought that the overwhelming majority of companies that do resort to section 261 action do so because they are genuinely concerned about the state of their register and what is taking place on it. Whilst I understand that there perhaps has been some overuse, as distinct from abuse, of the system, I would be interested to have some quantification of the degree to which that problem has arisen. I would also be interested to know why the process of charging a reasonable fee for the action to proceed would not be a suitable alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to know what delay will be involved in the tracing procedure through the Government's proposal having to work through the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). One of the essences of the rapidly moving situation in relation to changes in share ownership is that speed is quite essential. If there is going to be a delay, even a matter of 24 hours, in the sorts of situations that we can be contemplating it can be very significant. I would have thought that it was most unlikely that the Commission would be able, with a snap of the fingers, to give a yes or no as to the acceptability of the application. If it is going to be that brief, that raises a very significant question as to whether the monitoring role would serve any practically useful purpose at all. There are two or three things there that I think require clarification. I would welcome such clarification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, just briefly, in terms of quantification I think I should say to Senator Short that if information is available on that I will endeavour to provide it for him. I also ask him to take into account the actual details of the Government's proposal. It has been on the public record for 12 months now. During that time there has been only one representation that has queried it. Others have been totally in support. The proposal is not anything other than to prevent unreasonable requests. This is the debate with which honourable senators will be very familiar, Mr Chairman. It deals with the question of whether inquiries into unacceptable conduct should be conducted by the Panel as distinct and separate from the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). I understand the sequence of events in relation to this matter, according to the provisions of clause 733 of the Corporations Bill, is as follows:
Where it appears to the Commission that unacceptable circumstances have, or may have, occurred:
(a) in relation to an acquisition of shares in a company; or
(b) as a result of conduct engaged in by a person in relation to shares in, or the affairs of, a company;
the Commission may apply to the Corporations and Securities Panel for a declaration . . .
The Bill provided that the responsibility for making the declaration be passed to the Panel.

The recommendations of the Joint Select Committee, as I read them, were to the contrary; that the power should stay with the ASC in much the same way that currently power is exercised by the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). The next step in the sequence is that the Government wishes to maintain the position as set out in the Bill, in other words, that the responsibility be passed to the Panel. The Opposition, on the other hand, supports the position that was determined by the Joint Select Committee. In other words, we say that the ASC should have that responsibility. We principally adopt the arguments that were put in favour of this position by the Joint Select Committee. This whole sequence of amendments, therefore, is to adopt the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee of this Parliament.

The principal reason for the Committee reaching this conclusion, as I read it, was the experience of the NCSC. This is a power that the NCSC clearly regards as necessary in order for it to meet its responsibilities in a timely way. Certainly as far as that body-the principal policing body in corporate law in this country-is concerned, there was no justification to pass the responsibility to a separate and distinct panel. There are all sorts of arguments that one can develop about the nature of the Panel, and whether it is composed of those who are most suited to reach these determinations, but I do not think it is necessary for me to press those arguments. Rather, I simply rely upon past experience, which is that the system works well with the NCSC exercising the function and, therefore, the case has not been made out for a transfer of that responsibility to a separate and distinct panel. Therefore, I move these amendments to put into effect the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no disagreement in the Joint Select Committee's report on the Corporations Bill-apart from the general philosophical issues which were debated during the second reading stage, where there was obviously a division within the Committee-on the technical issues, which are the substance of the report, except with regard to one particular item, and that is the item we are discussing today. As a member of that Committee I signed a minority report, along with Senator Alston, Senator Cooney, Senator McMullan and Mr Kerr from the House of Representatives. Essentially, it reflects a divided view as to how best to have the organisations function.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's original Bill was based on the premise of the division of power between the Commission and the Panel. That, for most of our inquiries, seemed to be a reasonable premise. However, in the dying days of the Committee's inquiry a spirited intervention took place by the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) in defence of the position that he and the Commission had been arguing for some time-that they should be able to retain the power to make declarations of unacceptable conduct.

I had rehearsed those arguments myself for quite some time, and I must admit there is some substance to the propositions on both sides. That is why the Committee divided as it did-not along party lines, but on the basis of the evidence that was presented to us. In the final analysis my position-which is now, I am pleased to say, the position of my Party-on this particular item is that we stay with the minority report which I co-signed. The most compelling reason that I had for this is that I find that the structure proposed by the Government ought to be given a chance to work. I am attracted to the notion of some hiatus between the body which is doing the investigation and the body which makes those types of declarations.

We used the analogy, in the minority report, of a judge and jury. Of course, it is an analogy and it does not quite hold with regard to this matter. In any event, it gives the feeling of a distinct unease that many businesses have that the Commission should have all those powers.

My position was further strengthened by the acceptance by the Government of the notion of having a full time operator as President of the Panel. After all, one has to take very seriously any point concerning practical work put by the NCSC, since it is the only body which actually has any practical experience of the day to day operations of regulations in this country at that level. Taking its point seriously, I think it is met by the notion that the Chair will be available at all times so that there can be rapid intervention and movement along the lines that the Commission indicated was most desirable.

The last point I wish to make with regard to this is that I believe that the ability of the new Australian Securities Commission (ASC), which will take over the role of the NCSC, to make the public generally aware of its activities would be an excessively powerful weapon. I am not at all sure that many companies would relish the thought of being publicly hauled off to the ASC. Hence, I think that the NCSC somewhat understates the power that the new ASC will have of actually sending somebody to the Panel. In many ways that could very well look like the first step towards getting hung. Or, to use a court analogy, to be indicted on a charge of murder would be a pretty drastic first step to come from a magistrate's court. If that happens, one really feels that one is moving into much deeper water. The fact that the Commission is the body referring to the Panel will have a very powerful and salutary effect on business, so business, I am quite sure, will cooperate with the Commission.

We must bear in mind that the power to make unacceptable declarations has been used sparsely, but the fact that such declarations can be made has enabled the Commission to bring together many commercial settlements. That power to refer to the Panel will enable the Commission still to make those commercial settlements. In view of those matters, I believe that the Government's general structure should be given a chance to work and, therefore, I indicate that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments to restructure that organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that this will not inhibit the capacity to make commercial settlements?

—It will not. But, in saying all of that, I should not want to indicate that we do not believe either the advisory committee or the parliamentary committee should look very carefully in the next year or so-or when the Commission is up and running, after a couple of years of its operation-at how this has worked in practice. The only niggling concern at the back of my mind is that the NCSC's practical experience leans in the other direction and that it was upon the basis of that experience that the majority of the Committee finally made their decision. It worries me that we are running counter to that practical experience of the NCSC. Hence I believe it is important that both the advisory council and the parliamentary committee make sure that they look at this issue as a matter of priority and keep it under very close supervision. It may be one of the first items that have to come back on board for discussion. The fact that on this matter the Committee split along non-party lines also indicates that it is a matter upon which people, according to the weight of the evidence, can differ. For that reason also it is important that it be one of the major items kept under close supervision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Hill's amendment to the effect that the declaration of unacceptable conduct should be left with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) rather than vested in the Panel. I agree with many of Senator Macklin's comments. On this matter the Committee was divided 5-5-down the middle-along non-party lines. Members took different views according to the weight of the evidence available. I was one of the majority who supported the amendment that Senator Hill has moved on behalf of the Opposition. I did so partly for the reasons that Senator Macklin gave in expressing his view on some of the amendments. My judgment was very heavily influenced by the views of the people who have had the most direct involvement in this matter over the last few years-the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that was put to the Joint Select Committee was that the role of the ASC is going to be significantly lessened relative to the existing NCSC role, and that that weakening will have a quite detrimental effect on the ability of the Commission to conduct its investigatory and related activities. At this time, it is essential that we in this country do nothing to diminish investor confidence, but I believe that that is what will happen if the perceived role, as well as the actual role, of the major investigatory body-namely, the Australian Securities Commission-is weakened. That would be detrimental. Given the significance that the NCSC's staff and chairman attached to this matter, and given their view that there would really be a major weakening of its role as perceived by the business, financial and securities industry if the power to make the declaration of unacceptable conduct were removed from the Commission, I agreed with the NCSC position. That position, of course, is reflected in the amendments.

Arguments to the contrary have been put forward, and they are contained in the report of the Joint Select Committee. I should like to quote two of the relevant paragraphs of that report in order to get them on the record in Hansard because they are important in that they sum up the reason the Joint Select Committee and the Opposition have taken the view that they have taken. The paragraphs are 13.74 and 13.75, on page 163. I quote:

13.74 The thrust of the submissions made to the Committee by the NCSC, both in writing and in evidence, in relation to the ASCs powers when compared to the NCSC, was to the effect that the powers given to the ASC by the Bill were so limited when compared to the NCSC powers that they would seriously erode investor protection. In this regard the NCSC recommended to the Committee that it should consider extending the power to make a declaration under Clause 733 (of unacceptable conduct) to the ASC and remove it from the powers to be given to the Panel.

13.75 This is a view with which the Committee agrees. The provisions in the Corporations Bill are intended to allow the ASC powers of investigation of matters which arise in the course of takeover activities. The Committee observes that the principles of unacceptable conduct are the same as those in the present CASA legislation. The NCSC's argument that existing power of investigation and adjudication on declarations of unacceptable conduct amount to a more effective form of regulation of market conduct, by integration of litigation and investigation, has persuaded the Committee that the power to make a declaration should be vested in the ASC and not in the Panel. The Committee finds it desirable that the ASC not only have an investigatory role, but also the role of deciding what is unacceptable and that the Panel should have the role of reviewing the declaration and of deciding whether and what orders should be made.

That is a view to which I subscribe completely. It encapsulates very succinctly the arguments for the Opposition's amendment, and I commend the amendment to the chamber. If it is not passed, this matter, as Senator Macklin has said, should be reviewed at a early date. It should be monitored very carefully by the new parliamentary committee which hopefully will be established.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister sums up I wish briefly to respond to the comments made by Senator Short which I think accurately and correctly reflected the views of what has been called the majority of the Committee, although the Committee split evenly, five all, on this contentious matter. The report that has become known as the `majority report' is the one which was carried with the casting vote of the Chairman. I share the views expressed by Senator Macklin which I think cover most of the points which need to be raised on this matter and which motivated the five dissenting members of the Committee to their view.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we all understand the position of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) from the material that it put before us. It regards its capacity to make declarations of unacceptable conduct as a power which it has used very effectively in the regulation of market conduct. Therefore, it sees the loss of that power to make declarations as preventing the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) from operating in that area in which the NCSC has been so effective. Contrary to the other very useful advice which the NCSC gave to the Committee and to the Government, which is reflected in many of these amendments, I think that in this instance the NCSC has misunderstood some of the factors which will make effective the Government's proposal which is incorporated in the Bill and which will continue to operate if the amendments are rejected. As I recall it, the NCSC, in the course of its evidence to the Committee, made it clear that one of the powers that made its declarations such a powerful deterrent was that they would lead to a public exposition of the activities of the company in question.

The Government, in its response to the Committee's report-which I do not think was in any doubt-makes it explicit that the ASC will have the power to publicise the terms of a reference of unacceptable conduct to the Panel. I think this will prove to be a very powerful deterrent. Time will tell. I will not take up the time of the Committee by reiterating the comments made by Senator Macklin and Senator Short about the need for a continuing review. But I am very confident that that publicity power will be very effective. It is inconceivable that any company would be uninfluenced by the prospect of being referred, by the ASC, to the Panel on the grounds of an allegation of unacceptable conduct. Such diminution of power as there might be, which I would regard as probably minor, would not overcome the fundamental objection of giving the same body the right to be the prosecutor and the jury when other equally effective and convenient alternative mechanisms were available.

There seems to be a bit of confusion concerning commercial settlements. Neither in theory nor in practice do I see any way in which this provision will inhibit the capacity or effectiveness of the ASC in pursuing commercial settlements-in having the leverage to persuade people to enter a commercial settlement-any more than those provisions which currently prevail in the NCSC. I believe that the dissenting report of the five members of the Select Committee with respect to declarations of unacceptable conduct is the appropriate position. I support the Government's judgment to accept that position and I welcome its decision. Accordingly, I oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan is right. The Government is not convinced that the ASC should have the power to make declarations of unacceptable acquisitions or conduct. Basically, we believe that it is important to separate the investigation and adjudication functions. I think that separation is far more important than having, within the ASC, the weapon of declaratory power. We recognise-and this point has been made by the NCSC and others to the Joint Select Committee (JSC) on Corporations Legislation-that, in these circumstances, timing is extremely important. We believe that allowing the ASC to go public with its applications to the Panel would be tantamount to the ASC announcing that it would be investigating, seeking a declaration, or embarking upon a process which would lead to a declaration. The effect would be the same. The ASC would be able to publish-the NCSC has suggested that it would want to make public-its intention to embark on investigations in this area. We think that its capacity to go public, in addition to the fact that it will make an application, is a very useful mechanism to ensure that the question of timing is accommodated. Accordingly, with that very important requirement that we wish to separate adjudication from investigation, we do not support the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: In discussing those amendments, I should say that there are a couple of curious incidental by-products. Under current legislation I notice that the time period during which a declaration may be made is 90 days. The Opposition's amendments extend that to 180 days but, in doing so, they do not take into account the mechanism proposed by the JSC which is embodied in the current legislation-that is, that the time period be 60 days, but with the Panel having a further 30 days to make its decision. The other part of the JSC mechanism-which is also not embodied in the Opposition's amendments-is a provision for an extension of time. Under our provisions, pursuant to clause 737 of the legislation, the time can be extended either by the Panel or by the Panel after a request from a particular court. The other curious thing in the Opposition's amendments is that even though this function has been deleted from the Panel, the amendments do not do away with the Panel altogether. So we could well finish up with a full time chairman of a panel which has no functions to perform.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the Corporations Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 533, after clause 736, insert the following new clause in Part 6.9:
Commission may publish report about application to Panel or Court
``736a. (1) This section applies where the Commission:

(a) applies under subsection 733 (1) for a declaration under subsection 733 (3) in relation to an acquisition of shares in a company or conduct engaged in relation to shares in, or the affairs of, a company;
(b) applies for an order to be made under subsection 734 (2) in reliance on such a declaration; or
(c) applies for an order to be made under section 736 for the purpose of securing compliance with an order made under subsection 734 (2) in reliance on such a declaration.
``(2) The Commission may publish in any way it considers appropriate a report, statement or notice, whether or not in writing, that:
(a) states that the application has been made;
(b) names the company; and
(c) if the Commission considers that the report, statement or notice should name any other person to whom:
(i) if paragraph (1) (a) applies-the declaration, if made, would relate; or
(ii) if paragraph (1) (b) or (c) applies-an order applied for would, if made, be directed;
names that other person.
``(3) Nothing in this section limits by implication a function or power of the Commission, the Panel or any other person or body.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This might be an opportune time for me to explain why we will not press our amendment No. 7. That amendment deals with matters arising out of recommendation No. 31 in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. Pursuant to that recommendation, our proposed amendment was to include a provision that, where the National Companies and Securities Commission (NSCS) does not make a declaration under subsection 3-I should say that we referred to the Commission because we were optimistically expecting a substantive amendment to be passed and the Commission would be making these decisions rather than the Panel-it may arrange a commercial settlement and, where it makes a commercial settlement, it may cause the terms of that commercial settlement to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. As I have said, that picks up recommendation 31 of the series of recommendations of the Joint Select Committee which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee recommends that the ASC have the ability to publish any declarations of unacceptable conduct and referrals to the Corporations and Securities Panel.
That recommendation should be read in conjunction with the previous recommendation, which deals with commercial settlements and which reads as follows:

The committee recommends that the Government review the terms of the legislation to ensure that the Bill provides the ASC with the power to effect commercial settlements in matters involving unacceptable conduct proceedings.

We have decided not to press our amendment. On reflection, we feel that the matter requires further and more detailed consideration. Mr Chairman, you will be aware that, under the existing legislation, the whole area of commercial settlements under the operation of the NCSC is one of the most vexed areas of practice of that body. It is an area which I have had cause to criticise on other occasions in this place because commercial settlements often effected in private have not given those who follow the law information about whether breaches have occurred and, therefore, have failed to provide desirable precedents for the efficient functioning of the law in this area.

It has been a process which, in many ways, has aroused suspicion and concern and has been criticised on the basis that the NCSC has had a responsibility to investigate matters and determine whether there has been a breach of the law and to act accordingly. On a commercial settlement being reached we, the public, are simply unaware of the basis upon which that settlement was reached.

The NCSC has argued before Senate committees and in the Estimates that there is little alternative, because of the budgetary restraints under which it has had to operate under this Government. Also, there has been little alternative because of the volume of work that it has had to process under pressure where commercial matters have had to be resolved in the shortest possible time. I guess that, more positively, it is argued that the option of a commercial settlement can, in some circumstances, effect the best resolution of a problem in ways that allow the corporations concerned to get on with their business; in other words, a settlement of the problem has been reached that has commercial reality and may be, in all the circumstances, the best resolution to a problem.

The Opposition acknowledges that these arguments exist. We think that the whole area requires further consideration. We note that the terms of the Bill are similar to those in the existing legislation in that the receipts for commercial settlements are not spelt out. I think that Senator Macklin is correct and that there is still plenty of scope under this legislation to effect commercial settlements, but nothing sets out in what circumstances that can be achieved and the basis or information upon which the new panel can, in this instance, make such a decision. Furthermore, as the Committee has set out, there is nothing therefore that requires that either the basis of the commercial settlement or the commercial settlement itself be publicised.

In all the circumstances, bearing in mind the importance of this area, its complexity and the precedents, which some of us have considered to be unsatisfactory and for which others have argued positively in the past, we believe that this is an appropriate question to be referred to the new parliamentary committee which will oversee this legislation. It seems to us that that would be a more appropriate way to move in all the circumstances.

Therefore, I say that, on reflection, we have decided not to press the matters at this time. That is not because we do not think that they incorporate an important issue that requires resolution but, rather, because we think that a more detailed consideration by a parliamentary committee of the whole of the issues that surround commercial settlement should be undertaken and that the new parliamentary committee, which we are setting up today through this legislation, is the most appropriate vehicle to give consideration to such matters. On that basis I indicate that I will not be moving our amendment No. 7 and we do not oppose the Government's amendment in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to respond briefly, but first I digress and take this opportunity to congratulate Rosemary Follett on becoming Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory. That happened in the last few minutes. We on this side of politics are happy about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the corporate legislation, having listened to Senator Hill and Senator Macklin, the Government is of the view that the question of commercial settlements is one that can benefit from greater and further consideration. We will possibly look at either the parliamentary committee or the advisory committee considering the whole question of commercial settlement.

We recognise that, within the current law, and the proposed law that is before us at the moment, commercial settlements can in fact be entered into. We also recognise that the parliamentary committee recommended further consideration in this area. I am pleased that Senator Hill will not be pursuing his amendment. We are concerned that, if the concept of commercial settlements was embodied in legislation, we would be the first country in the Western commercial world that would be doing so formally. We also recognise that even though it may seem to be an attractive proposal it may have implications in terms of further investigation of matters that may have in fact been `settled'. Such considerations need to be further considered together with the question of publication and accountability through publication of whatever arrangement has in fact been reached. Those issues can be positively looked at in terms of their further consideration by either the parliamentary committee or the advisory committee.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I should like to take a few moments at this stage to place on record a couple of factors from the Government side. We have just finished a very important stage of this legislation and I think I should place on record the amount of work, effort and foresight put into this proposal by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the stubborn persistence with which he has pursued and is pursuing this issue. As well as the Attorney-General, a whole host of people put in a great deal of work in order to see that the legislation was prepared and progressed to this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially I should place on the record the Government's appreciation of the work done by the people in the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel. In the case of the former, the ranks of the particular division of the Department that was handling the legislation diminished from time to time. Despite that, the quality of the advice and information coming to the Government did not change at all. The Government appreciates the resources that have been put in by that division of the Attorney-General's Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-May I endorse what the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has said. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to associate myself with the remarks of Senator Hill, particularly the last one. It is my belief that, if this chamber ever manages to get back to the report which is before it with regard to procedures and committees to look at complex legislation, and if the more wayward members of the Senate permit an adequate and reasonable discussion of that particular report, we could implement it. Such procedures would facilitate enormously the consideration of complex Bills such as these.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill has pointed out, the thought of actually going into the committee stage of this legislation without having had a committee inquiry would have been so horrific that the Government would have kept putting the debate off. But for that inquiry it would have been virtually impossible for this chamber to manage the complexity of the issues, the differences of principle and the necessary emphasis. The fact that we were able to work matters out in an amicable way in the committee stage and that the Government was very positive in its response to the unanimous recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Corporations Legislation has enabled the passage of this legislation in a much more reasonable time frame than could ever have been imagined, if at all, with consideration simply by the Committee of the Whole.

I personally would like to thank the members of the Joint Committee for the enormous work they put in and the learning experience that I was able to have. I also thank the staff of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and the staff of the Attorney-General's Department, who were always very helpful through the stages that have taken something like a year in providing briefing notes, position papers and other materials as requested. It demonstrates that a constructive approach to legislation can be undertaken. This was a very good example of the way in which, hopefully, other legislation can be handled if we manage to get acceptance of the Procedures Committee report.
