SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the matter of an inequity arising from unintended consequences of the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangements) Act of 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory self-government legislation package which transferred staff of the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) to the ACT Administration and the National Capital Planning Authority. The problem is that the transfer of the NCDC staff to those bodies involved the transfer of staff employed under the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957 to employment under the Public Service Act 1922. This transfer did not involve any break in continuity, loss of accrued leave or other benefits consistent with the general understandings and the provisions of section 81 of the Public Service Act under which the transfer was effected.

SPEECH.PARA: However, because of the peculiarities of the terms of the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangements) Act, in which such arrangements as this were not envisaged, these ex-NCDC staff are regarded as having changed employers. Accordingly, in regard to the 3 per cent superannuation scheme, which is covered by the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangements) Act, that is, the extra government 3 per cent superannuation contribution, employees whose accrued 3 per cent fund is $500 or less, can get access to the money or roll it over in a preservation fund. Although I do not think that is an appropriate arrangement, there is no disadvantage to the individuals because they can get access to the money. It is not what the 3 per cent was intended for, but as it is such a small amount it is probably not a problem.

However, those people-I understand that up to 70 per cent of the staff could be involved-whose accrued 3 per cent fund is more than $500 must roll the money over in a preservation fund until retirement age, which is the standard requirement in circumstances of a change of employer. In this situation the proposal is totally unsatisfactory, because the change in employer in this case is really only a deemed change. It was entirely due to the employer, in this case the Government, restructuring its operations, not to any voluntary action by the employees, or to any decision of theirs even to change desks. They did not apply for new positions. They have been affected by a proper and appropriate restructuring by the Government, which possibly had adverse consequences for their superannuation entitlements and the way in which they will be treated.

All concerned seem to agree that this is unfair and anomalous, but it is generally accepted that it is too late to correct the matter because, I gather, the 90-day roll over time which is available to staff has expired. The NCDC Act was repealed on 31 January. Accordingly, it is too late to do anything at this stage. My understanding from discussion with departmental officers is that, as is publicly known, there is a review of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. They do not want to make piecemeal changes. They would rather deal with any anomalies in that way. It is possible, and I hope probable, that the 3 per cent fund will be incorporated with the existing Commonwealth superannuation scheme as part of the review. Given that this anomaly and potential unfairness has arisen, which is quite contrary to the intentions of the 3 per cent superannuation arrangements, I want to raise the possibility, and seek consideration by the Minister, of allowing the staff so affected to reincorporate their benefit into the main Commonwealth superannuation fund when the review is complete, on the assumption that that review leads to an amalgamation of the funds, which it should do and which I think is entirely appropriate.

This will not remove the anomaly that has already occurred but it will go some way to rectifying the problem caused by the anomaly and it will indicate to these employees that their reasonable expectations when the 3 per cent was granted have reasonable prospects of being fulfilled. I would like to put on the record that, while supporting the intentions and the implementation in the broad measure of the 3 per cent superannuation increment-it is a very important improvement in employees' conditions throughout Australia-the manner of the implementation of the superannuation scheme and the self-government proposals with regard to planning in the ACT has potentially disadvantaged these people. We cannot retrospectively correct that problem, and it seems inappropriate to do so, but I hope that the Minister will consider giving a commitment to these employees that they will be allowed to so reincorporate so that the anomaly might be rectified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the matter of allegations of corrupt practices in banking. Honourable senators are aware that over a period of some months now I have taken advantage of this Thursday lunchtime matters of public of interest segment to explore, probe, and table materials for the information of honourable senators in relation to a range of very serious allegations in the community concerning corrupt banking practices. On 5 April the Senate debated the proposition that this whole question be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That proposition was defeated by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition. Last week I returned to some aspects of that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate on 5 April Senator Stone tabled and had incorporated in Hansard four letters that the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Sanders, had sent to me personally. I had not previously tabled those letters because I was still researching their implications. As I said, Senator Stone tabled them. As a result of their incorporation in Hansard and their availability to others, I have now received a number of responses which argue that Mr Sanders had misrepresented certain circumstances to me in those letters. Inadvertently Senator Stone, therefore, had been a party to Mr Sanders actually misrepresenting those circumstances to the Senate.

It is not for me to make judgments about whether a misrepresentation occurred but to simply draw the Senate's attention to the fact that those allegations of misrepresentation have been brought to my attention. I will shortly seek leave to table the letters of response which draw the Senate's attention to those serious allegations. Each Thursday I have been seeking leave of the Senate to place before honourable senators a series of affidavits which build up the picture of alleged corruption. I seek leave of the Senate today to table two further affidavits, one in relation to the dispute between Mr John Kay and the Australian Guarantee Corporation Ltd, AGC, and an affidavit by Sharon Margaret Shannon who is in dispute with Westpac. Neither dispute is before the courts. I seek leave of the Senate to table those documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, leave is not granted on the basis that I have not been able to see the documents nor, I gather, has the Opposition. So we do not know what we are agreeing to table. This is about the fourth time that this has happened. It might smooth our procedures if, before Senator McLean comes in here to table documents, he checks them out with the duty Minister and the duty shadow Minister.

—Yes. Certainly I will do that in future. I turn now to a solicitor's letter addressed to me from the solicitors of Mr and Mrs Tony Rigg, who are in dispute with the Commonwealth Bank. Mr Don Sanders had written to me in relation to the Rigg question. That letter was tabled, as I said, by Senator Stone. The Riggs argue that the explanation which is offered to me in the letter from Mr Sanders-and which therefore is before the Senate, having been tabled by Senator Stone-incorporates a number of falsehoods. In the solicitor's letter on behalf of Mr and Mrs Rigg it is argued that the Sanders letter contains errors of fact and at least four falsehoods and is misleading.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I am not really in a position to make a judgment as to whether Mr Sanders has stated falsehoods to me, for the simple reason that I have the classic situation of two opinions before me. Indeed, that is the nature of these disputes on every occasion-some of which have been taken to the courts and judgments made upon them. Under the circumstances, since the previous letters of Mr Sanders are now a part of Hansard, I feel obliged to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that their content is disputed by those who claim to know the realities, that there are serious allegations of lying, and threats to life and limb in the case of Mr Gilliland, which I cited last Thursday, and that there are serious allegations of misleading statements and palpable falsehoods contained in the solicitor's letter on behalf of Mr and Mrs Tony Rigg. I seek leave to table these documents so that the counter statements, or counter case, is before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No. I will have to look at it first.
—Leave is not granted at this stage. Again a request has been made for the documents to be seen.
—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—The Government has no objection to the first two documents being tabled.
—Leave is now granted for all the documents to be tabled.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
(1) That discussion of matters of public interest be not further proceeded with this day;

(2) That intervening Government Business be postponed until after consideration of Government Business, orders of the day No. 23, Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill 1989; No. 11, Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Amendment Bill 1989; and No. 16, Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1989;
(3) That this order have effect until 2 p.m. this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES (INTERNATIONAL LINER CARGO SHIPPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purposes of this Bill are proper-to reform the outdated legislative framework under which our international liner trade is carried on and to repeal and replace part X of the Trade Practices Act. The Opposition has no objection to those purposes but it is worth being quite clear as to what we are talking about, what liner shipping is. It is mainly containerised cargoes on defined trade routes. The value of this trade is substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986-87, liner exports were 8 million tonnes, worth $13 billion, and imports were 6 million tonnes, worth $21 billion. It is worth noting that the value per tonne of our imports is much higher than our exports, because our exports are mainly wheat and wool and our imports are mainly high value, manufactured items, such as industrial machinery and equipment. Of that cargo, we carried in Australian flag ships seven per cent of exports and nine per cent of imports. It is worth noting why the figure is so high. Our shipping is generally very uncompetitive for reasons I will come to in a moment. The reason Australian ships are in these cartels, these conferences, is that they are very welcome there. The high costs of Australian ships put up freight charges for everyone and make the profits of the efficient operators much higher than they otherwise would be. Australian ships are very welcome in conferences, but not for good economic reasons as far as Australia's economic well-being is concerned.

As I said, the Opposition does not oppose this Bill but we do note that it has been very slow coming into being. It has been in the process of being drafted since 1984-five years ago. It is typical of the Government's approach to micro-economic and structural reform. The Bill, as presented to the Parliament, was very badly drafted. It had a number of serious problems which have been fixed up in the Parliament. But for a Bill which has been drafted for five years it is extraordinary that it should have come into the Parliament with so many errors. For instance, it did not contain a precise definition of what a conference is, the thing we are talking about in this Bill. It has been rectified by way of amendment but it was very sloppy drafting that allowed for a conference agreement to be described as an agreement between conference members without ever defining what a conference was. The definition of market power was not clear as originally drafted. That, too, has been fixed up. Under Designated Shipper Bodies, the Bill gives official negotiating recognition to designated peak shipper bodies and designated secondary shipper bodies but this is very far from a proper, market-based approach which would be ideal.

Another objection to the way the Bill handles things is that there are no incentives in the Bill to move away from the cartel-like structures in the liner shipping industry. I have given an example of the way this type of cartel can operate to the economic detriment of the country by the welcome it gives to high cost Australian shipping because it pushes up freight rates and pushes up the profits of the efficient shipping operators still further. We want to achieve a system where our trade moves at the lowest possible cost.

Another difficulty with the Bill is that it may increase costs. Members of the Trade Practices Commission have claimed that the mediation and monitoring function required of the Commission would involve substantial additional expenses for the Commonwealth. Finally, on the points of difficulty-a minor point, perhaps-the Australian Shippers Council in the past has received a small grant from the Commonwealth. I ask the Minister whether there will be similar grants to the designated shipper bodies.

The main difficulty with this Bill-though I repeat that the Opposition is not opposed to it; it is better than nothing-is that it does not really do anything significant to tackle the entrenched and damaging inefficiencies on the waterfront and in coastal shipping. These are very serious difficulties in a time when we have a balance of payments deficit of $15,000m a year, despite the fact that the value of our exports, and our terms of trade, improved significantly-by about 15 per cent-in the last year. Our balance of payments deficit is 35 per cent higher than for the same period last year. This is despite an improvement in our terms of trade of 15 per cent.

The world does not owe us a living. We must tackle inefficiencies on our waterfront and in our shipping. Our overseas shipping, our liner shipping, which we are dealing with here, is damaged because our highly protected, union and monopoly ruled coastal shipping conditions-the accommodation conditions, the pay conditions, the manning conditions-also flow over into international shipping. This is a great cost to the Australian community. The cost runs into billions of dollars a year. This Government is not tackling these matters.

The Government can be very free-I must say that I agree with it-in deregulating and freeing up the wheat market because none of the Government's interested parties are affected. But it is very reluctant when it comes to far more important reforms on the waterfront and in shipping, because its party members are involved. We do not have time on our side. I repeat: We are living $15,000m a year beyond our means. The world does not owe us a living. We must tackle these problems of shipping and the waterfront if we wish to improve our standard of living and keep up with the rest of the world. These are matters this Government will not touch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I answer the question that I think Senator Hamer has asked me I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to this Bill. The Trade Practices (International Liner Cargo Shipping) Amendment Bill 1989, I am informed, modifies or removes part X of the Trade Practices Act, that part which exempts liner shipping from the Trade Practices Act, and thus has the effect of exposing the conference lines to greater competition in shipping.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that Senator Hamer asked me was in relation to the funding of designated shipper bodies. No Commonwealth funding will be provided for the establishment or operation of designated shipping bodies. Such bodies are commercial organisations set up in the interests of their members. It is therefore appropriate that their membership fund them. An objective of the Bill is to place greater reliance on commercial structures. So the answer is no. The Government acknowledges that the Opposition supports this legislation. I take on board the other remarks made by Senator Hamer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Amendment Bill lifts the legislative maximum amount for export inspection of grain and dairy products and removes other items which are now charged on a fee for service basis rather than on quantity. The actual operating levels are not included in the Bill. They are to be set up by regulation. The Bill extends the Government push towards a fee for service. The intention to raise fees was made in the May economic statement. Of the 174 items inspected for export, only some dairy products and grain remain on a quantity basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition supports the general thrust of the legislation and changes to export inspection policy, which policy was commenced under the Fraser Government. The coalition accepts the need for increased charges where, for example, the Department was losing money on bagged and container inspection because the current maximum in the Bill does not allow it to recover costs. The Department states that residue testing of grain has resulted in a 31 per cent increase in costs and that is the major reason for the large lift in the maximum grain fees for bagged grain from 33c per tonne to $1 and for containerised grain from $1.46 per tonne to $5.

There are, however, problems for the exporters of horticulture and floriculture products. These are the problems that I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate. There is a $47 minimum fee for the inspection of horticultural products. I put it to the Senate and to the Government that that is a real disincentive to those who may choose merely to send a sample of their product overseas in order to open up some new market. This minimum charge has caused many nurseries to abandon the export market or attempts to enter the export market.

Mr Barry Waldeck, one of Western Australia's leading nurserymen, addressing the recent national Agricultural Outlook Conference on the future of floriculture told delegates that Australia presently holds only 0.06 per cent of the world flower trade and that a 2.5 per cent share of that market would be worth $100m a year. At the same time he said that it should be taken into account that the floriculture market is increasing at the rate of $400m a year. To provide some encouragement Holland, which commands 63 per cent of the world flower market, described Australia as `an untapped gold mine of unique flower species'. I cite this example to demonstrate the need for flexibility and the need to ensure that inspection charges are not at levels which discourage growth of new exports.

Australia simply cannot afford disincentives for new exporters. This country is on the edge of an economic abyss as to the value of its dollar. There is a desperate need to encourage exporters in all fields and this is a marvellous opportunity for Australia to enter into this field of export.

The coalition parties believe that the people of Australia, as well as the exporters, have an investment in exports from this country because exports are essential to the maintenance of our living standards and reduce the terrible overseas debt burden we are now suffering at the hands of the Hawke Government. We believe that all Australians should share in the cost of these export inspection costs and we will, in government, reduce cost recovery to a maximum of 50 per cent instead of the 60 to 100 per cent under this Hawke Government. We will encourage exports by solving the problems of the small and new exporters. In government, the coalition parties will encourage export industries to increasingly self-manage, self-assure and back the brand images of their products. Export inspection arrangements should be limited to what is required by international agreements or by importing countries. Outside that requirement it should be left to the exporters to maintain their own quality standards.

The Opposition does not oppose this Bill but condemns the Government for breaking its commitment to recover not more than 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities. The actions of the Hawke Government demonstrate its lack of sympathy for the problems of rural producers. It is repeatedly demonstrating a lack of sympathy for and understanding of the rural producers of this nation. Obviously it has a hidden agenda of moving towards a 100 per cent recovery cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities, as is demonstrated by the dramatic increase in the maximum permissible levels under this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Lewis has said, the Opposition supports this Bill. Therefore, unlike the wheat Bills which will come before the Senate today, and on which there is heated disagreement between some elements of the Opposition and the Government, on this Bill one can fairly say that there is heated agreement. That makes a nice change for this chamber. The second reading debate on this Bill has afforded Senator Lewis an opportunity to make a political speech about cost recovery of inspection charges. I acknowledge that it was a political speech. I do not propose to reply to it other than to make this observation: Last week a national employers body-it may have been the Confederation of Australian Industry; I am not sure-advocated to this Government that cost recovery on inspections should be 100 per cent. We have cost recovery at 60 per cent. That was lambasted by Senator Lewis in his remarks. He promised that the Opposition will reduce it to 50 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the general Australian taxpayer to consider why the Opposition imagines that the taxpayers' purse should be plundered, and that the taxpayer should shoulder a greater share of inspection charges for normal trading arrangements. The inspections that are undertaken are necessary to assure the quality and brand-type of Australian produce overseas and to allow that produce past international barriers that have quarantine or other restrictions on them. If our products have been inspected by our service in Australia, we can be assured that they will have entry into other markets as quality products. That service goes with the trading process. It seems to me that it ought to be paid for by those who use it.

However, we have pegged our fees at 60 per cent cost recovery. I do not think there is a case that the Australian taxpayer should subsidise the inspection service by more than 40 per cent. The Opposition seems to think that it should. On the other hand, I take note of Senator Lewis's remarks about the flower industry. The flower industry has a vibrant lobby that makes its case clear to the Government, but I do not believe the $47 inspection charge is a major inhibition. I commend the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 April, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill 1989. I am somewhat disappointed that there are not more speakers on the list, Madam Acting Deputy President, to debate the serious issue of the progress of the Government's affirmative action regime. Nevertheless, I am pleased that you are in the chair. You will have no choice but to listen to the views of the Opposition in this regard. The amendments proposed in this Bill will result in some minor administrative adjustments being made to the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 which established the Affirmative Action Agency and which requires employers to promote equal opportunity for women in employment. This Bill seeks to amend those portions of the principal Act that require employers to report annually to the Director of Affirmative Action on their individual programs and to ensure that tertiary institutions that amalgamate are not regarded as `new employers' for the purpose of establishing affirmative action programs. The Government is also seeking to have higher education institutions report on their affirmative action programs by a uniform date each year and to cover the same period in their reporting.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the amendments. They seem to us to be sensible. We hope that they streamline reporting requirements and ensure continuity in the affirmative action programs in amalgamating tertiary institutions, notwithstanding whatever reservations we might have about that amalgamation process.

As one of those who supported the original legislation in its passage through the Parliament, not surprisingly I follow the progress of the Affirmative Action Agency with interest. I commend the work of those who work within the Agency. It is obvious from our dealings with them in Estimates committee hearings that they are dedicated and are clearly seeking to achieve the legislation's objectives.

Much of the work the Agency does also deserves to be supported: encouraging compliance with the provisions of the Act, advising employers in the development and implementation of their affirmation action plans and monitoring progress of tertiary institutions, companies with over 1,000 employees, companies with between 500 and 999 employees, and now the last phase, involving companies with between 100 and 499 employees.

Those who follow the Estimates committee hearings on this matter will be well aware that our concern relates to the qualitative assessments of the work that is being done by the Agency, or rather, to this stage, the lack of qualitative assessment. The question that we on this side of the chamber wish to ask is: How is the Agency assisting in improving the employment status of women which, of course, is the principal objective of the Act? We have been concerned that on the evidence before us the emphasis of the Agency-and therefore, no doubt, the direction of the Minister and the Government-has been to look at whether those obliged to comply with the Act are meeting the technical requirements of the Act rather than determining whether they are meeting the spirit of the legislation and whether the Act is being useful in improving the employment status of women. In other words, what is being done to date is a quantitative assessment of compliance with the Act in its various forms rather than a qualitative assessment.

We put to the Government that no great effort is needed to get companies and higher education institutions to comply with the strict provisions of the Act. On the basis of the last report, the fact that only three companies did not meet the technical requirements of the Act shows that a very high level of compliance can be readily achieved.

The real question to be asked when one looks at the report is: What does it tell us about how much the legislative structure, and those who are working within it, are achieving in regard to improving the status of women in employment? As I indicated one finds very little information in the report to guide us in that direction. One would have thought, I respectfully submit, that one would be able to find it because that is the ultimate objective of the legislation and of those who work in the Agency.

In the Estimates committee hearings, we pressed the point. We asked how the Agency was assessing the effectiveness of its projects, of the legislation. As a result of that process of seeking information we found that the Agency uses a number of different mechanisms to produce the outcomes for which the Agency has been established. The first of the methods it uses is self-evaluation. As I recall it, that obligation is set out in the legislation.

Information which is obtained from companies is collated and published in the Agency's annual report. Under the legislation companies are obliged to assess themselves against the eight steps they are required to take. But nothing gives us any indication as to whether they are self-assessing; whether they are undertaking a process of self-evaluation. So we have to say that whilst it might, on the face of it, be useful to invite companies to undertake self-evaluation, it gives us no help at all in determining whether or not they are seriously addressing the issues that underlie the legislation. So we do not find much help in the first of the steps that are used by the Agency, it tells us, to assess its success or otherwise.

The second process was put to us as being the audit process. The Agency, we were informed, picks out those companies which have not met minimum standards of compliance and-I quote from the transcript of the Estimates hearing-`looks at their programs intensively and `audits' a 2 per cent sample of other returns. So it audits a 2 per cent sample. So we asked what was involved in this audit process. We found out that it is merely a desk-based audit. In other words, it involves nothing more than reading the reports carefully. We suggest that that is not the type of audit which will in any way inform us as to whether there has been improvement. All it does-it is only a random 2 per cent sample-is to test whether companies are meeting the strict reporting requirements of the Act. We on this side of the chamber would prefer to see a much greater sample taken than 2 per cent. Furthermore, if one is to enter into an audit procedure one enters into a proper audit procedure, which means that one checks. One does not simply read the report, reports which are so easily prepared in terms that comply with the minimum requirements of the legislation.

I reread the Estimates transcript and what was even more astonishing is that this process of desk audit has not yet started. If we were misreading the Estimates transcript or if there was some confusion in the evidence that was given by the officers, I hope that will be clarified by the Minister in this debate. The Agency has now been in operation for some years. We see no reason why the audit process should not be in place, not just spoken about.

The third of the tests of meeting the requirements of legislation is referred to by the Director as `evaluation'. We said, `What does that mean?'. The answer was, `Looking in detail at programs in a qualitative sense'. That is what we were looking for all along but, when we searched further and pressed the officers, we found that that evaluation process has not yet commenced. We were told that the reports of some 20 large companies are being looked at in greater detail, but doing an evaluation in a qualitative sense to see whether there is an actual improvement in the status of employment of women within these corporations has not yet commenced.

When we pressed even further as to what the nature of this qualitative assessment will be-this method of evaluation-again, I regret to say, there were no satisfactory answers. It does surprise us, I say with some disappointment, that these matters have not been addressed. I would have thought that they were the starting point of the Agency's work and the starting point of the Government's resolve in bringing down the legislation. The Government's emphasis seems to have been to get companies simply to meet a reporting function-a basis, almost mechanical, reporting function, thus being able to say in an annual report that the corporate world is meeting its requirements under the Act. That, I regret to say, tells us very little.

When one considers what is meant by `meeting minimum standards', it seems that it does not mean complying with the eight steps that are set out in the Act. The minimum compliance, we understand from the Agency, in year one of reporting is simply that the company gives some statistics plus compliance with one other step. If that is wrong, we would like to hear from the Government in this debate. It seems to us to be disappointing. In the second year, we are told that companies have to give a statistical profile plus four steps. Why in the second year can they not be required to meet the eight requirements that are set out in the legislation? Why is it necessary to adopt this step by step approach, particularly when, in our view, the meeting of those eight steps in itself does not really mean that the company is complying with the spirit of the legislation? We are aware that the Agency recently has put down an evaluation strategic plan. I think it was prepared from outside the Agency. I do not quite see why that was necessary, given the senior and experienced officers within the Agency, and particularly if companies are mainly going to be meeting a clerical requirement in the first few years of operation of the Act. Even when we look at the evaluation strategic plan, which sets out three levels of effectiveness, we find that all the Agency is looking at now, and seeking companies to comply with, is level one. Level one effectiveness is that the Agency assists employers with reporting obligations and monitors compliance with the legislation and the quality of the programs. Level two effectiveness is that the programs lead to improvements in the equal opportunity performance of the organisations, after which the Agency will provide a broader education and communication service to raise awareness of equal employment opportunity issues in the general community. Level three effectiveness is that the position of Australian women in the work force is improved. We do not understand, and perhaps the Minister might explain, why it is necessary, three years into the legislation, to be looking only for level one effectiveness, which seems to be to comply with the reporting requirements of the legislation rather than to impress upon companies and institutions that are covered by the legislation the need to meet the spirit of the legislation and actually achieve what lies behind it. We bring to the Government's attention in this debate our concern at what seems from the evidence put before us in the Estimates committee hearings to be a lack of effective evaluation proceedings that look to qualitative improvement in this area. I reiterate that qualitative improvement should be what the whole process is really about.

If we are left at a loss as to the progress of the status of women in employment from the work of the Agency to date and from its annual reports, I guess that the best direction for us to look is to areas of the work force that are directly within the control of the Government and upon which the Government has a much greater power to influence change in accordance with the direction it says it advocates. We therefore look, firstly, towards the Australian Public Service. Again we find a disappointing picture. The Public Service is covered not by this legislation but by a separate equal opportunity regime. When we consider how successful that has been in improving the status of women within the Public Service, as I indicated, the results are disappointing. We see that in the last year the increase in the number of women in the Senior Executive Service was 0.1 per cent. In other words, it was negligible-almost nil. The Government should hang its head in shame. We would have thought that by now we would have seen some female department heads. This Government has been in office for six years. Perhaps the Minister might confirm that there are still no female heads of departments in the Australian Public Service. We do not think that is a credit to the Government. It ought to do something about it.

The vast majority of women in the Public Service are still in the lowest categories of employment. On the figures I have, women still make up 68.3 per cent of clerical assistants in the Public Service. That percentage has actually increased. So although more women have come into the Public Service, more of them are coming in and being lodged at the lower levels. Evidence of vertical improvement of employment within the Public Service by women has been disappointing. Women are still progressing within the Public Service more slowly than comparable men. The Public Service Board said in its equal employment opportunity annual report 1986-87:

The low representation of women at senior levels is not fully explained by differences in length of service; nor by differences in qualifications; nor by concentration of women in States with slower promotion rates; nor by concentration of women in departments with slower promotion rates, nor by a combination of these factors taken together. Women have progressed more slowly than comparable men.

Perhaps the Minister will be prepared to explain why. Whilst the Government insists on the corporate sector meeting its reporting requirements under its legislation we find the disappointing picture that not all government agencies directly under the control, or certainly within the control, of the Government meeting theirs, which we suggest sends at least a confused signal to the private sector in this regard.

I understand that eight government agencies, at least one of which failed to report in 1986-87, failed to report in 1987-88. Perhaps we can have an explanation from the Minister as to why government sector reporting requirements are failing to be met. Four Cabinet level ministries, I am advised, were in default regarding their equal opportunity programs. Amongst the departments which have failed to report progress was the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet which has within it the office of the Status of Women. None of these departments were listed in the Public Service Commission's annual report which we would have at least expected the Public Service Commissioner to have done.

The Minister was pretty quick to jump on the only three companies in the corporate sector that failed to meet the reporting requirements. We have a classic case of double standards. The explanation given in the Public Service Commission's annual report was that there had been major changes and uncertainties due to the Public Service's reorganisation. That is not an excuse for those in the private sector. One should apply the same principles to both the public and private sectors.

Senior Government Ministers would not comment when asked about the failure of the government agencies to report. As I said, perhaps this Minister might. Neither the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) nor the Minister responsible for the status of women was prepared to comment. Even the Australian Council of Trade Unions told the Government in a recent report, which was reported in the Canberra Times on 22 March 1989, that the Government's equal employment opportunity strategy had failed. It said:
Probably the most disturbing aspect of the Federal Government's attempt to legislate against discrimination have been the number of government departments which still have not submitted EEO plans.

As the Federal Minister for Industrial Relations was attacking private companies for failing to comply with the affirmation action legislation his own Department still has not submitted its plans. The Canberra Times editorial of 18 December 1988 summed it up when it said:
The words of promise spoken by Public Service heads when the program was introduced almost five years ago-
referring to the equal employment opportunity program in the Public Service, not to the more recent program for the private sector-

have not been matched by the emergence of women within their own ranks, proving that, for all its checks, balances and appeal mechanisms the Public Service still lacks the force and egalitarianism capable of propelling women to the top.
It goes on to note that only 108 people out of the 1,632 people in the Senior Executive Service are women. It continues:

What makes the figures even more damning is the fact that the Australian Public Service, among all employers, had the scope to prosecute the affirmative action program to its maximum extent-it had the Governments imprimatur and was not inhibited by the financial and corporate considerations of private enterprise.
A damning indictment, I would suggest. The editorial finished with these words:
There is some evidence that the affirmative action program changed virtually nothing in the Public Service except the modus operandi of senior administrator.

I hope, with all due sincerity, that the Government will address the question of the Federal Public Service because the Government cannot expect improvement in meeting the spirit of the private sector requirements unless it is prepared to take a lead and set the example within the areas of its control.

More women are moving into employment and, provided they are doing it by choice, we applaud that. We are concerned, however, that as more women move into employment the percentage of those in jobs of lower than average weekly payment is also increasing. It tends to substantiate our concern that more women are moving into the lower paid jobs which carry with them less job satisfaction, fewer training entitlements and more difficult career progression. We would like to see the Government addressing this question more effectively.

We regret to note that in occupational groups there seems to be little horizontal improvement. Women are still largely entering traditional areas of employment. The Government's traineeship system should be an example. We see a domination of women trainees within the traditional area. For example, women constitute 95 per cent of textile, clothing and footwear trainees, 89 per cent of trainees in child-care and 86 per cent of trainees in office/clerical work. We bring that to the Government's attention again and ask that it make a greater effort.

Again I remind honourable senators of the position regarding apprenticeships. This same picture is seen. In the metals are there are 322 women and 43,000 men; in electrical, 286 women and 17,000 men, in building 320 women and nearly 25,000 men. Regrettably, very little progress is being made in moving women into areas of non-traditional work and giving them the additional opportunities for job satisfaction and financial reward that would come from achieving that objective.

We can have all the legislation in the world but we will not have an effective affirmative action system without adequate and affordable child-care. There is no subject upon which I receive more representations in relation to my responsibility for the status of women than the lack of available and affordable child-care which is inhibiting the progress of women within employment. We stress that again for the Government's attention. We stress that women need a better tax package than they are getting at the moment. If I had time I could advance this. We stress that it is necessary to get more women into tertiary institutions and to start courses, as I said, in non-traditional subjects. Unless these basic subjects are addressed, the legislation can be but partially effective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Affirmative Action Equal Employment Opportunity for Women Amendment Bill 1989 proposes a minor change to the Act to require new tertiary institutions to report by 1 January and to recognise that, where amalgamations between tertiary institutions occur, the new body created out of the amalgamation is not to be regarded for the purposes of the Act as a new tertiary institution. As I have said, the amendments are minor. The Government and the Opposition are in accord, and there is no indication that the legislation will be defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have heard from Senator Robert Hill, however, is a speech about the whole of the Act, a questioning of the performance indicators, the effects the Act has had and a number of issues of a general nature. Senator Robert Hill-perhaps after Mr Ian Macphee, a man who has recently had his name in the newspapers, having been dumped by the Liberal Party in Victoria, an event which, is unfortunate for the Liberal Party-is regarded as being one of the feminists of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Peter Baume.

—I acknowledge that we could include Senator Peter Baume in that category. Certainly they are both little `1' Liberals. It is not surprising, therefore, that Senator Hill should have a deep interest in a Bill of this nature. I regard the questions he has put as serious and deserving of an answer. I will refer them to the Minister responsible for this legislation, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris. I am sure that he will, in due course, answer them. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
