QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the very critical report by the Auditor- General on the Government's 150 per cent tax concession for research and development, a report which was released only two days after the Government announced a four-year, $600m extension of the scheme. Specifically, I refer the Minister to the Auditor's conclusion on page 5 that:

QUESTION.PARA: Considerable work remains to be done within the Board, the Department and the Australian Tax Office before there can be an acceptable degree of assurance that amounts allowed as tax deductions are actually expended on eligible and R & D and yield benefits for Australian industry.

Has the Minister previously been made aware of deficiencies in the scheme? If so, when, and what action did he take? Does he accept the Auditor-General's criticisms and what action does he now propose to take? Was the Minister aware of these criticisms when the Government decided to extend the scheme? Does the Auditor's report that monitoring and evaluation procedures to minimise abuse are currently inadequate lend weight to recent claims by some members of the scientific community that the concession has merely encouraged `creative' accounting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, the claims made by two officers of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation regarding creative accounting were totally unsubstantiated and have to be distinguished from the situation relating to the administration of the scheme. I have not studied in detail the Auditor-General's report at the time, but I am familiar with some of the things which are said in that report. For example, the Auditor-General made an absolutely legitimate complaint that there was delay in the adoption of the relevant tax legislation, which delayed the administration of this scheme for some considerable period. The burden of the Auditor-General's report is not one of alleging abuse of the scheme, but rather one of his not being satisfied that the administration was sufficient at the time the report was written to monitor and administer the scheme adequately.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether I had previously been made aware of deficiencies in the scheme. I had, to the extent that there is now in operation a system of auditing of applicants under the scheme jointly by the Australian Taxation Office and my Department. That audit process has been put in place more slowly than I would have wished. I am aware, for example, that for the first time this year company tax returns will be asked to specify amounts claimed in respect of research and development. It might have been desirable for that to have happened earlier. As I understand it, the company tax scheme is being revised generally and this is included in that revision.

I find some difficulty with what the Auditor-General said with regard to monitoring and evaluation, because we have moved in respect of taxation to a scheme of self- assessment. I understand from reports of the Auditor-General's report that the audit process under the tax concessions scheme will involve the same percentage of claimants as the audit scheme generally catches or examines in terms of the overall self-assessment scheme for taxpayers. So I do not think there is any difference there from the normal run of taxation paid. I do not see why there should be, because there is potentially much more to be lost to taxation revenue generally under a self-assessment scheme than under this tax concession. As far as I know, every effort has been made to improve gradually the administration of the scheme. That process will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not respond to my question about whether he was aware of these concerns when the Government decided to extend the scheme. I repeat that part of my question. I also ask the Minister, in light of his rather low key reply, whether he accepts that these are serious matters that have been raised by the Auditor-General? Is he doing anything about it, and, if so, what?

—To an extent, I would agree that they are serious matters. I gave one example. Implicit in the Auditor-General's report is the suggestion that somehow the audit of claimants under the scheme should be different from the audit of taxpayers generally. I do not understand that and I will be very happy to discuss it with the Auditor-General as soon as I can see him. In the earlier answer, I said that there had been delays in improving the administration of the scheme, which I regret.
—Are you aware of the criticisms of the extended scheme?
—I am not aware of the criticisms made by the Auditor-General. I am aware of criticisms, most of which emanated from me when I inquired about the administration.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to media reports of proposals for a Bill of Rights for aged Australians being promoted by the Australian Retired Persons Association. Has the Minister seen a copy of the Bill of Rights and has he had costed the proposals it contains? Is the description of the so-called Bill of Rights as `affordable' correct and will the Government be implementing it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen a copy of the so-called Bill of Rights about which Mr Bernard Lord has spoken, but I have seen a number of transcripts and newspaper reports. From them, it is apparent that the three most significant proposals are, first, to increase and tie the pension to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings; secondly, to lift the free income area to 12 1/2 per cent of average weekly earnings; and, thirdly, to provide automatically or, as of right, which is the term Mr Lord used, a universal pension to persons over 72 years of age. There were a number of other demands, but I have had those three costed.

ANSWER.PARA: The cost of tying the pension to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings would, if it was restricted to age and service pensioners, cost $2.3 billion. If it was extended to invalid pensioners, supporting parents and unemployment beneficiaries, those payments, which are either identical to or closely linked to the age pension, would cost an additional $1.7 billion. The total cost for the first item is $4 billion. The cost of increasing the free area prior to the operation of the income test to 12 1/2 per cent of average weekly earnings is $280m for the age pensioners and $85m for the others. The very regressive proposal to pay a universal age pension to all persons over 72 years of age would cost at present pension rates $1,200m and at the proposed enhanced rate of 30 per cent of average weekly earnings an extra $380m, making a total of $1,580m. So the gross cost is $5.9 billion. If it were paid only to age pensioners and not to the other related categories, the gross cost would be above $4 billion. The claw-back would be of the order of $800m if the increases were paid to all the social security recipients that I have identified, leaving a net cost to the Budget in excess of $5 billion or close to 10 per cent of total taxation revenue.

I have been asked whether it is affordable. That really depends on the level of taxation which the community is willing to pay. For example, if Australia's level of tax from all governments was as high as Sweden's, that is, 50.5 per cent of gross domestic product as compared to just over 30 per cent in Australia-using 1985 figures, which will not have changed very much-taxation in total as a proportion of GDP would rise by 20 per cent. That would give government an extra $66 billion to spend. It is, however, very clear that Australians are not willing to pay the Swedish level of taxation.

I would like to make a couple of other points on the interview with Mr Lord, which I personally heard. He was asked whether, in view of the ageing population of Australia, superannuation was the way to go to provide for retirement incomes rather than universal pensions. He said that young couples these days cannot afford superannuation. To the extent that that is true, if they cannot afford it on present taxation levels, they certainly would not be able to afford it if there was a 60 per cent increase in total tax collection. That is what would be required to take us to the Swedish level.

The relevance of the Swedish level, of course, is that Mr Lord himself cited it. When asked about the greying of the Australian population he said that that really was not a relevant issue because Sweden had twice as many people of pensionable age for twice as high a proportion of pensionable age right now as Australia does. Sweden pays pensions out of-I stress again because it is terribly important-a level of taxation 20 percentage points of GDP above the Australian level. If people want those levels of taxation they can afford the sort of thing that Mr Lord is talking about. But clearly they do not.

It ought also to be observed that nobody who is presently of pensionable age has paid throughout his working life the level of taxation which would have been required to pay a pension without any income test. In other words, in calling for this measure now when he has reached retirement age, Mr Lord is asking to receive what he himself during his working life has not paid for. My final comment is that I certainly do not believe that Mr Lord is speaking for people of retirement age in general; he is speaking for a small minority of people of retirement age and should be judged accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It relates to the concern which some people have expressed that there will be no work done at the National Museum of Australia for five years. What funding decisions have been reached and/or announced by the Government on the Museum of Australia both as to its construction and the maintenance of the collection? Is the fairly extensive collection already in store likely to have no permanent home and no place for display for another five years because funds will not be released for construction of the museum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly in respect of the National Museum of Australia there have been some funding problems, to say the least. In addressing general priorities for funding in the last few years, there had to be substantial cuts across the board in all sectors of government spending in order to participate in righting our economy from the wrongs of the past. Obviously the arts community had to bear some part of that burden. In establishing what burden it ought to bear, obviously the Government was mindful of trying to make sure that we did not make it too great and that it did not impact too much on individuals. Given that the National Museum of Australia would have required a very substantial amount of money to build a new facility, it was the view of the Government that such a decision could be postponed in the light of other priorities. That is what occurred. Nonetheless, money was granted for maintenance of the collection. There are before the Government at the moment other proposals for the future of the museum. However, I am not at liberty to disclose those because they remain part of Cabinet discussions. I am afraid I cannot elaborate any further.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer him to an article entitled `Cocaine and the Foetal Risks' which appeared in the New York Times of 5 September 1988 and a very similar article in the Melbourne Sun in March of this year.
—Do you read the New York Times?
—Does the Minister read the New York Times?

—What about the Melbourne Sun? Can the Minister inform honourable senators of the results of research on the effects of cocaine and crack usage during pregnancy? What is the Government doing to stem the awful trade in cocaine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that Senator Hill is more familiar with the New York Times than almost anyone else in this chamber since he spent some months there at the taxpayers' expense-quite legitimately. Nevertheless, that would explain his awareness of articles in the paper.
—Senator Bolkus read it too.

—Senator Bolkus would have read the New York Times also, no doubt. This is a most serious question. I can understand why Senator Foreman, who takes a great interest in these matters, should wish to raise it. The information that was contained in the articles in the Melbourne Sun about the results of research into the effects of the taking of cocaine, particularly by pregnant women, can only be described as horrific. The image that cocaine has as recreational or yucky-yuppie-drug-I will explain why that slip came about as I go on-is totally undeserved. Let me outline the position from those articles very briefly: In some United States cities 27 per cent, more than one in four, of babies being born are addicted to cocaine and other hard drugs. Crack hit California in the early 1980s and the far-reaching effects of the drug have just surfaced. This year, about 25 per cent of an expected 2,500 births at Oaklands Highland General Hospital, east of San Francisco, will result in shuddering, dwarfish babies affected by the crack their mothers smoked during pregnancy.

ANSWER.PARA: According to Dr Ira J. Chasnoff who directed a study of 36 United States hospitals research suggests that a single cocaine `hit' during pregnancy can cause lasting foetal damage. While a single dose of cocaine and its metabolites clear out of an adult body within 48 hours, an unborn baby is exposed for four or five days. As a result, the researchers believe almost no cocaine-exposed baby fully escapes its damaging affects. The lists of threats is long and growing. Cocaine exposed babies are more likely to die before birth or to be born prematurely. They tend to be abnormally small for their age at birth and have smaller than normal heads and brains. They face an increased risk of deformities of the genital and urinary organs, including kidney malformations that can lead to life-threatening infections.

I mention these ill effects which can affect the foetus. It is not within my portfolio interest to send a message to women, though I hope they receive it, but I want to explain the very vigorous steps that Australian law enforcement agencies are now taking to prepare us for the targeting of Australia as a market for cocaine by the cocaine cartels. Intelligence indicates that those cartels from South America are targeting Australia as a new and relatively untapped market for their deadly drug. In 1987 in the United States of America some 37,000 kilograms of cocaine were seized compared with 375 kilograms of heroin. In Australia the comparable figures were 16 kilograms of cocaine and 31 kilograms of heroin. One can see from those figures that the United States market is well and truly saturated, and Australia is regarded by these cartels as a relatively wealthy untapped market for their deadly drug. Indeed, the street price of cocaine in Australia is 10 times the price in the United States, so one can see why Australia would be attractive to such cartels.

The fact is that, in order to meet this challenge, the two relevant Commonwealth agencies-the Australian Customs Service, under the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, and the Australian Federal Police (AFP)-are devising their strategies to help prevent this expected penetration of cocaine into the Australian market. For example, only recently the first of what I hope will be a number of AFP liaison officers will be posted to Buenos Aires in South America, because that is the first city to establish a direct air link between Sydney and the South American continent. I believe that that sort of intelligence gathering and the cooperative endeavours with local law enforcement agencies, which have characterised the work of the AFP overseas liaison officers, will help us to get early warning of proposed importations into Australia and help in the law enforcement effort to preclude them from our shores.

I hope that, at the Australian Police Ministers Council meeting next week in Adelaide, the full cooperation of the States in these endeavours will be secured so that we can prevent the sort of horrific damage, not only to adults in our community but also to foetuses and babies, which has been evidenced in the United States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to an answer given by the Minister for Finance to a question from Senator Newman on Monday of this week relating to a delayed Government response to a committee report. The question and answer are recorded on page 1959 of Hansard. As part of that answer, Senator Walsh said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . no, it does not indicate the Government's concern about the subject; it probably indicates something about the degree of respect that the Government has for Senate committee reports-a degree of respect which, by and large, I think is entirely justified.

Is the Leader of the Government able to explain on what basis Senator Walsh implied that a lack of respect by the Government for Senate Committee reports is `by and large . . . entirely justified'. Does Senator Walsh's answer accurately reflect the Government's attitude towards Senate committee reports? If it does, will the Minister give details to the Senate of any other committee reports which have not been responded to within a reasonable time because of the Government's apparent contempt for the Senate committee system? If it does not reflect the Government's attitude, what is the reason for the lengthy delay in the Government's response to this particular committee report, and is the Government planning a re-education campaign directed at Senator Walsh and his attitude towards Senate committees by and large?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very complex question. Senator Haines is asking me to make a subjective analysis of what was in Senator Walsh's mind at a particular time. I know there is a lot on his mind at any particular time. I cannot really make a guess at what he was saying at that point. I will have a discussion with Senator Walsh about that and see whether I can elucidate what he was talking about at that time. There were a couple of other parts of the question about outstanding reports and so on.
—No, the Government's attitude to committees and committee reports in general.

—I do not think the Government has, or ever has had, a collective attitude on that matter. Some Senate reports are very good, and I hazard a personal opinion that some of them are not so good. But I do not think there is any collective view about that.

—My question, directed to the Minister for Resources, follows a question about taxes on crude oil asked by Senator Lewis on Monday. Can the Minister tell the Senate how much excise the Fraser Government took from Bass Strait production compared with the amount extracted by this Government? What steps has the Government taken to meet the objections from oil companies that the tax is damaging the Australian oil exploration effort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis tried to score a cheap political point at the end of Question Time on Monday by accusing this Government of being an excessive taxer of the Australian oil industry to the extent that it curbs exploration and thus the finding of more oil to meet our opening self-sufficiency gap. I cannot answer in direct monetary terms what the Fraser Government took out of Bass Strait in the way of taxes compared with what we have taken because, since there is one producer, those figures are commercial in confidence figures. But what I can do is refer to a table which shows the percentages of take by the Fraser Government in the last five years of its period in office compared with what has been taken in five years under this Government. In that table we find that, on average, the Fraser Government took excise of 71 per cent of the gross value of sales out of Bass Strait compared with 60.4 per cent under our Government. In the year 1978-79, the Fraser Government took 63 per cent, the following year 72 per cent, the next year 74 per cent, in 1981-82 73 per cent, and in 1982-83 72 per cent. Indeed, in terms of oil excise, the Fraser Government was a very high taxing government. Under this Government, taxation on Bass Strait production has been, in 1983, 65 per cent, and in successive years 65 per cent, 58 per cent, 58 per cent and 56 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Not all of those figures, of course, are due to the level of excise. Under the old oil/new oil regime some of those figures show a disproportionate bias in favour of the Fraser years, it has to be said, because of the reliance on old oil production compared to new oil production. But there have been significant reductions in excise on Bass Strait production under this Government. We made a number of changes. The highest excise rate applying to old oil was reduced in 1986 from 87 per cent to 80 per cent. Further reductions will see this rate fall from the current level of 77 per cent to 75 per cent on 1 July this year. The Government also made the important concession that the first 30 million barrels of production from all onshore fields and new offshore fields where the resource rent tax regime does not apply will be excise free. Furthermore, there is an annual excise free production tranche of 8,000 barrels a day. Hence, no onshore oil producers pay excise, and that means that excise will not be paid on most new projects either.

I also indicate that the Government has, by its introduction of the resource rent tax, sorted out a number of the imperfections in the taxation system. Also, I have foreshadowed, in carrying out a promise given by Senator Gareth Evans when he was Minister for Resources and Energy, the bringing forward of the excise review. So I conclude that, on the figures, the Fraser Government, of which I understand Senator Lewis was a member, was the higher taxing government of the oil industry. Further, if one believes the argument of the oil industry-and the argument Senator Lewis tried to put in this chamber-that the level of taxes determines the amount of exploration, and if there is a curb on exploration in Australia, the Government of which Senator Lewis was a party was a major contributor to that curb.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the rapid acceleration in the growth of the money supply in recent months to the extent that, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia, the increase in M3 was 22.7 per cent in the 12 months ended March 1989 compared with 13.9 per cent just six months earlier and that the growth in what is described as broad money was 18.1 per cent in the year to March compared with 11.2 per cent six months earlier? Does the Minister regard these rates of growth as excessive and far beyond those commensurate with the requirements and best interests of the Australian economy? Does he agree that their damage to the economy is compounded by the record level of real interest rates prevailing in most sections of the money market? What are the reasons for these excessive rates of increase, and what measures does the Government propose to take to return monetary policy to an acceptable and responsible course?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is anything worse than an unreconstructed Friedmanite, or a crude monetarist, I suppose it is one who does not even know some of the other relevant changes that have taken place in the last 12 months. In the last 12 months, specifically, the reduction in the statutory reserve deposit requirements has had the effect of taking into bank transactions financial transactions which would have been conducted outside the banking system before that, and, therefore, has increased bank deposits. That is even if people believe that M3, or broad money M6 which includes M3, has the sort of relevance that some believe it had in the 1970s. The long-term effects of deregulation in 1984 or 1985 are probably still coming through as well.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Short wants to consider base money-I gave these figures the other day and cannot remember precisely what they were-the increase in the money base was something of the order of 9 per cent over the most recent 12 months, which is lower than nominal gross domestic product growth. Therefore, there has been a squeeze on that. The final point I make concerns the contradictory premises upon which this question seems to be based, that is, the allegation that the growth of the money supply is excessive and should be tightened, coupled with the demand that interest rates be reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Does he mean by it that the Government considers that the rate of growth of money supply is now irrelevant to the course of economic activity in this country?

—The Government does not consider that it is irrelevant. Even if one believes in the crude Friedmanite money supply theory, it would need to be adjusted for such clear compositional changes such as those which have been induced by the reduction in the statutory reserve deposit requirement. At no time should anybody who understood it have believed in the super-crude or super-simplistic MV necessarily equals PQ2 equation, because there were two other variables in that equation besides the price levels and the money supply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. The Courier-Mail recently carried a report publicising the decision of the Queensland National Party Government to renew sand mining leases on Fraser Island. What is the Commonwealth Government's attitude in regard to this decision which would allow further destruction of this magnificent island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was in late April, although I cannot recall the exact date, that the Courier-Mail reported that the National Party Government in Queensland had renewed sand mining leases on Fraser Island in 1987, and had done so without any consultation. The leases in question are those owned by Dillingham-Murphyores, which is a subsidiary of the Pivot Group. The Courier-Mail reported that the leases cover the east coast of the island and include parts of the townships of Happy Valley and Eurong, as well as the scenic area of Eli Creek. In 1976, it should be said, on environmental grounds the Fraser Government stopped sand mining on Fraser Island by use of the export control powers. We heard about some of that in the debate on forests yesterday because this is, seemingly, the only issue that the Liberal Party can point to in which it has some environmental credentials.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier than 1976, the Whitlam Government set up an inquiry to produce a report on the Fraser Island environment and that inquiry found, among other things, that Fraser Island is the largest sand island in the world; it contains large areas of rainforests and areas of free, open eucalyptus forests, perched lakes, heathland and a number of sand dunes. The report stated that the natural environment of Fraser Island `had great significance, complexity and fragility'. The Fraser Government in 1976 also compensated sand mining companies for not proceeding. Dillingham-Murphyores received $4m in compensation; Queensland Titanium received half a million dollars in compensation; and $10m was allocated to regional employment initiatives for projects for employment in the area.

Despite this 12-year ban on mining on Fraser Island, the National Party Government in Queensland, one of the coalition partners in terms of the Opposition in this chamber, has granted further leases for mining. I think it would be interesting, before we go too far down that track, to find out what the Liberal Party policy might be on matters affecting this issue. The present Liberal-National Party coalition policy on the use of export control powers reads:
We will abolish all export controls on the minerals and metals sector except where such exports infringe on national security or on international obligations.

If a Liberal-National Party government were to come to power, it would abolish, according to its policy prescription, the very means by which the Queensland Government was able to protect the environment of Fraser Island. Given the attitude of the Queensland National Party Government in granting leases, this would open this unique and fragile environment to mining. As the ban on mining on Fraser Island is the only issue on which the Opposition can parade its environmental credentials-quite apart from its most recent attempt to turn green on Antarctica-what we have in terms of the Opposition's policy commitment is a commitment, in effect, which would allow mining in this fragile area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Defence give a guarantee that the Chinook heavy duty helicopter squadron based at Amberley in Queensland will not be disbanded? This unique chopper squadron is vital not only to the nation's defence but to civil emergencies as well, as demonstrated recently when a family of four was saved from a sinking yacht off the Gold Coast. Had a Chinook not been available, the family, including a seven-month old baby, would almost certainly have perished. If the Chinook squadron is to be disbanded, can the Minister give a reason why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make some inquiries of the Minister for Defence and give Senator Sheil an answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the labour force figures released today. Firstly, do those figures confirm a continued decline in the national unemployment rate? Secondly, do the figures show differences in the levels of unemployment amongst the States? Finally, can those differences be explained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen today's Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin employment levels and workforce participation. One should express the reservation about the figures that for the last three months they have been somewhat erratic. At this stage I do not think one should be too dogmatic about whether the seemingly very high April figure should be taken to be more reliable than the inexplicably low March figure.
—Easter very rarely falls in March.

—I thank Senator Stone for that interjection. That may be a relevant factor. I am reserving judgment on which figure is the more accurate. When one looks at the three-monthly figures, what does unequivocally emerge is that employment is still growing at very high rates. Because of that, the unemployment rate came down marginally in April to 6.1 per cent, even though the participation rate rose from 62.2 per cent to 62.8 per cent. That was a large increase in the participation rate, but still a reduction in the unemployment rate. Of course, those two figures, other things being equal, would be inversely related. It is also worth noting-and these are all seasonally adjusted figures-that the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in April last year was 7.8 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked about the performance of the States. They are quite variable. In Victoria, for example, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 5 per cent. The figures rose through the other States. Western Australia had the somewhat higher figure of 5.4 per cent; in New South Wales, it was higher at 6.4 per cent; in Queensland, the figure was 7.1 per cent; in South Australia, it was 7.4 which was, however, substantially down on the 9.2 per cent recorded in the same month last year. Tasmania was, as usual, the worst performer with a staggering unemployment rate of 9.2 per cent, and a fall of only 0.2 per cent since April of last year when the national figure had come down by 1.6 per cent. The South Australian figure had come down by 1.8 per cent. As I mentioned last week, Premier Gray was elected in 1982 on a promise to do something about jobs in Tasmania. He has clearly failed to do it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INFORMATION SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. With the Minister's awareness of the Australian Science and Technology Information Service, and the part that it is designed to play in the promotion and promulgation of science and technology-specifically amongst the general public, school students and their teachers, and parliamentarians and public servants-and with his knowledge that the service is in line with similar aims and operations of the Royal Society of London, the American and British Associations for the Advancement of Science, and the Scientists' Institute for Public Information, can he assure the Senate that sufficient funds will be provided from the billion-dollar deal pronounced on Monday to enable the service to carry out its very important functions?

—That organisation was considered in the discussions leading up to the statement that was made on Monday. I do not think that it is valid to proceed on the assumption that the sort of service offered by the Australian Science and Technology Information Service would be the same sort of service as is offered by the Royal Society in Britain. The market is totally different, the number of inquiries is estimated to be totally different in terms of the percentage of the population, and so on. I cannot give any assurance about money being made available for that service. It is on the agenda to be examined. The appropriate amount of money will be determined when the cost-benefit analysis of the service to the Australian community has been completed.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, refers to the labelling of non-alcoholic beverages. What level of alcohol has to be present in a product before the manufacturer is required to declare its presence on the label? Do certain so-called soft drinks, such as Claytons tonic and certain non-alcoholic wines, in fact contain some alcohol? If so, how much? What protection is available to the public in determining whether or not the so-called soft drink does, in fact, contain alcohol?

—This question has obviously come a bit too late in the week for some of us! Basically, the labelling of alcoholic products is governed by the food standards code, which is part of the National Foods Standards Agreement. It is a code which is adopted in all States and Territories, apart from the Australian Capital Territory and, after today's events in the ACT Assembly, I anticipate that Rosemary Follett's Government will adopt the food standards code for the Territory. The food standards code provides a number of regimes for the labelling of alcohol. In essence, however, all products with levels of alcohol have to be labelled, setting out the percentage of alcohol content. However, in terms of the maximum allowable alcohol level for non-alcoholic or non-intoxicating beverages, the National Food Standards code provides that if beverages contain more than 0.5 per cent of alcohol by volume they cannot be labelled as non-alcoholic. For certain reasons, drinks containing a level of alcohol of less than 0.5 per cent can be classified as being non-alcoholic. We also have provisions in the food standards code for the labelling of beverages which cannot be labelled as non-alcoholic but can be labelled as being low-alcohol or reduced-alcohol and non-intoxicating. They differ according to the particular product, but in those cases as well the labels have to indicate clearly the level of alcohol in the beverage. In essence, therefore, I cannot really say what the situation is in respect of Claytons, but I can say that non-alcoholic beverages can have a maximum of 0.5 per cent of alcohol. The protection for the consumer is that there has to be adequate labelling.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of the growing crisis facing pharmacies in one-pharmacy towns? Is he aware that these pharmacies are becoming non-viable as a result of the Federal Government's cuts in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and other measures taken outside the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remunerations Tribunal which are eroding the economic base of community pharmacies? Is he aware of the reality that residents of one-pharmacy towns will have to travel hundreds of kilometres each time pharmaceutical services are required if their pharmacies are closed? Can the Minister give an unequivocal guarantee to the people of rural Australia that this Government will take action to prevent the closure of the pharmacies in these rural towns and, thus, prevent undue medical hardship for residents and severe financial and social loss to local communities?

—I am aware of the situation facing pharmacies in cities, large towns and country towns. I believe that nothing that this Government is proposing to do to reform the pharmacy arrangements in this country will affect them.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of events that have befallen the population of some 12,000 Lebanese Christians of the Chouf Coast who were ejected from their homes by armed troops on 28 April 1985, after which their houses were bulldozed and their entitlements to the land was lost? Is the Minister aware that the Australia Government's compassionate and humanitarian immigration program for war-affected Lebanese civilians was amended in early 1986 to provide that eligible applicants must make application within 90 days of the incident that directly affected them, and that many of the Chouf Coast Lebanese Christians have thus been denied entry to Australia? Since some 10,000 of the Chouf Coast refugees are now in Australia, having left behind some 2,000 relatives excluded by the 90-day provision, will the Minister grant a special waiver of the immigration points system to permit these Australian families to be reunited with relatives currently in Lebanon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the historical circumstances affecting those people from the Chouf Coast. In fact, I visited that area before those events occurred. I think most people would agree that that is typical of many of the events that have occurred in Lebanon over the past 15 years of internecine warfare. I know that there exists a special program for Lebanon, under which, if a person's house is destroyed, and if he has relatives in Australia, he can apply within 90 days to come to Australia. That is outside any other policy requirements, such as refugee status or the points system. Lebanon is the only country receiving this favourable treatment which bypasses both the 1951 convention on refugees and the points system. It is the only exception that we make around the world. It has been in place for five or six years and I should like to remove it, but until circumstances in Lebanon change I have no intention of doing so. I should like to remove it because that would indicate great progress in attempts to end the warfare in Lebanon.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether we would provide a one-off waiver for these people. The answer is no. Yesterday I met the same delegation as the honourable senator met-the delegation that prompted this question. One would be pretty heartless if one did not feel for some of the people in Lebanon in these circumstances, but if we were to provide one exemption, how many more exemptions would we be supposed to grant? What about the Kurds from Iran? What about the Tamils in Sri Lanka, the Indians in Fiji, or the people in Guatemala, El Salvador or Nicaragua? On and on it goes.

I recently sent a reference to the House of Representatives Committee on Community Affairs, specifically asking it to look at ways in which people could come to Australia on compassionate grounds without having to be measured by the points system or given refugee status, while at the same time guaranteeing the Australian Government and taxpayer that they would not be a financial burden. I hope that that Committee will bring forward suggestions that will meet not only this case-and we know that many of these people would make great settlers in Australia-but also other cases in which people are ruined. I think the honourable senator is aware of the type of cases I am referring to. What it comes down to in the end is that every year we receive 1.3 million inquiries-representing three million people-about immigration to Australia. That figure has to come down to 140,000. Currently 12 million displaced persons in the world are claiming refugee status. It is very hard to appeal to my compassion by saying that I should favour one group over another. If I were to do so I think it would be only for political advantage and not out of fairness and equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, refers to my question to him yesterday about industry development arrangements for the telecommunications equipment industry and the undertaking he gave to provide a more detailed answer to aspects of the question. During the course of his answer yesterday he said that I did not mention that the proposal was of limited duration only and that it had a sunset provision in it. I ask the Minister: Has he or any of his colleagues made any previous statement to the Parliament outlining the nature and details of the industry development arrangements for the telecommunications equipment industry? I have not been able to find any such statement to the Parliament. I have managed to find a press release issued by a couple of Ministers on 13 December last year, but there has been no statement to the Parliament about these matters. I also ask the Minister: What is the basis for the dispersal of favours inherent in those arrangements? For example, are they to be covered by any legislation of the Parliament or by any regulations? If not, will the Minister make a detailed statement on those arrangements so that the Parliament can take note of that statement, debate the issues and understand what the Government is proposing for these industries? Or will the Government do what it really ought to do-that is, introduce legislation to provide a formal basis for these arrangements and other schemes, such as the partnership program and the offsets scheme, so that the Parliament may examine in detail the merits or otherwise of the Government's various schemes and provide legislative cover for them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator tempts me. His Liberal Government introduced the offsets scheme and ran it for many years without any legislative base.
—You have been in government for a long time now.

—It is no good for the honourable senator to come in here and complain about this Government not providing a legislative base. If he listened to me for a minute he would realise that his Government did not provide any legislative base as it was not really possible to do so. We are in exactly the same position as the previous Government was then. If the honourable senator understood the scheme he would know that. So it is no good for the honourable senator to come in here with his usual slogans about government by press release and all that stuff which is very convenient to him. They alleviate him from the responsibility of having to think about the issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday the honourable senator asked me a question about these industry development arrangements and I undertook to provide a more detailed answer. As I said yesterday, during the development of this policy a considerable effort was devoted to ensuring that the new arrangements were consistent with the approach of the partnership for development scheme in the information industries. As I also said yesterday, they represent a transitional arrangement-from Telecom's very rigid local content scheme to a new scheme which is much more market-oriented. The industry development arrangements provide an orderly environment for increasing competition and promoting the restructuring of the local telecommunications equipment industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does `orderly' mean? A regulated marketing scheme, not a free market operation?

—No. I want to try to help the honourable senator to understand what I am saying. I am saying that a very controlled, rigid point system was operated by Telecom for many years. An exit from that scheme to a market-oriented scheme has to be done in an orderly way. The purpose of that is to promote the restructuring of a local telecommunications equipment industry over the four-year period of the industry development arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of a desire for consistency in the approach adopted in the partnership scheme, the industry development arrangements focus on research and development, export performance and local value added. Industry development schemes permit these activities to be undertaken in any segment of the customer premises equipment sector. That is in great contrast with Telecom's previous approach, which essentially required local production of any product which was to be supplied in Australia. The approach is directly in line with the emphasis on strategic business formulation which is inherent in the partnership scheme.
Yesterday the honourable senator also asked about the partnership scheme and whether that was being abandoned. The answer to that question is no. It is achieving some degree of success.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Some degree'-very comprehensive!

—It is always best to be modest in terms of the achievements of these schemes because the task is a very big one. Looking at the trade deficit and computer and information industry equipment we see that that will not be overcome very quickly. So one refers-if I might do so without raising the honourable senator's ire in any way-to modest success with that scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator also asked whether the development of the industry would be compromised by fragmentation and diminishing linkages between local and international firms. An understanding of the customer premises equipment industry would lead one to the instant conclusion that it is highly fragmented at present. One of the major purposes of the industry development arrangements is to promote restructuring, consolidation and international competitiveness in the sector and to try to get rid of some of the fragmentation that is inherent in the past arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister seen recent press reports that appeared in a number of newspapers over the last weekend which, in part, blamed the shortage of international airline flights landing in Perth for the alleged loss of thousands of dollars to Perth hotel proprietors? Is the Minister aware that these reports arise following the launch of a public awareness campaign by the Western Australian Hotels Association Inc.? If the assertion to which I referred in the first part of my question is accurate, will the Minister place on the record the actual figures on the number of international aircraft landing each week in Perth and, in giving these figures, will he please indicate the percentage of seats that are occupied on those aircraft?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Transport and Communications that claims that the Federal Government's aviation policy is responsible for the loss of millions of dollars of tourist revenue in Western Australia are clearly unsupportable. The reported surplus of hotel accommodation in Perth is clearly the result of commercial decisions having been made within the Western Australian tourism industry. Undoubtedly, it is also a consequence of the extensive development which occurred in the lead-up to the America's Cup in 1987.

ANSWER.PARA: Any claim that Qantas Airways Ltd has prevented carriers from flying to Perth can be dismissed by reference to the fact that the Federal Government determines the grant of rights and levels of capacity to be operated on routes into and out of Australia. It is quite appropriate that the Government should consult with Qantas as the national carrier. This is the practice for all governments around the world. Negotiations for access of foreign airlines to Australia must take into account judgments about the balance of opportunities and benefits, both for Australia and for Qantas. While the views of all interested parties are given due weight, ultimately the decision is one for the Federal Government.

The Department of Transport and Communications consults in this respect with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whose responsibilities include, in turn, consultation with tourism bodies, such as the Australian Travel Industry Association and the provision of a coordinated approach to tourism matters at the national level. It consults on all major issues affecting inbound tourism to Australia and specifically on international landing rights negotiations. In addition, the Department of Transport and Communications receives direct representations from tourist organisations on specific issues relating to the provision of international air services.

In recent months substantial increases in seat capacity to Perth have been agreed to for a number of Asian carriers and discussions with other Asian government authorities are planned for later this year. It is a matter for these airlines to make their own commercial decisions regarding their pattern of operations within the overall entitlements agreed for them. The Federal Government does not interfere in these commercial decisions.

The Government can and does encourage foreign airlines to take up their entitlements to serve Perth. Finally, in terms of statistics, of the 15 carriers which have been granted rights to service Perth only eight, including Qantas, have chosen to exercise their entitlements. The seven airlines which have chosen not to take up the rights that they presently have are All Nippon Airways, Continental Airlines, United Airlines, KLM, Hawaiian Airlines, Air India and the Flying Tigers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DIESEL FUEL TAX: BASS STRAIT FERRY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and relates to the Government's decision to refuse a request from a Tasmanian ferry service company and the State Liberal Government to exempt from diesel fuel tax the service's proposed Bass Strait catamaran. Can the Minister explain the rationale behind the Government's decision when exemptions already apply to airlines which are to be in direct competition with the ferry service? Does the Minister acknowledge that the Government's decision, which will add about $26 to the cost of a return ticket on the ferry, will cause significant harm to the growth of Tasmania's important tourism industry-which, by the way, Senator Richardson admitted yesterday was being under-funded and under-promoted by the Tasmanian Government? Does the fact that this decision had to be announced by the State Minister for Transport, Mr Nick Evers, indicate that Mr Hawke and the Federal Government have sought to keep the lid on this matter until after the State election because of the electoral backlash that this will have on the State Labor Opposition's dwindling stocks in Tasmania?

—I am not sure that this question is properly directed to me because it relates to excise. It perhaps should have been asked of another Minister. I do not know anything about it, although I must say that the claim that the excise on diesel fuel for a passenger ferry would add $26 to the price of ticket across Bass Strait I find extremely fanciful. I would be very interested to see the arithmetic that justified that claim. I suspect that he put the decimal point in the wrong place.

—At Question Time yesterday Senator Panizza asked me a question about the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations (CER). In the course of the answer I said that the free trade in goods was being brought forward from 1992 to 1990. That was a step in the process. In fact the answer should have been from 1995 to 1990, considering the original CER discussions. I wanted to correct that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis asked me a question on 5 May about the business activities that government business enterprises might be allowed to undertake. He cited Australia Post as an example and suggested that it might sell post offices and invest in a brewery. Senator Lewis knows that this Government has taken a series of decisions to reform its business enterprises, and legislation to implement those decisions is currently before the Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I should remind the honourable senator why it is that we are taking these important steps. Enterprises such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post provide services which are important to our economy and form a significant input to the costs of many industries. Obviously any improvements that we can make in the way that these services are delivered will lead to economic benefits to the community as a whole and assist in improving our international competitiveness. The Government's reform packages recognise that, to realise these efficiency gains in the way the enterprises deliver their services-letters in the case of Australia Post and telecommunications in the case of Telecom-the enterprises need to be able to maximise the use of the assets employed in these businesses.

To allow for this, it is normal practice to provide an incidentals power in the enterprises' enabling statutes. The Government intends that this practice be continued in the future. However, the Government's reform package also protects against the wild cases being speculated by Senator Lewis by providing for a corporate planning process where enterprise boards are required to indicate what business policy directions are to be adopted in the future. Boards are to be held accountable for achieving pre-determined targets in these plans. Through these corporate plans, the Government will ensure that the enterprises concentrate on their core activity.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY AND SEX DISCRIMINATION

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Vanstone asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, about equal opportunity in the Public Service and a case involving Ms Styles. I undertook to obtain further information and it is as follows. The Commonwealth is appealing against the decision of Mr Justice Wilcox in the Styles case, for technical reasons only, to clarify matters of principle including equal employment opportunity principles which have been clouded by the terms in which the original decision in the Styles case was phrased. The Government has undertaken to meet Ms Styles's costs for the appeal.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is concerned that the original decision would endanger the success of the equal opportunity programs and practices by providing a disincentive for the practice of advertising positions. Among other things, the original decision implies that departments could remain within the law if they filled positions on transfer without advertising. Secondly, in reference to practices, the original decision might cast doubt on the ability of management to transfer staff between positions, a mechanism which is considered to be important for the implementation of equal employment opportunities.

The Government endorses the sex discrimination legislation and is seeking to clarify its application, not to water it down. The Government's commitment to equal employment opportunity policies is a matter of record. Frankly, I would say that the major organisational changes since July 1987 have slowed progress to some extent. However, the transition period following this restructuring is now complete and the Government is looking to reinvigoration of equal employment opportunity programs and improved results.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov has asked a question of me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women regarding the affirmative action legislation. She asked what evidence there was of success in terms of women entering the work force and gaining access to promotion. The affirmative action legislation introduced in 1986 was a major plank in the Government's strategy to improve the participation and status of women in the Australian labour market, and it is already yielding results. It created an awareness of the very real benefits of giving women a fair go, both among employers and in the wider community. This increased awareness is reflected in the high level of compliance in the higher education institutions and companies in the first phase of the operation of the affirmative action legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Of the employers covered by the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act, 99 per cent reported to the Affirmative Action Agency on their affirmative action programs in the first year. Amongst those who reported, over two-thirds indicated that they had reviewed their promotion and transfer policies in order to identify and remove discrimination against women in this important area of personnel policy, and there are many examples of companies directly attributing the affirmative action Act as the impetus for recognising the greater potential of women employees and opening promotional opportunities for them. For example, the Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society said:
The number of women managers at Colonial Mutual has increased by 50 percent since the implementation of its affirmative action program.
The Ford Motor Co. of Australia said:

the Company's equal opportunity program has ensured a greater focus on matters such as the recruiting of female graduates from engineering and other disciplines, and female apprentices into trades which were hitherto exclusively male.
There are other examples of the same kind from companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it is as a result of the legislation?
—These companies say so.
—They do not say so. They say that the numbers have increased. They do not relate it to the legislation. It is an important question, isn't it?

—Of course, it is an important question. Perhaps Senator Hill could ask it at Estimates Committee hearings as he did last year. The participation rate of women has increased from 44.3 per cent in April 1983 to 50.5 per cent in April 1989. Further gains of that kind are expected to be made.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS: SICK LEAVE CERTIFICATES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Chapman asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications about air traffic controllers and sick leave at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The response I have from the Minister is as follows: The Government, of course, deplores the disruption to services that occurred at Kingsford-Smith airport last Friday in which we understand some 11,000 people were inconvenienced. The reason, it appears, is that there was a high level of reported sickness of air traffic controllers in past weeks, especially on last Friday when further air traffic controllers reported sick that day. There was no-one to take their places who had not already worked a reasonable amount of overtime. Requests to work more than that level of overtime on Friday were refused. Accordingly, with unavailability of a senior air traffic controller and one of the aerodrome controllers, the rest of the staff refused to continue working.

ANSWER.PARA: It is difficult to say emphatically that what was happening was industrial action but we certainly regard it as very likely. It appears that in recent weeks the level of supposed sickness at Sydney Airport has reached levels far above historic levels. I must stress, however, that this has not been brought about, on all available evidence, by controllers being required to work excessive overtime. They are working to a level of overtime which has been determined by the Industrial Relations Commission as being reasonable, which equates to one extra shift of seven hours per fortnight. That is the only amount of overtime that any air traffic controller is being required to work. I think we would all agree that this is hardly an excessive level of hours for people to work, even given that controllers have a stressful occupation.

For its part the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has now reinstituted a requirement for doctors' certificates to be produced by controllers taking sick leave. Since the specific bans of the air traffic controllers were lifted a couple of weeks ago, there has been substantial work on items agreed to be examined, including a review of staffing levels. Award restructuring is being progressed. The main area of non-agreement at this stage relates to shift rostering but this is being discussed by the parties.

In the Government's view, therefore, there is no need for industrial action because all of the concerns of the air traffic controllers are being addressed and award restructuring is being rapidly developed so as to enable the controllers to be a special case, within the meaning of that term of art, and so get pay rises ahead of most other workers.

Finally, the CAA also held discussions with the union on Tuesday, which I am told were quite productive, and further discussions are being held today concerning the difficulties experienced on Friday and steps that may be taken to prevent any recurrence. The Authority will also be instituting a number of specific measures to ensure greater staff availability and maintenance of operations. In the circumstances we believe that the Civil Aviation Authority is doing everything it can to ensure that services will be maintained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Coulter asked me a question on the London dumping convention. I undertook to get some further information and I have been able to do that. I seek leave to have that information incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: The London Dumping Convention (LDC) is an international convention on the prevention of marine pollution by dumping of wastes and other matter. It was drafted in 1973 and its adoption by a large number of maritime nations was a landmark in international environmental responsibility. To achieve acceptance it was necessary to define the scope of the convention closely.

The convention refers to any deliberate disposal at sea of wastes or other substances carried by ships, aircraft or other man-made structures at sea for the purpose of disposal. It does not apply to other discharges (such as ``operating discharges'') from ships, to discharges from structures (such as jetties or pipelines which extend from the land) which are not ``at sea'' and does not apply to internal waters of states.

These matters of definition are made clear by the international legal authority on marine pollution, Dr G. J. Timagenis, who also describes article 1 of the convention as ``of preambular character'' and states, ``despite certain wider expressions in article 1, the main object of the convention is the prevention of marine pollution from dumping at sea.''

Jurisdiction over the waters of Spencer Gulf rests with South Australia. On the basis of the South Australian constating instruments, which are letters patent of 1836, these are ``internal waters'' of South Australia and are not subject to the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act, or to the LDC. The limits of South Australia were determined in this respect by the majority of the High Court of Australia, in A Raptis and Son v South Australia (1977) 138CLR346.

The agreement between Mr Fraser and Mr Tonkin referred to ``marine pollution through dumping'' in the 3-mile territorial sea, and beyond the outer limit of the 3-mile territorial sea, and to implementing the provisions of the dumping convention. As I stated in the Senate yesterday, legislation regarding marine pollution through dumping was passed by South Australia and received assent in May 1984. It has not been proclaimed.

But Senator Coulter is wrong if he is suggesting that South Australia stated that Commonwealth legislation would apply in the 3-mile zone, in regards to land based marine pollution. In Mr Tonkin's letter to Mr Fraser of 7 May 1980 he stated quite clearly in reference to land based marine pollution: ``State legislation will control pollutant discharges within the 3-mile limit.''
The waters of Spencer Gulf, being internal waters of the State of South Australia, are neither within nor beyond the outer limit of the 3-mile territorial sea.

Even if Spencer Gulf was subject to the agreement, the land-based discharges which featured in Senator Coulter's original question (part 3) would not have been brought within the Commonwealth's reach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. An article appears in today's Sydney Morning Herald under the heading `New boy puts the boot in', which relates to the maiden speech given by Senator Faulkner on Monday. The article says in part, in relation to Senator Faulkner's comments:

SPEECH.PARA: He-
that is, Senator Faulkner-

chose to ignore the Senate Bible, J. R. Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, which says it is the custom for new senators' speeches not be `unduly provocative' and for the Senator to be heard without interjection or interruption.
The article goes on to mention certain remarks had been made by Senator Faulkner and then says:
. . . a total of 11 Opposition senators rose and left, leaving NSW Liberal Senator Chris Puplick to reflect on Senator Faulkner's speech alone.
The article concludes:
An unbowed Senator Faulkner said he couldn't care less about tradition. He added that Senator Puplick probably remained because he agreed with what he was saying.

I want to make a comment about that. Firstly, it is correct that Opposition senators left and I remained alone in the chamber. I did so because I was the shadow Minister on duty. It was my responsibility to keep the House as far as the Opposition side was concerned. I did so after having been consulted by a number of my colleagues who believed that Senator Faulkner's speech had transgressed the accepted conventions and traditions of this place and were minded to raise with the President a point of order on that particular matter, thereby interrupting Senator Faulkner during the course of his maiden speech. I advised them that I thought that that was not appropriate despite what they might regard as provocation and that the correct thing to do was for them to leave the chamber rather than remain here. I asked those Opposition senators who were in the chamber who had that view to leave the chamber. I asked the whips to leave the chamber. I asked that a message be sent via our whip's office to senators who were on their way to the chamber to pay Senator Faulkner the courtesy of listening to his maiden speech indicating that they should not in fact come into the chamber.

I believe that that was the correct way to proceed. If I had not proceeded in that fashion, we certainly would have taken a point of order about the nature of the maiden speech. To imply, even by way of a presumed tongue in cheek comment, that I in any way agreed with what Senator Faulkner was saying is, of course, incorrect. I do not have any comment to make about what Senator Faulkner may or may not believe about tradition. That is entirely a matter for him. I make the point that this was a question which reflected not only on simply the observation of a technical tradition but also on one's attitude towards the personal courtesies which are extended or not extended in this place in relation to maiden speeches and to other activities which we undertake. We now have an idea of Senator Faulkner's views on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You are going beyond the bounds of a personal explanation.

—I hope he will be courteous enough in relation to my own views on this particular matter to properly reflect not on any comment about my agreement or disagreement with what he was saying but the situation which I have put in relation to the management of the House from the Opposition's point of view under those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement on a matter referred to the Privileges Committee by the Senate on 8 December 1988 and relating to the drugs in sport inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 December, following the determination of the President that a matter of privilege raised on behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts by the Chairman, Senator Black, should have precedence and the Senate's decision to refer the matter immediately to the Privileges Committee, the Committee received the following reference:

SPEECH.PARA: whether there was any improper interference with a witness who gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in relation to that Committee's inquiry into the use of drugs in sport.

Because of the importance of the issues raised for the operations of all Senate Committees, the Privileges Committee will be presenting a full report in relation to its reference as soon as possible after the Senate resumes this month. In fairness to the persons affected by the reference, however, the Committee considered it appropriate to advise the Senate of its findings as soon as possible.

Briefly, after considering both written and oral evidence, the Committee has found that Mr Greg Blood's action in asking Ms Sue Howland to leave his house on the day after she gave evidence to the Committee was not taken in consequence of her appearance before the Standing Committee. The Committee has also found that Mr Blood did not try to prevent Ms Howland's giving evidence, or producing a document, before the Standing Committee. Thus, the Committee has concluded that no contempt of the Senate has been committed by Mr Blood, in that he did not improperly interfere with, or inflict a penalty or injury upon, Ms Howland on account of evidence she gave before the Standing Committee in relation to its inquiry into the use of drugs in sport.

As indicated earlier, the Committee will give its reasons for its findings in a report canvassing issues of significance to the Senate and its committees. The Committee will also table the Hansard report of its first public hearings held pursuant to the Privilege resolutions of 25 February 1988. The Committee also wishes to emphasise at this early stage that it regards Ms Howland's notification to the Standing Committee of the events which transpired after her giving evidence to the Standing Committee, and that Committee's report to the Senate as entirely appropriate, and indeed necessary, for the proper functioning of Senate committees. The Committee considers that the resolution of the matters before it was due in no small measure to the helpfulness and cooperation both of Ms Howland and of Mr Blood, who was accompanied by his legal adviser at the hearings held last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
