TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on Defence industry and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
MINISTERIAL STATEMENT
ON
DEFENCE INDUSTRY
BY THE
MINISTER FOR DEFENCE
THE HON. KIM C. BEAZLEY MP
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
Madam Speaker,
This statement marks a new chapter in Defence's relationship with Australian industry.
The Defence policies adopted by the Hawke Government over the past six years have transformed our Defence strategy and reshaped the Australian Defence Force.

Defence self-reliance is inextricably linked to our industrial capacity. The capacity of our industrial base to support our Defence effort is as important to self-reliance as a Defence Force structure tailored to our strategic environment.

Our policies have played a cardinal role in overhauling industries vital to our Defence. These embrace Electronics, Aerospace, Ship Building and Ship Repair, Heavy and General Engineering, and Munitions.

These are essential elements of an industrial base to serve our Defence needs. They are equally essential for the type of commercial industry structure this Government has sought to encourage to serve Australia into the next century: A structure that is global in outlook, export oriented, and internationally competitive.

I am pleased to announce today another major step in this process with the formal launching of Australian Defence Industries. ADI has taken over the major Defence Industry facilities still remaining in Government ownership. These establishments were previously controlled by the office of Defence production within my department.

Australian Defence Industries, a Government-owned corporation, will operate on a commercial basis. ADI will have an annual turnover of $400 million. It will commence as the largest single supplier of Defence equipment and services.

Instead of 11 independently-operating Government establishments, we now have a single company with four operating divisions-Naval Engineering (principally the Garden Island Dockyard), Ammunition and Missiles, Weapons and Engineering, and Military Clothing. We have been fortunate to obtain the services of the former secretary of my department, Mr Alan Woods, as chairman of the new company.
The launching of Australian Defence Industries completes the process we began in 1984, when we abolished the Department of Defence Support, which had been created by our coalition predecessors.

By 1984 Defence Support had become one of the largest Public Service Departments, with a staff exceeding 15,000, a total outlay of $598 million, of which only $242 million was recovered from sales to customers.
Madam Speaker, since that decision in 1984, this Government has embarked on a quiet revolution in Australian Defence Industry.

We have undertaken a massive program of restructuring, rationalisation and commercialisation. We have closed or are closing two Government-owned Defence factories, The Albion Explosives Factory and the Explosives Factory Maribyrnong.

We sold the Williamstown Naval Dockyard in Victoria and the Aircraft Workshop in South Australia. We converted the former Government aircraft factories at Fisherman's Bend and Avalon into a Government-owned enterprise, Aerospace Technologies of Australia, run strictly on business lines.

In the last five years the annual cost to the taxpayer of subsidies to our Government-owned Defence Factories has been cut by around $250 million. That is not a one-off saving. It is a permanent reduction in Defence outlays each year.

With the launching of Australian Defence Industries we have taken a further significant step away from the bureaucracy and politics that have bedevilled these Defence establishments for so many years.
At the same time, the transformation has given us the opportunity to restructure awards and employment levels.

Overall, our actions have reduced the number of employees in dedicated Defence manufacturing facilities from more than 15,000 to 6,800 employees. This has resulted in a saving of $92 million in the wages bill alone.

Another round of staff reductions at ADI commencing earlier this year involved about 1300 positions. ADI's Head Office in Canberra now has just 35 people. Just four years ago the comparable number was 1,000.
There will be further major savings, about $8 million a year, with the decision to close the explosives factory at Maribyrnong over the next 18 months or so.
I must emphasise, however, that this has not been a negative exercise; a ``slash and burn'' pursuit of efficiency no matter what the consequences.
Our aim has been to make Government factories and dockyards not just competitive, but an integral part of Australian industry.
These factories served us well in earlier times. Australia has been in the munitions business for more than 100 years. By the end of WW1 we had five Government-owned Defence factories.
During WW2, by mobilising Australian industry around the core of Government-owned factories, we achieved genuinely outstanding results in defence production.

In April 1940 Australia sent Britain 30,000 rifles. Within 14 months we had also sent 100 million rounds of small arms ammunition. To put this in perspective, British industry in 1940 was able to produce only 81,000 rifles; with some troops being forced to drill with dummy weapons.

Other Australian Defence production establishments responded with similarly spectacular increases in production. During the war, no fewer than 10 shipyards built three Destroyers, 12 Frigates and 60 Corvettes.

Successive conservative governments after WW2 failed to recognise and act on the fundamental change in our strategic circumstances. They maintained massive excess capacity in progressively more obsolete capabilities. As a result the defence industry facilities inherited by this government were in poor shape. They suffered from low morale, chronic undercapitalisation, excess capacity and totally unsatisfactory industrial relations.

Madam Speaker, the Hawke Government has finally swept away the long-held notion that industry capabilities needed for defence purposes must be carefully identified, and then preserved at public expense. That is not the way to go in today's environment. In fact, it is self-defeating.
Our defence industry policy has clear objectives which were spelt out in the 1987 Defence White Paper.

That document pointed out that while a substantial commercial workload can provide a base from which to bid for defence orders, the inverse is rarely true. The peacetime requirements of the Australian Defence Force are not usually capable of providing a viable long-term baseload for individual firms or industry sectors.

An insistence on maintaining specific defence industry capabilities leads to a freezing of technology and, ultimately, to a decline in capability. Defence, like the economy at large, is best served by an industry structure that can hold its own in the world market, capable of recognising opportunities and seizing them.

We have not abandoned the idea of nurturing particular capabilities in special circumstances. But Government support of that kind is no longer an easy way out for firms unable to compete in the commercial arena.

This contribution to the government's micro-reform agenda was possible because, as my colleague the Treasurer puts it, we tackled the big picture first. We recognised that a more responsive financial sector was a prerequisite for change.

By floating the dollar, relaxing exchange controls, and freeing up the banks we gave the economy access to goods and services at world prices. We have signalled that the days of Australia's inward-looking, protectionist stance have gone for good.

Industry has been a direct beneficiary of the accord process with the ACTU. The government has succeeded in maintaining a wages policy under which real unit labour costs have fallen by about ten percent in the past five years.

That restraint will continue under the arrangements announced by the Treasurer on April 12. The wages-tax agreement contained in that statement will further consolidate the linkage between productivity and wages and, between wages restraint and the growth of employment.

The Government is overseeing a sweeping overhaul of the industrial award system, the most momentous change in 80 years in the sphere of industrial relations. The overhaul of occupational classifications and skill categorisations promises immense benefits to both employers and employees. This will allow Australians to adapt more easily to changing technologies.

These initiatives are reshaping industrial practices so that industry can adjust to a more competitive environment. In defence our principle instrument for change has been a greatly expanded capital procurement program. Fourteen years ago the capital program represented about 18 per cent of defence outlays. Today the equivalent figure is around 30 per cent. We intend to keep it at that level.

When this Government took office the average level of local content in new equipment acquisitions was about 30 per cent. Now it has reached 59 per cent. In the 1990's we estimate that it will reach an average of 70% as projects such as the new submarine and the Anzac frigate project gather pace.

Our objective is to foster Australian prime contractors able to achieve high levels of local content without subsidies. The shipbuilding, ship repair and engineering industries exemplify this approach.
The submarine project costing nearly $4 billion and the ANZAC Frigate project costing about $5 billion have prompted a major restructuring of the Australian shipbuilding and ship repair industries.

This restructuring started with the sale to the private sector of the former Williamstown Naval Dockyard in Melbourne. Employment in the dockyard has reduced from 2,200 to 750 and the productivity of the overall organisation has increased at least fourfold. The Landmark Industrial Award at the dockyard has fundamentally changed the way people look at their jobs. People are encouraged to develop their skills in order to become an integral part of a multiskilled workforce.
Some 23 unions have been reduced to three. All this has occurred in a dockyard once notorious for inefficiency.
Last Friday Williamstown Dockyard launched, three months ahead of schedule, the Frigate FFG 05, the first warship launched in this country in nearly twenty years.
Madam Speaker, under this Government, Australia is now back in the business of naval warship building.
The owner, Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd, (AMECON), is tendering the German Meko design for the ANZAC ships, in conjunction with Cable Price Downer, a New Zealand engineering firm.

The decision to close Cockatoo Island Dockyard and the Wran Government's decision to close the Newcastle State Dockyard cleared the way for the emergence of a second bidder for the ANZAC Frigate contract.

Australian Warships Systems, comprising TNT, Carrington Slipways, AWA and the New Zealand Engineering Firm, McConnell Dowell, has teamed with the Dutch company, Royal Schelde, and has proposed the Dutch M class design.

Another important development has been our decision to relocate half the fleet to Western Australia over the next ten years. To accommodate that move, the Naval base HMAS Stirling is being expanded at a cost of more than $300 million.

We now envisage two centres of ship repair located near the main naval bases on either side of the continent. In Western Australia the facility is to be established entirely in the private sector with investment in the first stage totalling more than $20 million. A shiplift has been built and the first docking of an Oberon submarine has been completed. The destroyer escort, HMAS Swan, is currently undergoing refit at the facility.

Garden Island Dockyard will remain the East Coast Ship Repair Centre and will remain in Government ownership as part of ADI. It will increasingly have to look to the commercial market for part of its workload.

The Hawke Government has also initiated important changes in the Aerospace Industry. This sector developed its wartime skills in areas such as missiles and aircraft. The IKARA missile and the Nomad aircraft were at world standard in their day. However as time passed the industry lagged, particularly in management, finance and marketing.

As I mentioned earlier, the Aviation and Aerospace activities of the former Government aircraft factories have now been combined in a new company, Aerospace Technologies of Australia, (ASTA), established by legislation of this Parliament.

ASTA is an independent, fully commercial company, with a board of directors experienced in business and keen to see the company expand on a profitable basis, both in Australia and International markets. It has made substantial progress in this direction already.

ASTA's most recent success is a contract from Boeing to manufacture the composite rudder system for its 757 aircraft. This is the firm's third major contract with Boeing and has a potential value around $125 million. In addition, the company has signed an agreement with the Sikorsky company to take over from Hawker de Havilland as the prime local contractor for the assembly and test program of the navy's eight second phase Seahawk helicopters.

I am pleased to be able to advise the House that the ASTA board is now exploring the sale of some equity in the company. Companies with key technologies, or access to markets, may be invited to make strategic investments in relevant parts of ASTA and their facilities. The Government believes that this will maximise returns to the taxpayers of Australia as well as enhancing aerospace industry's prospects.

My department has put its relationship with the rest of the aerospace industry on a normal commercial footing. The private sector counterpart to ASTA is Hawker de Havilland which took over the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation.

Hawker's have restructured substantially and have been winning defence and commercial work. They recently signed a commercial development contract with McDonnell Douglas to design a new light helicopter which has already achieved preliminary sales.

This industry structure is based on two major companies as prime contractors associated with specialist sub-contractors. It offers the best compromise between competition and economies of scale and bodes well for the future.

The Defence program has also stimulated change in the electronics and systems industry, which in a strategic sense, probably has become the industry of greatest importance to the defence effort. In the last three years the submarine and frigate projects have generated major opportunities in the electronics sector. Most of the world's leading companies in this field now take a more active interest in Australia and are doing business with Australian companies.

As with shipbuilding and aerospace, local companies are starting to act as prime contractors and linking with overseas firms to tap their technologies and access to markets. They are starting to acquire the necessary technical, financial and managerial expertise to compete effectively.

There is no doubt that big defence projects have attracted into Australia, technologies and investment in this industry that would not be here otherwise. Some are already looking actively for civil sector work to maintain Australian operations for the long term.

To an important degree, the increasing sophistication of some sections of Australia's electronics industry has been driven by defence-based research. Perhaps the outstanding example is our remarkable Jindalee over-the-horizon radar system, which will give our forces a surveillance reach of some 3,000 kilometres.

Over a decade of research and trials by the defence science and technology organisation has established the principles used in the system and the hardware and software elements have been demonstrated experimentally, Jindalee, as an operational system, will enter service in the mid-1990's.
Australian companies have been involved throughout this process, and will be involved more and more as the operational phase progresses, with up to three radar systems being envisaged.
I cannot stress too strongly that my aims for industry development, as Minister for Defence, complement those of my colleague, Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.
Defence has also made a significant contribution to the Government's commitment to help Australian firms to tap export markets.

The defence offsets program has been progressively refined and broadened over the years, and it has done much to encourage long-term arrangements between overseas and Australian suppliers. The offsets program is now starting to run down because of the success of our overall efforts to encourage local industry involvement.

Madam Speaker, Australian content in the submarine contract was 65 percent. With the Anzac ships the Australian and New Zealand content should reach 70 percent and, in fact, with offsets work added, could reach 80 percent.
We have reached the point where Australian firms are able and more than ready to take on the role of prime contractor for major defence programs.
Obviously this means a progressively lower foreign content in such programs and a commensurate decline in new offsets obligations.

Nevertheless, the program continues to provide valuable assistance for Australian companies. Last financial year, new offsets obligations were a relatively modest $25 million. But past obligations discharged in that same period, for offsets and Australian industry participation programs, totalled more than $120 million.

Three weeks ago, defence signed deeds of agreement with four big overseas suppliers of high technology defence equipment for the accumulation of defence offsets credit. These deeds of agreement will allow the companies to undertake long-term programs with local companies to help the Australian partners meet our own future needs and aim at export markets. The companies concerned already have begun negotiations that could lead to Australian industry involvement in joint development, production and export sales.
The Government has also fostered the development of a number of specialised technologies to meet particular Australian requirements.
Last year we spent $12 million to develop generic technologies and a further $27 million to facilitate Australian industry involvement in our capital equipment projects.

In June 1987 I announced an extensive revision and streamlining of the regulations governing exports of defence-type goods. This is a fairly specialised export area but it has the capacity to foster and maintain specialist skills and reduce the cost of such goods on the Australian market. Last year we received 400 applications for the export of defence goods, of which only 2% were declined.

Australia is critically dependent on access to advanced western military technology if it is to realise its goal of self reliant defence, and we are just as critically dependent on access to advanced western commercial technology if the Government's objectives of more internationally competitive, outward-looking Australian industry are to be achieved.

Australia therefore adheres to guidelines developed by the main NATO countries and Japan for the export of advanced commercial technology with dual civil and military applications. Full observance of these guidelines is vital in maintaining this access.

Last month we joined the Co-ordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, (COCOM), which administers these arrangements. I am confident that this will both facilitate advanced technology transfer into Australia, and help increase exports from Australia.

Madam Speaker, under the Hawke Government defence self-reliance is no longer a mirage, but a realisable goal. Our policy of self reliance has two central pillars. The first pillar is a clear definition of our primary strategic environment, which in turn dictates a force structure matching our unique geographic circumstances.
The second pillar is a competitive, technologically proficient, and adaptable industry base, able to supply and support the changing requirements of our defence force.

Madam Speaker, the Government believes its redirection of our defence industry in recent years has already produced significant long term benefits for Australia. I am confident that Australian industry increasingly sees our defence policies in the same light.

DEBATE.TITLE: PERSONNEL WASTAGE IN THE DEFENCE FORCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force, and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
MINISTERIAL STATEMENT IN RESPONSE TO THE `PERSONNEL WASTAGE IN THE DEFENCE FORCE', REPORT OF 10 NOVEMBER 1988 BY THE DEFENCE SUB-COMMITTEE OF THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE
BY
THE HON DAVID SIMMONS MP
MINISTER FOR DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL
Introduction

I present the Government's response to the report, `Personnel Wastage in the Defence Force', prepared by the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and tabled in the Parliament on 10 November 1988.

The Committee sought to analyse the extent and magnitude of the personnel wastage problems in the Australian Defence Force, and its effect on the ADF's capability. The Report offered a series of recommendations which the Committee believed would aid in the retention of personnel in the ADF.

On behalf of the Government I thank the members of the Committee for the time and energy they spent in preparing this report, and for their demonstrated concern for the well-being of the Australian Defence Force and for the defence of this nation.

As my predecessor Mrs Kelly said to the Committee in August last year, the profession of arms is a unique occupation. It requires people with special skills and a high level of commitment to their work and to their nation. I am pleased to have this opportunity to give due recognition to those who contribute so much to Australia's defence.

The men and women of our Navy, Army and Air Force and their families are a very important part of our Australian community. They are justly proud of their Service and of their own individual achievements. It is a pride in which we can all share.
Last year, during the Bicentennial celebrations, millions of Australians did share that pride, and paid tribute to that skill and commitment during the Naval Salute, the Army Tattoo and the Air Show.

But recognition of the Defence Force is not something that should be confined to such occasions, or remembered only on Anzac Day. While it may not always be so visible, that skill and commitment continues ever day at hundreds of locations both in Australia and overseas. The Government acknowledges and fully supports that commitment.

Two other important groups also need to be recognised. Firstly, the spouses and children of members of the Defence Force. While they provide invaluable personal support, the inescapable reality of Service life means that these families must endure considerable disruption and separation. This Government has been the first to truly recognise and act on the problems of Services families.

The second group which needs to be recognised is the civilian element of Defence. The provision of Australia's defence is a partnership to which both the Defence Force and the Department of Defence make a vital contribution. Many thousands in the Department work directly for and in support of the Services, many others, such as those in Defence Science have, as their primary and predominant task, the support of the Defence Force.

This Government's strong and continuing support for the Defence Force is a matter of public record. Despite the present era of economic constraint and reducing public sector expenditures, the real level of Defence funding has been maintained. The 1987 Defence White Paper has provided a logical and coherent basis for force development and exercise planning. A wide range of new high technology equipment has been provided or is on order. Later this year, Exercise Kangaroo 89 will provide the Defence Force with a great opportunity to test its skills and capabilities right across the northern part of the continent.
Personnel Wastage

The present levels of personnel wastage from the Defence Force is an issue of very great importance and concern. The Government has not sought to deny this fact, nor to disguise, in any way, the extent of the problem. We have been most active in taking effective measures to deal with this problem.

We have reviewed our manpower statistics so that the true extent of the wastage problem, and its impact on specific employment categories can be assessed accurately. This analysis demonstrated that the primary concern with separations is not necessarily the overall numbers leaving, but rather the impact on some specific employment categories.
We have analysed the reasons for the current high wastage rates. The major conclusion of that analysis is that there is no one cause for increased wastage and thus there is no one simple answer.

The public image of the Defence Force, the challenge of peace-time service, job satisfaction, Service-civilian relationship, conditions of service, housing, the needs and interests of spouses and families, education, postings policy, personnel management, competition from the wider economy, the simple desire to do something different. These issues and more are all involved in the wastage equation.
All this analysis was made available to the Committee by the Defence Organization in three agreed and detailed and public submissions.

The Committees's deliberations and their report took place within the context of a continuing program of Government action to both address the wastage problem, and more broadly, to improve the conditions and personnel management of the Defence Force. Many of the Committee's recommendations had already been implemented or were in train before the Committee's report was tabled. Action has continued during the period in which we have been analysing the Committee's report.
As part of our overall Defence Force personnel policy we have been actively seeking better personnel management practices, and an ongoing improvement in conditions of service.

We have introduced some creative new schemes that go beyond what the Committee's report recommends. We have continued to give priority to the areas we recognized as crucial before we had the benefit of this Report. We have, I believe, a proven record of performance across the full range of Service personnel issues, including
successful support for substantial increases in many key general and specialist allowances;
the provision of financial, educational and support arrangements for Service families;
a commitment of $750m to address the long neglect of Service housing, with more than $200M spent in the last two years; and
recognition of the important area of morale and job satisfaction through more responsive career management, and increased devolution of authority and responsibility.

These much needed improvements were introduced as part of an overall personnel management strategy. They were introduced in advance of the Committee's report. Where these improvements also overcome a perceived cause of wastage, we know we are on the right track.

The Committee's Report, like any report to Government, has the status of advice, not policy. I am happy to say, however, that much of what this Report recommends has been implemented, is in the process of being implemented, or will be.
A detailed response to each of the Committee's recommendations has been finalized, and I will table it at the completion of this Statement.

In this Statement, I want to go beyond an examination of the Committee's recommendations. I intend to place those recommendations within the broader scope of the Government's initiatives on Defence Force personnel policy.
There is one very important difference between the Government's personnel policy strategy and the terms of reference that constrained the Committee's Report.
As the Chairman said in his tabling speech:

If people are asked what is wrong with their organization and why they are leaving it, then that is precisely the kind of information they will provide; they are unlikely to say much about the positive aspects of their employment.
ADF personnel policy, however, cannot choose to ignore the positive aspects of ADF employment. Indeed, personnel policy cannot be run by wastage.

In that regard the Parliamentary Report is not, and cannot be, the engine for reform in ADF employment and family support. Reform was already in progress at the time the Committee's Report was in preparation, and has continued since.

The Committee's Report has provided a valuable focus for discussion; and the spirit of their recommendations fits in very well with what we have been doing. However, I am sure that no member of the Committee would want to see their Report taken as the outer limit of what the Government might do to improve retention.

In fact, the Government's initiatives in the area of Defence Force personnel policy do go beyond the scope of the Committee's report. Our initiatives take up the Committee's call for awareness, concern and action. They involve some major changes.
Review of DFRDB

Today I announced that there will be a complete review of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme (DFRDB). The Chiefs of Staff Committee has advised me that the DFRDB scheme no longer meets Service objectives, nor provides the right incentives to those who choose to make the profession of arms their lifetime career. The Committee has recommended that the scheme be reviewed.
The Government concurs.

There are effectively three groups of ADF personnel. There are those who join up for a short period, often to learn a skill or a trade, who serve out their period of engagement, and who leave to join the civilian workforce.
There are those who, encouraged by the structure of the DFRDB scheme, serve for twenty years in the ADF, and, in their late thirties or early forties, take their benefit and enter on a second career.
The third group consists of those who serve as members of the ADF until retirement, making the Service their life's work.
The DFRDB scheme works well for the second and third groups at the expense of the first.

While fitness and strength are still very important attributes, the Defence Force is coming to rely more and more on skills and technology. Therefore, it is time for us to question seriously whether twenty years is still the optimum period of military service for all groups in the Defence Force.

The DFRDB scheme was established in 1972 with the aim of providing a scheme which-would be easily understood by its membership; would be simple to administer; and would provide retirement benefits suitable for the special requirements of its members on re-settlement into civilian life. The scheme is now failing to meet at least the last of these objectives.

All public sector superannuation schemes, including DFRDB, are required to conform to the Government's occupational superannuation standards. With regard to the DFRDB scheme, the only significant change which may affect benefits relates to the reasonable benefit limits which are to be set by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. These limits relate to the size of lump sums and pensions on retirement, relative to the level of salary at retirement. While these limits are yet to be set for the DFRDB scheme, they are likely to affect only a few very senior officers. I will make an announcement on the effect of the reasonable benefits limits when they are decided.
The Committee said that any review of the DFRDB scheme must be on the basis of no detriment to current contributors. I agree.

Let me be quite clear about this. Subject to the effect of the superannuation standards I have just mentioned, the Government gives an ironclad guarantee to those presently in service that the benefits of the existing DFRDB scheme for which they are contributing will remain available to be taken up when they leave the Services.
Some months ago my predecessor announced a limited examination of dependants and invalidity benefits under the DFRDB scheme. That examination will be completed.

In that respect, it has been of much concern to the Government that orphans' benefits under the DFRDB scheme are considerably less than under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. I am pleased to announce that from the first pension pay day in July, orphan benefits will increase by some $4300 per annum. Full details of this interim adjustment will be announced separately.
A small board of expert people will be appointed to review the DFRDB scheme and to recommend what changes should be made to it. The ADF will be represented on the review board.

Complete details of the terms of reference for the full review of the DFRDB scheme, and the composition of the board will be announced shortly. There will be opportunities for service personnel to make submissions.

The terms of reference for the review board will include a requirement to investigate and report on the feasibility of providing serving members with the option of transferring to any new scheme, if they so wish. There will be absolutely no compulsion for any serving members to do so, if they would prefer not to.

The review of the DFRDB scheme will also be, in effect, a review of the personnel needs of the ADF into the nineties and beyond. The DFRDB scheme must provide ADF personnel with fair recompense for their service, but must also be a major structural element in the pattern of ADF employment.

The great challenge for Service personnel management into the future will be to make the ADF a competitive and attractive employer of the specialists whose skills our re-equipment program and the modernization of our force structure requires.
The Committee rejected the Department of Defence's analysis that while wastage was of major concern, it was of serious concern only in some specific specialist areas.

Without reopening this debate, I think it is important to realise that in future the following is a likely scenario: As Australian industry restructures and develops, there will be a shortfall in skilled trades, engineers, project managers and executives until the Government's greatly accelerated tertiary training effort can take up the slack. Skilled members of the Defence Force will be targeted to fill such shortfalls.
This case is one where, I suggest, a personnel policy that allowed itself to be directed by wastage would be off the track.
The DFRDB review will be predicated on the future manpower needs of the ADF, and on the retirement incomes policy that this Government has put in place throughout the workforce.
The ADF and Community Standards
The Government bases its ADF personnel strategy on two fundamentals. The first is the recognition that the profession of arms is a unique profession, with unique traditions, duties and skills.

The second is that the Defence community, while it is unique, is also part of the Australian community. ADF personnel and their families live much of their lives just as all the rest of us do. They are affected by the same rules and regulations, they are influenced by the same social dynamics, they feel the same aspirations as the rest of the Australian community.
And that society is changing. It is from a changing society that the ADF has to recruit, and in a changing society that the ADF has to retain, its personnel.
We cannot afford to hanker after the values and work practices of the 1950s. We live and work in the late 80s, and the ADF must accommodate itself more to that reality.

It is a reality that includes increasing job mobility, especially by younger members of the work force. It includes the legitimate and rising expectations of women for education, for their own careers, for child care. It includes all the legitimate expectations that members of the Defence Force share with every other Australian-expectations like good quality housing and educational opportunities for their children.
To ignore wider social movements in a serious discussion about Service personnel policy is to duck the issues.

It is also ducking the issues to pretend that the two fundamentals on which our personnel strategy is based are always harmonious, and this is the one area in which I and the Government are strongly at odds with the recommendations of the Cross Committee.
Review of ADF Pay

Recommendation 21 of the Report asks the Minister to direct the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal to ``undertake a complete job analysis and job evaluation review of the ADF, exclusive of National Wage Guidelines, for the purpose of establishing wage levels which are based on the recognition of the members of the profession of arms as a distinctive institution.''
There are two reasons why this recommendation is unacceptable.

First, it attacks the independence of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. The Tribunal is established by legislation to be an independent body which reviews Defence Force pay and allowance claims on their merits. The Tribunal is not subject to Government direction, nor should it be.

The only limitation placed on the Tribunal is the requirement that it should have regard to principles determined by the Industrial Relations Commission. These principles include the National Wage Guidelines.

The second reason the recommendation is unacceptable is the principle that the National Wage Guidelines apply to all Australian employees. In this sense, the notion of Service personnel as members of the Australian community overrides their membership of a unique profession.
While the Government does not accept this particular recommendation, we do believe that a full pay review should be undertaken-a review within the Guidelines.

The current structural efficiency principle is designed to reward enterprises that improve efficiency and provide more varied and fulfilling jobs. The ADF has commenced a pay review under this principle.

This review will address the compression of salaries of senior officers as recommended by the Committee. The review will incorporate the outcome of the current structural review of higher ADF staff arrangements being undertaken by Major General Sanderson.

An important additional outcome of this aspect of the case should be more fulfilling jobs for those posted to Canberra. This will address the perceived dissatisfaction in the middle levels of the ADF towards Canberra postings-a topic much discussed in the Committee's Report.

The ADF pay case will also seek pay adjustments based on structural changes and efficiency measures introduced across the whole ADF. The case will therefore encompass the pay of all ranks in the ADF. The aim is to develop the case for submission to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal later in 1989.

A leaner, more efficient organization uses every resource in a more effective way. And people are our best resource. If they feel they have little effective input into the Defence process, are just shuffling papers, or duplicating someone else's job, then dissatisfaction and disillusion are inevitable. The current structural review of higher Defence Force staff arrangements is directed towards rectifying such problems.
Civilianization
The Government intends to continue our policy of civilianization within Defence.

I am aware that the Committee had some difficulty with this concept. Let me reassure them, and this House, that civilianization does not, and will not be allowed to degrade combat capability or the operational or manning flexibility of the Defence Force.

The aim of civilianization is not to convert positions from military to civilian for its own sake, or for reasons solely of peacetime cost-effectiveness. Rather the aim is to ensure that our military/civilian balance is the one which maximises the combat potential of the ADF. Used this way, civilianization releases Service professionals from tasks which do not require specific military skills and puts them in field positions where these skills are needed. Civilianization thus increases the ``teeth to tail'' ratio across the whole of the Defence Force.
Conditions of Service and Service Families
Let me turn now to the other two major areas: the Service family, and conditions of Service.
I plan to take these together, because they are by nature related.
Conditions of service are the elements of ADF remuneration that recognise, in a tangible way, that the profession of arms is a unique profession.

Specialist allowances recognise special skills, and other allowances make up for disadvantages or difficulties inherent in Service life, most of them clustered around the operational need for postings.

Postings impact very much indeed on Service families. The dissatisfactions identified in this area by the Committee relate very closely to the effect of mobility. Thus, education, housing and disturbance and rental allowances are all involved here.
Under this Government, the Service family has become, for the first time, a recognised entity with its own special needs, pressures and difficulties.

I believe that the Government, and in particular my predecessor, Mrs Kelly can be very proud of what has been done. I do not have the leisure to go through what we have achieved today, but Mrs Kelly has already reported to this House on the implementation of the recommendations of the Hamilton Report.
We intend to proceed with an alternative to the Committee's suggestion for a White Paper on Service families. There have been enough reviews and reports. We prefer to keep achieving results.

A Defence families policy plan therefore will be incorporated in a proposed Defence Personnel Policy Plan. That plan will parallel the Defence Five Year Programme. The family policy plan will coordinate family support measures and allow for a systematic periodic review of these arrangements.
Disturbance Allowance
Despite improvements in postings policy, mobility is a fact of Service life, and disturbance an inevitable consequence.

Disturbance Allowance is a difficult allowance to administer. It is meant to cover the range of costs incurred by an individual or family during a removal that is not individually reimbursed. Naturally personal circumstances and expenses of a removal will vary to some degree.

Recognising the mobility of the ADF, we consider the present arrangement for married members is sound whereby the amount of Disturbance Allowance is tiered according to the number of removals experienced.
Present rates effective from 29 November 1988 range from $545 for the first and second removals to $1095 after seven or more removals.

We support the recommendation that there should be a survey of Disturbance Allowance. Defence has set in train a co-operative study with 12 large organisations, both in the public and private sector, which have a requirement to re-locate their employees. On a confidential basis each organisation is being asked to provide details of the degrees of assistance provided to its employees to re-locate. Defence will reciprocate by providing details of its assistance.

It is hoped to have the survey completed by June. The data gained could provide a valuable insight into approaches in other industries and assist in deciding whether present assistance provided to the ADF is appropriate.
Temporary Rental Allowance
The Committee's recommendation on Temporary Rental Allowance reflects a general dissatisfaction with the operation of this form of housing assistance.
The whole arrangement for this allowance requires major improvement. Therefore, the Defence Housing Authority will, on a progressive basis, substitute itself as the lessee of rented housing.

That is to say, when the Defence housing stock is inadequate for the ADF's total needs in a particular area, the DHA will take out leases with private owners and the individual ADF tenants will occupy these houses on the same basis as if the houses were part of the permanent Defence housing stock.
I hope that the DHA also will establish a `market' among ADF members who are home-owners and who are leaving their homes on posting.

The new arrangements when fully in place would remove, for many, the frustrations of house hunting in a new locality and should enable more door-to-door removals with considerable benefits to families who at present must sometimes endure longer than necessary stays in temporary accommodation.
The new arrangements will require a lot of preparatory work by the DHA. However, the DHA will take over the role progressively from 1 November this year.

Initially, the DHA intervention will be to remove some aspects of the present system which the Sub-Committee criticises. Members eligible to rent privately will advise the DHA the details of suitable accommodation that has been found.

The DHA will take out the lease and the member will be required to pay only the normal personal rental contribution. Bonds paid by individuals will be eliminated, and experienced DHA staff will manage repairs and maintenance in consultation with individual landlords.

The important element of choice in rental housing will be preserved. I am aware that some families choose to spend more on housing than the normal level of contribution. Such families will be able to opt out of the new system, while still receiving the same level of housing assistance.
As the DHA operates on a commercial basis, it will charge the Department of Defence a fee for its services.

This Government is proud of its achievements in Defence housing. Progression in new construction and acquisitions has been matched by improvements in the speed and standard of repairs and maintenance. Housing Management Centres are being progressively established by the DHA in all regions of Defence housing concentration. Letters from tenants attest to the high degree of satisfaction with the new standards of repairs and maintenance which these centres are delivering.

Following the report in 1986 of the Task Force that examined Public Service and Defence Force housing, the Government adopted a set of principles to govern the provision of housing for its employees. A key principle is that there should be compensation provided for those who incur a housing disability by virtue of employment.
Rents paid by Defence Force personnel have always been viewed by this Government as conditions of service. There is no intention of changing that policy.
There are two other Defence housing initiatives that I wish to address today.
Renegotiation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (Services)

The first of these concerns the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (Services)-the CSHA(S). Under that agreement, the Commonwealth provides subsidised loans to the States to provide low income housing which in turn is leased to Defence for Service housing. Some 14000 houses presently are provided under that agreement. It is the view of the Government that the agreement has outlived its usefulness. The agreement has failed to provide and maintain housing of the quality or maintenance standard required by Defence Force families.

I am pleased to announce that the Government has agreed to seek the renegotiation of this agreement with the States. This action will greatly assist Service families by allowing for a marked improvement in the standard of Service housing.

Under our proposal, the Defence Housing Authority would take over the ownership of 7000 CSHA(S) houses. These houses could then be upgraded or replaced. The remaining 7000 CSHA(S) houses would be released to the States for public housing purposes over the next five years. These houses would be replaced by new housing provided under the existing Defence housing program.
Post May 1985 Housing Assistance

The second housing initiative concerns the form of housing assistance to be provided for those who enlisted after May 1985 and who are ineligible for the Defence Service Homes Loan of $25,000 over 25 years.

It has been the Government's wish to establish a new form of housing assistance which would help to retain members in service and which would in some way provide a benefit proportional to the service rendered, and to the housing disability encountered by virtue of service.

The new scheme, which I announced today will, as previously, require an initial period of service of six years. Having met that eligibility period, a member who enlists after 14 May 1985 will be entitled to a housing loan of $40,000 with interest being subsidised so that it remains 40% below the market housing loan interest rate. This subsidy will be provided for a period equal to the number of years in excess of six that a member serves.
For example, a 16% market rate would mean a subsidised loan interest rate of 9.6%. Loan subsidies will be available for a maximum of 25 years. The maximum subsidy period is 20 years.

Details of the scheme will be announced separately. Eligibility for the scheme will begin to accrue when members reach their six years service point in May 1991. At that time, Service personnel who enlisted before May 1985, who are still serving and who have not used their Defence Service Homes Loan, will be given a one time option to forgo that entitlement in favour of the new scheme.
Assistance for Defence Force Families

One of the most important products of the Hamilton Report was the establishment of ADFILS-the Australian Defence Family Information Section. By providing Service families with information and the skills to use it, ADFILS' aim is to develop a better community spirit and to enable families to help themselves.

ADFILS staff are presently working on projects such as employment opportunities and work skills for spouses, health care and parenting issues, neighbourhood houses, child care, sole parent support groups, children's educational programs and youth activities.

This self help approach, and local Defence community efforts needs to be recognised and fostered. I therefore have given approval for grants of up to $20,000 per year to be made to each major base for allocation to organizations of Defence families which are formed with the objective of assisting local community welfare. Within guidelines necessary to protect the spending of public moneys, the priorities for use of the funds will be at the discretion of the local organizations.
I believe these grants will encourage innovative ideas on community support and will be a useful mechanism for the Defence community to determine its own highest priority needs.
Family Information Network (FIND)

We have also, since Mrs Kelly reported to Parliament on the implementation of the Hamilton Report, introduced the FIND system, a 008 number that Service personnel and their families can ring, from anywhere in Australia, to get information on their entitlements or about community services in a new posting, or about anything else they need to know.
FIND is convenient and confidential. It answers a need identified in the Hamilton Report for Service families to have a ``clear choice'' to direct their questions.
It is obviously answering a need. The planning estimate was fifty calls a day; but the inquiries have been running at between two and three times that rate.

FIND is a case of appropriate, and relatively new, technology being harnessed to an identified need. 008 telephone services have been gradually increasing in popularity since their introduction, and people are now familiar with the idea. I am delighted that the Defence Force has been able to respond with a creative, simple solution to a time-honoured problem.
Education
The Cross Report identified education as an area of special concern to Defence families. Progress, real progress, is being made in that area.

The Australian Education Council (AEC), the peak group consisting of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the State Ministers for Education and their Directors General, set up a committee to study mobility issues, following the Student Portfolio Scheme trialled by Defence in 1988. Core curriculum issues are being addressed as part of a related review.

These developments are a significant breakthrough. They are a tribute both to the Minister, and to his State colleagues, some of whose predecessors have been more interested in competition and confrontation than in the sensible spirit of cooperation that is now abroad.
I am delighted that the Defence Student Portfolio Scheme has been the catalyst for such a positive development.

The National Consultative Group of Service Spouses also has been asked to advise me on improvements that could be made to the conditions governing extra tuition allowance, which assists with the costs of private tuition when a child changes schools. The take up rate of the allowance has been well below expectation. I believe the scheme could benefit many more families.

All these steps are designed towards assisting Defence families to preserve unity and to minimise education considerations being the cause for family separations. This should be our fundamental principle.

When separation must occur due to stages of education reached, Education Allowance may be available to assist. The take up of this allowance has been improved in the last two years. This reflects changes made to give greater discretion to those administering the scheme. Nonetheless, there remain a few aspects of the scheme that seem to produce unfair outcomes. These aspects are being reviewed.
Other Initiatives

I can also announce today that the Government has decided to implement, in a modified form, the suggestions made by the Committee on postal assistance, and the provision of equipment and supplies so that members of the Defence Force can undertake minor ``do it yourself'' improvements to their married quarters and singles accommodation. In addition, we are at present finalising arrangements for a discount buying scheme for Defence families.
Conclusion

In conclusion, I should like to thank Rear Admiral Alan Beaumont and Mr. Ray Finnegan, who have been tireless in their task of reviewing the recommendations of the Joint Committee, and in coordinating the development of the initiatives which I have announced today.

Their cooperation, and the cooperation that they have obtained from throughout the Personnel areas of the three Services and the Department, demonstrate that Service-civilian relations in Defence often are less competitive and more harmonious than myth has them.

I would like to pay a special tribute to my predecessor Mrs Kelly for her great contribution to the improvement of the conditions of members of the Defence Force and their families. The very widely based and genuine statements of appreciation and regret that greeted her move from this portfolio provide eloquent testimony to that contribution.

I have high hopes for the measures that I have outlined today. They represent another substantial series of steps in the rational, and integrated program of improvements that this Government has provided for ADF personnel and their families. I am confident that these measures also will have a significant effect in turning around the current high levels of wastage.
We have proved that we are about getting results.

Everything that I have detailed today, together with the detailed responses to the Committee's recommendations, is part of a coordinated strategy to improve personnel management in the ADF and to provide better services to Defence families.
With this package of improvements, ADF personnel and their families have further evidence of this Government's clear commitment to them.
I thank the House for its attention; and I table the Government's detailed responses to the recommendations in the Committee's report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the following paper:

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-Joint Committee-Defence Sub-Committee-Report on Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force-Ministerial Statement in response to the Report tabled on 10 November 1988 by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, dated 11 May 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I would think that even the boys and girls in the gallery today would know that we are having trouble keeping the soldiers, sailors and airmen of Australia happy in the defence forces. Certainly an Australian adult would have to be deaf and blind not to know that there are severe problems facing the defence forces. We have had four years of high wastage in the forces which has meant a tremendous drain on the experience levels of the forces. The Cross Committee reported to the Parliament six months ago back in November 1988 and it was a report which pulled no punches. It stated:
It is clear that the present level of wastage is substantially too high and has been for some time. Further there has been a clear and consistent trend towards the situation for several years.

The response to that report throughout the defence forces was one of hope that at last the problems had been recognised in the Parliament of Australia and that the 48 recommendations which were made would go some way towards stopping the situation which had developed. Consequently for the last six months servicemen and women around this country have been holding their breath waiting for the Government's response. So very much has been riding on the Government's response, much more, I think, than the new Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) realises. Our service men and women are fed up with a variety of things that have been happening to them since this Government has come into power, so the Government's response holds the future for many of them. It is really quite surprising how many of them held on waiting just to see what the Government would do. This Government has had a history of broken promises, delays and lack of funding in the defence area. I do not wish to take the time today to detail the quite sad tale of broken promises and reductions in resources and benefits to the forces, but reductions there have been.

As I said earlier, the Government's response has come six months after the Cross report was tabled in the Parliament. It is interesting to note that at the time the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, stated:
I do not intend to make quick decisions in relation to this report.

Never was a truer word spoken. When we look at the Government's response we see that she might as well have made it the day after the report came down. During the six months we have all been waiting to see what the Government was going to do about it, another 3,100 personnel have quit; Qantas Airways Ltd has raised its recruitment age to 45, luring into Qantas those who missed out on the wasteful and badly organised pilots' retention bonus; we have read the internal Royal Australian Air Force report which was critical of the manning deficit in the RAAF and its erosion of Air Force capability; and we have seen a signal from the Army which tells us that it needs reservists to fill the gaps of the 350 officer positions it cannot fill. In the middle of this crisis the Hawke Government appoints a new Minister with not only no experience as a Minister, but also with no shown interest at all in the defence area for the six years that he has been in Parliament. It does make the service people wonder whether the Government cares at all.

Let us look at some of the realities that we are facing as a result of these problems. As I said earlier, the Army has 350 officer vacancies in 1989. Many of those positions will be empty for months. Problems of hand-overs and lack of expertise are being passed on. A total of 170 vacancies are between the lieutenant and major levels, and they cannot be filled, even using reservists on full time duty and temporarily putting senior non-commissioned officers into those positions. The Army is calling for reservists to fill those spaces and yet the provisions of the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme mean that they are not eligible to receive their pensions while they are helping the Army out of its predicament even though, if they went into the Department of Defence as civilians, into private enterprise or any other government department they could receive the pensions to which they have contributed. Although the country needs them and the Army needs them, they have to lose their pensions to which they have contributed for the period in which they come back to the colours.

Let us turn to the Navy. In March 1989 we had 25 per cent of the principal warfare officer billets still vacant. Since the Cross Committee report six months ago there has been no improvement in the Navy officer shortfalls. The Cross report expected that there would continue to be a 16 per cent wastage in the weapons electrical branch as there was in 1987-88; in fact, the wastage in March 1989 was 17.8 per cent. We have had problems with the Navy worrying about whether it can afford to take ships to sea due to the inexperience of the available engineer officers. The RAAF has an 18 per cent to 20 per cent deficit in squadron leader and wing commander areas. The general duties branch of the RAAF has a wastage rate of 260 per cent over the average. The RAAF has not met its recruiting targets for officers since 1981. A total of 101 pilots are leaving this financial year, 73 have already left and 28 are leaving soon. Ten have already given notice that they are leaving in the next financial year. In desperation the RAAF is considering lowering recruitment standards for officers, borrowing foreigners and recruiting more older men and young women. The RAAF is already recruiting 45 per cent females. It is a measure of its desperation when so many of its positions have formerly been denied to women.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not desperate, that is social change. You ought to be awake to that. That's another thing that's happened. `Desperate to recruit women'-what a ridiculous thing to say. That is the sort of boofhead thing you would say.

—I do not have the time to waste on Senator Button and so I will leave him to mutter into his beard. The funding realities are also of great concern although the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, recommended 2.6 per cent to 3 per cent real growth per annum in order to maintain capability. That was never met. The total real growth since 1983 has been 1.7 per cent. This year we have the lowest proportion of the gross domestic product being spent on defence since 1950-that is 2.4 per cent. Despite the Cross report recommendations and all the recommendations that have gone before, there is no percentage real growth in 1989-90. If the Minister for Defence is lucky he might get 0.5 per cent from the funds generated by the sale of defence assets-just a fire sale, a once-off.

SPEECH.PARA: It is hard to know just how the response we received today will be funded, because we understand the funding is to come from existing resources. The existing resources are now in such a state that there will be no money for Army removals from now until the end of the financial year. There is a $28m shortfall for army uniforms over the next two years and the Army does not have a clue where it will find the money to outfit its personnel. There is an extra $28m commitment for the Namibian force that has to come out of the existing Defence Force budget; there is no extra allowance for it. Kangaroo 89, which is the showpiece for the Minister to show how clever he is but is more likely to show exactly the opposite, accounts for another $36m and has meant that there will be no other exercises for the rest of the financial year. We have desperate shortages in areas relating to spare parts and personal equipment and we are already down to minimal exercises and operations in the lead-up to Kangaroo 89.

The problem has been exacerbated by the Government's priorities within the defence budget and a reduced proportion year by year going into the personnel area. Now the Government is also cutting operational expenditure. Mr Beazley has said that there is nothing magical about the fact that we can finance a major defence equipment program without major increases in defence outlays. He said that it was simply a matter of management. It is hardly good management when we are losing personnel at the rate we are. Since April 1983, we have lost 48,000 people, which is over 68 per cent of the current strength. Recruitment simply will not replace the experience and the skills.

We come again to the Cross report and to the Government's response. The Cross report focused on the need for adequate, substantial retention measures which would stop this happening and turn the position around. The RAAF report which the Opposition released recently said exactly the same things.

Then we come to today's statement by Mr David Simmons, his first public act as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. On page 1 of his statement, he says that the Government acknowledges and fully supports the commitment of the defence personnel of Australia. It is not good enough for him to say so. It is action that is needed, real support, to show that the Government is committed to its Defence Force personnel. I understand that the first draft of this speech made no mention whatsoever of families and had to be sent back to deal with that oversight. Such is the Government's attitude to the families of Defence Force personnel that we had a ministerial speech in draft form that failed to recognise families. Families are critical to the happiness and well-being of Defence Force personnel and they have been sadly neglected in times past. The Minister went on to say:
The Government's strong and continuing support for the Defence Force is a matter of public record.

This is quite untrue. One of the core problems of the Defence Force and their morale is that they feel that the Government does not care. The Government's action speak louder than its words and its funding cuts over the last six years to the Defence Force personnel and the erosion in their conditions of service are much more important to them than a small statement like that, which they see to be quite untrue. It is a matter of saying the right sort of thing a bit too late. Under the heading, `Personnel wastage' Mr Simmons says:

The present levels of personnel wastage from the Defence Force is an issue of very great importance and concern. The Government has not sought to deny this fact, nor to disguise, in any way, the extent of the problem.

The fact is that the Government has denied the problem. It has denied it over and over again. Then, when finally it had to admit it when the Cross Committee made its report, it continued right up to the other day to deny the desperately serious implications. They go to the capability of our Defence Force to defend this nation in the way that is necessary. It also goes to the ability to maintain safety standards in what is often a very dangerous occupation. The Government fails to acknowledge that. It tries to whitewash it. The Minister, Mr Beazley, has done that on a number of occasions and Mr Simmons is also learning bad habits. About all he has said recently is simply that the Opposition is wrong and that there is no problem with capability. The forces know better.

On page 2 of the statement there is a mention of statistics. That reminds me that a number of witnesses to the Cross Committee poured scorn on the Defence Department's keeping of statistics. It keeps several sets of statistics. I think it keeps one for public consumption and the rest it keeps in the Department. None agrees with the other. There was a very real need for the Department to do something about its statistics and there were recommendations to that effect. The way the people of Australia were being hoodwinked about the true situation was disgraceful. One cannot be sure exactly where the responsibility for that lies, whether totally within the Department of Defence, totally within the Government, or a mixture of both.

The Minister says that the major conclusion of the report is that there was no one cause for increased wastage and no one simple answer. But there is one very direct answer that the Government could have given long ago-that the people in the defence forces feel that nobody cares about them, that nobody knows they are there. If they go off in a flurry to Fiji, if there is a natural disaster in Australia like the cyclone in Darwin, if there are bushfires, if we send a force off to Namibia, or if we send people to the Iran-Iraq border, for a moment the nation notices and then goes back to its peacetime occupations. The Government has a responsibility to keep the importance and the contribution of the defence forces before the Australian people so that the forces themselves know that the Government cares and the Government respects their status and importance in our national culture.

Mr Simmons claims that the Government has a proven record of performance across the full range of Service personnel issues. He goes on to list them. I would say it has a proven record of a rotten performance and the claims that he makes in the statement about a successful support for substantial increases in many key general and specialist allowances is a lot of rot. The only substantial allowances that the Defence Force has been able to achieve in the last two or three years were when the independent Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal made the determination, over the screaming body of the Commonwealth. The Government has fought every inch of the way to see that decent flying allowances and other allowances were not paid to servicemen, and it knows it. It is no good Mr Simmons claiming otherwise. He claims that the Government has been providing financial, educational and support arrangements for Service families. He has done nothing of the sort. His document proves that. When it comes to educational arrangements, he would not bite the bullet and the recommendations relating to educational stability for secondary school children were rejected.

So many things in this statement need dealing with that it is hard to choose which ones to pick out particularly for attention. As I have already said, the Government has complained that it has done things about the defence forces already and that the recommendations of the Committee's report fits in very well with what it has been doing. The truth of the matter is that the Government denied the problem until the Committee met and then it continued to deny the implications. The Government had to be dragged to recognise that there really was a problem. Today the Government told us that it will review the defence force retirement and death benefits scheme (DFRDB), and a long time overdue that is. It is interesting to note that when Mrs Kelly was speaking in the House of Representatives only last year on 30 November, she said:

I think there would be a frenzy through the Defence Force, a feeling of terrific uncertainty, if we tried to make major changes to the DFRDB, even though I recognise that there are anomalies with it at the moment.

She has never spoken a truer word. In fact, the defence forces are terrified of this Government touching the DFRDB scheme, desperately needed though it is. The Government has said it will make sure that people retain their benefits, but I do not think it will be believed too well because its record on superannuation for the general community is so rotten. It has always reduced superannuation benefits for Australians, and servicemen do not trust them. The DFRDB scheme is facing problems at the moment with the Government's reasonable benefits limits. The Minister says:
While these limits are yet to be set for the DFRDB scheme, they are likely to affect only a few very senior officers.

He said that he would be making an announcement when the impact was decided. That is not true, either. The reasonable benefits limits are going to affect considerable numbers of people who go into other employment after they leave the defence forces. I am concerned about the review of the DFRDB scheme because there is nothing in the statement which says it will be a public review. If this gets to be a review behind closed doors in the hands of the bureaucrats, with the Governments able to manipulate it, it will be totally unsatisfactory and will be seen to be so by Defence Force personnel. It is urgent that we see the details of the terms of reference. As with any inquiry, they will be vital in determining how much can come out of the review.

I draw attention to the fact that this Government recently introduced into the Parliament legislation which will deal with superannuation benefits where a policeman has been found to be corrupt. I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that a corrupt policeman in the Australian Federal Police will be able to leave his employment with more benefits than a serviceman who has served honourably for 19 years and nine months. In other words, the policeman will get back interest on his own superannuation contributions; the soldier, sailor and airman are entitled to not a penny more than they put in themselves. This is a pretty good indication of how urgent the Government sees the need to increase retirement benefits for servicemen when it rushes this legislation through and still leave a corrupt policeman with interest on his contributions.

There is a passage on page 4 of the statement which really bothers me. The Minister talks about the Defence Force personnel being affected by the same rules and regulations, influenced by the same social dynamics, and feeling the same aspirations as the rest of the Australian community. The situation is that they are subject to quite different rules and regulations. They are under discipline all day every day. They do not have the benefits of unions and the muscle that that gives. They have no right to strike. They have no penalty rates or overtime rates. They are expected to separate from their extended families and live wherever the nation demands; and be separated from their immediate families. If necessary they must put their lives on the line, as our member on the Iran-Iraq border and in Namibia are doing right now.

It is nonsense for the Government to claim that they are affected by the same rules and regulations and are in the same position as the rest of the Australian community. That is a very important item. It relates to the question of Defence Force pay in particular. The Government has absolutely refused to accept the recommendation of the Cross-committee on a major review of pay and allowances. The important point is that the Defence Force is a unique organisation because of the factors I have already mentioned. As a result, special guidelines need to be laid down for the Remuneration Tribunal to take into account when it is considering the pay of servicemen. The Government welshes on that and says the Tribunal is not subject to Government direction. It is subject to Government direction, however, in that the Government says it must take account of the national wage guidelines. Apparently it is a different thing when the guidelines should include a direction that servicemen are in a unique situation.

There are many other matters of concern, as I have said. They include the provision of fulfilling jobs for those who are posted to Canberra and the need to review the Department of Defence. The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has totally refused to do anything about the organisation of the Department of Defence. That will remain a major stumbling block for middle to senior ranking officers who decide that the frustrations of work in the bureaucracy are just not worth the effort. I am also concerned that the Government has seen fit to give such emphasis to civilianisation. It is not the answer to the Defence Force's problems. It will give it extra problems, such as problems that it incurs when there is a civilian freeze, the extra expense, which is not widely recognised, but is incurred with civilians, and the question of what to do when there are civilians in vital positions during times of national emergency. An emerging problem concerns maternity leave. A high proportion of the Force is now female, but the Government's policy requires that positions not be filled while women are on maternity leave. That is leaving an enormous hole in the Force as well. Civilianisation will not help, either.

One thing the Minister says in the statement is that there have been enough reviews and reports. I could not agree with him more, but he goes on in the next couple of pages to suggest areas where there should be surveys and reports. One of the issues that worries me is that there is no attention given to benefits that it is likely will have to be provided for single personnel. There is no readiness to come to grips with the need to more speedily upgrade single as well as married accommodation. The Government has finally taken on board a suggestion I have been pushing ever since I came into the Parliament, as to rental accommodation; in the meantime it is not prepared to do any-thing about reviewing the temporary rental allowance so we may have for a considerable time yet a number of rental ceilings still dating back to 1986.

The Defence Force Housing Authority has been a great improvement but we are faced today with a really nasty little smart alec gimmick, described on page 8 of the statement as post-May 1985 housing assistance. That is a variation on the existing defence service home loan scheme. At first glance it looks like an improvement. The amount of the loan which will go to people who have enlisted since May 1985 will be $40,000. That is long overdue for all loans. When we look into it more closely, the interest rate, at 40 per cent off current market rates, would be 9.6 per cent. When we look at the fine print here it is hard to work out whether the subsidy period of the loan will be 20 years or 25 years. The Minister claims it will be both. I do not know what the Westpac Banking Corporation is going to say about the arrangements. It means that some of the people who Westpac would have contracted to provide loans for are now going to be able to opt out of that scheme and into this one.

The most important point is that there is actually a reduction in benefits. It is another erosion because people will be able to have the interest subsidy only as long as they are serving in the Force. If someone serves 10 years, as soon as he gets out he loses his entitlement. The old defence service home loan scheme was for 25 years. People had the interest subsidy for the whole of that time. Once again there has been no attempt to develop a childcare policy.
