DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (SAVINGS ACCOUNTS INTEREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this cognate debate on the Income Tax Assessment (Savings Accounts Interest) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Income Tax Assessment (Housing Loan Interest) Amendment Bill 1989.
—Are you speaking for Walsh, or is he coming in later?

—I assume that I am speaking for this side of the chamber. I believe that these Bills, which have been introduced by the Australian Democrats, are the latest manifestation of the populism which has been exhibited by the Democrats in recent times. They remind me of a notice of motion given by my colleague Dr Dick Klugman in the House of Representatives a couple of years ago to the effect that interest rates be increased for lenders and that simultaneously interest rates be reduced for borrowers. That was the whimsical nature of the notice of motion which graced the Notice Paper of the House of Representatives in 1987. It satirised the inconsistencies of some people who parade around the country with economic solutions to some of the problems facing this country. It was totally in character with Dr Klugman who takes a whimsical view of politics most of the time.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Government, I oppose the Bills that have been introduced by Senator Haines on behalf of the Democrats. It is very easy for the Australian Democrats to come into this place and propose taxation rebates for the people who save and rebates on home loan repayments, both of which will detract from the revenues available to the Government to fund expenditures at the national level in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think you can afford them out of a $9 1/2 billion Budget surplus?

—I will come to that in a moment. The reality is that the Democrats have never been responsible for governing in this country; they never will be and they never have been. They are on the downward trend. They are not responsible for finding revenue at the national level to pay for the accounts of the Commonwealth Government of Australia in its many forms, and they never will be. It is very easy for them at all times to parade around Australia finding ways in which to reduce the revenues available to the Commonwealth and also to add to its expenditure levels.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are simply further examples of the pie in the sky thinking which is being manifested by the Australian Democrats at the moment. The proposals regarding the housing sector-the subsidised interest rates and subsidies on savings in particular accounts which relate to the housing industry-are a reflection of Senator Haines's particular personal interest in the electorate of Kingston in South Australia at this time. The Kingston electorate is in the southern suburbs of Adelaide. A large number of new dwellings are being constructed. It is an outer suburban area with rapid housing growth. Presumably Senator Haines has done some soundings and has come to the conclusion that interest rates are a very sexy issue in the Kingston electorate at this time. So that is probably what is behind this particular proposal for subsidised housing interest rates and subsidised savings in particular accounts to fund housing allocations.

In standing for the electorate of Kingston and putting forward these proposals, Senator Haines is simply trying to focus national media attention on the Australian Democrats. There is a very good reason for that; that is because the Democrats are on the down trend in Australia. In fact, after the next half Senate election instead of seven Australian Democrats in the Senate there will be three.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two, with any luck.

—Senator Richardson suggests that there may be two, with any luck. We will probably have Senator Powell from Victoria, Senator McLean from New South Wales and Senator Haines from South Australia, all of whom have six-year terms. The rest of the Democrats may depart at the election because they will not get elected. This will mean that the Democrats will no longer have party status in this place; they will not have the requisite number of senators to qualify as a political party; they will not qualify for the resources which accompany a recognised political party; and they will not have the entitlements that go with the status of a recognised political party. The Democrats will effectively be functioning in this House as three independents after the next election. I think that is probably the reason Senator Haines is contesting the seat of Kingston in South Australia. It is essentially a move to focus national media attention on a declining political party in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get onto the question of housing, I will put some figures forward. It is interesting that in South Australia-and Victoria and South Australia are the two major States for the Democrats-the Democrats could manage only an 11.2 per cent Senate vote at the 1987 Federal election. That was exactly the same vote to the exact decimal point that the Democrats obtained in South Australia in 1977. At a national level, at the very first election the Democrats contested in South Australia, they managed 11.2 per cent of the vote. At the 1987 election, despite the publicity and the hype, nationally the Democrats' vote was not one decimal point higher than they obtained in their first election 10 years before. So there has been absolutely no progress in the Democrats' share of the vote in one of their two major states. This is a situation stagnation for them. I presume that the result is paralleled in other States of Australia.

Members of the Government are aware of interest rate concerns. We do not try to pretend that they do not exist. We are aware that members of the community are vitally concerned about the level of interest rates. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made it abundantly clear that interest rates will not remain high for one day longer than is absolutely necessary on economic grounds. One of the great problems of debates in this chamber is that there is too much focus on the symptoms of economic problems, but very little focus on the causes. The Australian Democrats, with their proposed legislation, are being consistent with their track record of focusing on the symptoms-in this case interest rates-rather than the causes of economic problems in Australia.

The housing Bill we are debating jointly with a Bill to subsidise savings provides for some tax relief to be given on home loan repayments. As I pointed out earlier, it is very easy for the Democrats, a minor party-it has seven members at the moment and will soon be reduced to three independents-to parade around Australia suggesting that it is easy to cut government revenues. If the Democrats want to have tax concessions for this, that and the other, government revenues will have to be reduced. We in government have to take a responsible view. We have to ensure that revenues are available to fund government expenditures. That is what it is all about. It is not about one-off, populist measures; it is not about people parading around Australia asking for a tax break for this and that without keeping an eye on the big picture, which is the revenue required to fund the ongoing commitments of the Commonwealth Government.

Senator Haines is entirely consistent in this. I well remember that when I came into this chamber in 1983, one of the really momentous pieces of legislation at that time was the so-called bottom of the harbour legislation to crack down on tax cheats and tax avoiders in Australia. That momentous legislation was brought in by the Hawke Government to ensure that tax cheats were caught up with. I do not recall Senator Haines voting with us on that. I do not recall her helping us find that extra revenue from tax cheats, the people who stripped companies and dumped their records on the bottom of the harbour. I do not recall Senator Haines voting with the Government to try to find that revenue, to crack down on tax cheats and to ensure that there was fairness and equity in the Australian tax system. On the other hand, at all times the Australian Democrats are able to find ways and means to reduce the Government's revenue by giving hand-outs here and hand-outs there; giving tax breaks here and tax breaks there. that is the sort of activity that goes on in minor parties.

I now turn to the specific proposal for housing tax rebates. Housing tax rebates are inappropriate and certainly very expensive. The Fraser-Howard Government, which was in power up to March 1983, tried to bribe the voters in 1982 by bringing in two schemes to subsidise housing interest payments. It tried to bribe the voters by introducing programs to subsidise housing interest payments. That was the record of the Fraser-Howard Administration. We progressively got rid of those rebates in 1983 and 1984 for very good reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you tell the people what your real agenda was?

—We will ask Mr Peacock what his real agenda is for tomorrow today. I would be fascinated to hear that. To get back to the matter of housing rebates, I cannot understand why the Democrats would want to bring in a proposal to subsidise home loan interest repayments. After all, for the last couple of years Senator Powell has lectured us about how the Democrats have a compassionate side, she has said that the Labor Government has let down people on social security. By definition, home loan interest repayment subsidies do nothing for people who rent. They do nothing for the poorest people in the community, those who cannot afford to purchase their own homes and have to rent properties. Such people get nothing out of these schemes. That is another policy inconsistency of the Democrats. Month after month last year Senator Powell lectured the Government about how it was letting down the people in need, the people in poverty, yet here is a particular scheme that would do nothing to subsidise or help the neediest people in the community. It would help only those who already have a toe in the housing market. That point about these proposals for taxation rebates for housing loan interest payments needs to be stated most strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the key philosophical reasons for our not having such rebates is to ensure that the real and effective tax rates that apply to people are very close to the published tax rates. We should all support that very important factor because once we start going down the road of allowing rebates, tax concessions, we end up opening up the way for tax loopholes. Tax concessions have tended to become tax loopholes for the rich and powerful. We must ensure that there are a minimum number of tax rebates and concessions in the tax system. The lower and middle income earners of the community will do better out of the system if the effective tax rates that apply to people on a weekly and fortnightly basis are close to the published rates. Otherwise, a cancer develops in the tax system, such as that which developed under the Fraser-Howard Administration with a range of tax breaks becoming tax rorts and tax loopholes, with the real tax rate becoming diluted by a range of rebates and tax concessions. I am proud to say that one of the philosophies of this Government since 1983 has been to make sure that the published tax rates are very close to the real and effective tax rates. We have systematically got rid of tax concessions, tax deductions and tax rebates. They all watered down the published tax rates. Lower and middle income earners should be very careful and vigilant in this respect, because if we open the door with a tax concession here and there, it becomes a tax loophole and the rich and powerful exploit it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Alan Bond?

—That is what happens with tax systems. The populism of Senator Haines is no excuse. The history of tax systems in this country makes it clear that once we do that the lower and middle income earners have shifted onto them more of the total proportion of the tax system because the rich and powerful exploit loopholes to their advantage. The most important thing is to make sure that the tax rates we read about on our tax forms are the effective tax rates across the board.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1 July, we will be ensuring that, as a result of a range of tax concessions being removed in recent years, there will be substantial personal income tax relief for lower and middle income Australians. Instead of allowing a tax break here and there-the sort of piecemeal approach of the Democrats, the populists-we are reducing tax rates across the board. That is the most important way to reform a tax system. It is preferable to opening a loophole here and another there. From 1 July, a single income Australian family with two children and a fairly typical income of $500 a week will benefit to the extent of $23.95 a week as a result of the Government's tax reforms. That figure includes family allowance payments and the increases in the family allowance supplement. That is the sort of thing that can be done for lower and middle income families if all the rorts are taken out of the system. If the cancers are taken out of the tax base and all these rebates and concessions which become loopholes are swept aside, such things can be done for lower and middle income Australians. We can give substantial tax cuts. I am proud to say that I am a member of a Government that from 1 July will give substantial tax cuts across the board.

We are castigated by those opposite for our housing record. Senator Haines moved a motion about subsidised housing mortgage repayments and said how the housing industry had been crippled and so forth. However, let us look at the record. Let us look at what has been happening in the housing sector of the economy in recent times. In the last year of Mr Fraser's Administration, when Mr Howard was the Treasurer, the number of actual housing commencements in Australia for that year was 105,000. Last financial year, under the Hawke Labor Government, the number of new dwellings commenced in Australia was not 105,000, 110,000 or 115,000, but 136,000. That is real bricks and mortar. According to the independent indicative planning council for the housing sector, it is expected that, despite the high interest rates that the Australian Democrats are running around the country complaining about, the number of actual dwelling approvals this financial year is likely to be 165,000. That is a tremendous record. Not only is it a very high figure for the current financial year but it is also an enormous increase over the 105,000 commencements of dwellings under the Fraser Government in 1982-83. That is the record. Despite the so-called effects of high interest rates, we are still seeing substantial investments in bricks and mortar in this country.

I want to talk briefly about the first home ownership scheme. I am sure that will be of great interest to Senator Haines in her campaign in the Adelaide electorate of Kingston. The scheme was introduced by the Labor Government in 1983. It is a targeted scheme. It is much better focused than the tax rebates, which can go to anybody, including the mega-rich in the large capital cities. The scheme gives assistance for housing purchase and focuses on the people in need. It is an income-tested scheme. Therefore it has high social justice; it is very fair and equitable. Since 1983 the Hawke Government has provided $1.4 billion in housing assistance through the first home owners scheme. That is a tremendous boost for home ownership in this country. Some 320,000 Australian families have been assisted by the first home ownership scheme throughout Australia.

I would like to turn to the figures for the Kingston electorate, which I just happen to have here. I find these figures fascinating. Senator Haines runs around the Kingston electorate in the southern suburbs of Adelaide saying, `Let's have higher interest rates for savers and lower interest rates for borrowers'. That is what it really comes down to. Despite that, the reality is that as a result of the quiet and methodical work of the Hawke Labor Government, in the Kingston electorate there have been 2,800 successful applicants under the first home owners scheme. That probably means 5,000 electors in the Kingston electorate up to 7 April this year have qualified under the first home owners scheme.

Between 1983 and 1989 this Government spent some $12,600,000 on the first home owners scheme in the Kingston electorate. That is a tremendous amount of money to spend in one electorate in one State. It turns out to be equivalent to 10 per cent of the whole allocation in the State of South Australia. Perhaps 5,000 electors in the Kingston electorate in the southern suburbs of Adelaide are very well aware that they have benefited tangibly, explicitly and directly under a housing program launched and implemented by the Hawke Labor Government. Some 5,000 people will not be receptive to the sort of nonsense that is being put around in that electorate by the Australian Democrats, who, as I say, effectively want lower interest rates for borrowers and higher interest rates for savers. That is what it comes down to. It is populism out on the hustings.

I now want to turn to Senator Haines's proposals for tax breaks on savings. For example, one proposal is that there should be exemption from personal income tax for the first $2,000 of interest income on savings. That is essentially the nub of the proposal. My first question is: why give this tax break effectively to all taxpayers, irrespective of their income? That is the first proposition that has to be raised. Why should a mega-rich person from the big end of town qualify for this particular tax break? Why does such a person need this particular tax concession? Such people patently do not need it. It strikes me as being a very inequitable proposal. Perhaps it is rather like the proposal launched by Mr Fraser and Mr Howard in the previous coalition Government when they introduced a tax rebate for dividends. It was put forward on the basis of an alleged need to encourage wider share ownership in Australia. Yet they made the concession available to the superwealthy who clearly did not need it. It was yet another of these very expensive policies which were not focused or targeted, which went right across the board and benefited people who did not need it.

It is interesting that one of the aspects of the Democrats proposal is to try to increase saving. I want to look at the question of saving as a concept in a modern economy. Total saving in an economy by definition includes both private sector saving and public sector saving. That is something we have to face up to. The Government itself is a saver-or can be a saver-just as much as the private individual. That is something that has to be borne in mind. Senator Haines claims that her proposal, giving tax rebates on the first $2,000 of interest income, would boost private and individual saving. That would seem to be the motivation behind the proposal. The reality is that once we do that, once we go down that road, we are cutting government revenues, as I have pointed out. Taxation will be lower; so government revenue falls. But the present reality is that the Government has a Budget surplus-it is actually spending less than the revenue it is generating. So the Government itself is a net saver in economic terms. If we were to implement Senator Haines's proposal, we would reduce government revenue and therefore government sector saving.

Senator Haines claims she is trying to boost private or individual saving. There is no guarantee that that will happen as a result of this measure. But we can clearly say that on the other side of the ledger, the other side of the balance, public sector saving will be diminished. The size of the Government's saving through its Budget surplus will be reduced. Even if we gave a tax break for saving, in the present circumstances it is very unlikely that it would boost total saving in the economy. On the other side of the ledger, it is very clear that there will be a reduction in public sector saving. I think that is a fundamental factor that has to be borne in mind. I am not sure that any arguments can be put against it.

Again I make the point, as I made it repeatedly in regard to the proposed legislation on taxation concessions on mortgage repayments, that it is very important to be vigilant about any of these proposals for tax rebates, tax deductions or tax concessions. Again the proposed tax concessions on saving will also have the effect of diluting the tax base and moving the real effective income tax rates away from the published rates. We have to be very vigilant about that, as I pointed out earlier. In this country we must go for fewer tax concessions but have a philosophy of trying to reduce the tax rates themselves. That is a better way of doing things. The way to reduce the economic distortions in the system is by having general policy measures rather than piecemeal rebates, concessions or loopholes in particular parts of the economy. It is better to have lower tax rates and have a general policy measure which does not distort the economic system.

I would like to move on to one particular group in the community who possibly are net savers-the age pensioners. The aged in the community typically-but not always-own their own homes. Typically they do not have mortgages like younger members of the community. I would like to put on the record that the aged in the community have done extraordinarily well out of the April statement that was brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) not so long ago. This is very relevant to the whole question of saving. As I pointed out, I believe that, unlike younger members of the community, the aged in the community typically are net savers rather than net borrowers. The reality is that as a result of the April statement the aged have had enormous tax relief given to them. For example, in the current financial year, the tax relief applying to non-pension income of age pensioners-that is, personal income over and above the pension, which might be in the form of dividends or interest payments or whatever-was a little below $10 a week. That is the sort of benchmark figure we are looking at. It is a figure of a little below $10 a week of tax exempt income in the current financial year. But next financial year, 1989-90, single pensioners, for example, will have tax exempt income of $25 weekly. So that is a 150 per cent increase in their tax exempt income next financial year, to be followed by a $40 weekly tax exempt income in 1990-91. So that will be a figure four times the current figure.

As a result of those measures and of the further exemption from tax of the extra income of married pensioners-for whom the amount will be going up immediately; in the next financial year, beginning on 1 July, to $70 a week in tax exempt income-that particular group in the community should have a significantly larger capacity to save. As I pointed out, I believe that they are probably net savers now anyway. But, as a result of these measures-lower taxation through the April statement on the extra incomes of pensioners-that group should be able to have greater disposable incomes and therefore greater savings. Of course, this will not apply in the case of every household, but I am talking in generalisations. That is a very tangible way in which the Hawke Government has in recent months added, probably significantly, to the potential in the Australian community to save. Again, we are not talking about piecemeal measures. We are not talking about a tax break here, a rebate there, a concession there and a lurk somewhere else; we are talking about the putting in place of a general policy measure for a group of people in the community which should enable them to save more.

Those are the points I would like to make in opposition to the pieces of legislation proposed by the Australian Democrats. It is much more important in government to go for general policy measures than for piecemeal measures. When addressing the taxation system with a view to reforming it, it is much more important to work on the basis of principles and not populism. That is a very important thing that distinguishes this Government from the populists in the Democrats-that we see tax reform as being based on principles, on general policy measures, and not on piecemeal one-off measures involving a tax rebate here, a tax concession there and a tax lurk somewhere else. So when one does those things-when one goes down the road of general policy measures, cleans out from the system the rebates, the concessions, the lurks and the loopholes-one has a tax base which is sound and not riddled with cancers and which therefore will generate revenues which can be redistributed to lower and middle income earners, as we are doing as a result of the April economic statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very easy to understand the feelings that motivated the Australian Democrats to bring these two Bills before us today. The two Bills are the Income Tax Assessment (Savings Account Interest) Amendment Bill and the Income Tax Assessment (Housing Loan Interest) Amendment Bill. These two Bills are related in the sense that the first tries to stimulate savings and the second tries to reduce the impact of mortgage costs on individual Australians. It is perfectly clear that the need for these things has been very largely the result of the policies of the present Hawke Labor Government with regard to interest rates and tight monetary control. That, of course, stems from the very significant overseas debt which has been generated in the six years this Government has been in power, climbing now to something like $140 billion, and which, of course, is added to every month to the tune of $1 1/2 billion as a direct result of our current account deficit-which, of course, is the difference between our net exports and imports. In other words, as a nation, we are losing $1 1/2 billion a month, and we have to borrow to make up that difference.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is clear that the Democrats, in concept at least, are on the right track-in so far as they see the need for there to be a stimulation of savings within Australia to cope with this ballooning debt problem of $1 1/2 billion a month and in that way ensure that we rely less and less on the import of foreign capital, either through loans or by the sale of our assets, and generate the money to cover that shortfall ourselves. We in the Opposition do not have any quarrel with that general concept. However, when we get down to the mechanics of the Bills themselves-the way they are actually drafted and the issues they seek to raise-we find that we are unable to give our support to them.

Let us go to some of the provisions of the first Bill, which is the Income Tax Assessment (Savings Accounts Interest) Amendment Bill. As I have just outlined, there is no doubt that the Liberal and National parties strongly believe that Australians should be given greater encouragement and incentive to save. There are many reasons for that. They are not connected just with our immediate very sizable problems with the economy; rather, they are of a general nature and conform very greatly with the Future Directions document of the Liberal and National parties. That document, of course, indicates our interest in making Australians self- assured and in control of their own affairs by ensuring that they build up capital during their working lives so that they can indeed earn a satisfactory and well looked after retirement. So saving is part and parcel of our general approach to individuals and their futures.

Let us turn to some of the provisions of the Bills with which we have quarrels. We are not in any way sure that Senator Haines's Income Tax Assessment (Savings Accounts Interest) Amendment Bill will increase savings in the way she hopes it will. Senator Haines said in her second reading speech:
. . . many Australians will save more if we give them a direct incentive to save by not taxing the first $2,000 of interest earned. That is what this Bill will achieve.

However, on analysing it-and I will come to the points later-it is pretty clear that that might not be so. It is more than likely that, if this Bill succeeds, the savings will merely be redirected from existing investment areas to the proposed low interest accounts in order to take advantage of that $2,000 tax free limit. In other words, the community is already investing in certain types of instruments, including savings accounts, but if a tax free incentive is offered, it is pretty clear that people will tend to take their money from whatever depository they are using and put it into another where they can get that added tax advantage. Quite clearly that is a consequence not contemplated in any way by the provisions of Senator Haines's Bill.

This reallocation of funds from one asset into another for certain kinds of financial institutions might very well significantly disrupt the capacity of individual enterprises and institutions to meet their commitments to their various borrowers. Moreover, for those who are presently earning at least $2,000 from interest income each year, Senator Haines's proposal would certainly not encourage additional savings because, quite clearly, those who may wish to save will not get the tax benefit beyond that $2,000. In other words, they will work it up to that maximum level of $2,000 of income and will have not incentive to go beyond it. So, quite clearly, this could run counter to the proposition which she is espousing.
I will quote from the Bills Digest issued by the Legislative Research Service of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, which makes a further point about this matter. It says:
For those who already earn--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, check that. They made a mistake in that. They have acknowledged that they got it wrong. I rang them yesterday. I mention that before you start reading-unless you have one that is dated today. They misread the legislation.
—I am not dealing with that point. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: For those who already earn $2000 or more from their investments and pay more than the lowest marginal rate of tax, the incentive will largely be to channel the funds into a tax free return and so earn a greater after-tax return from the same level of investment (i.e. there will be little incentive to increase the total level of investment as they can take advantage of the tax free area already and any new investment will effectively be taxed at the marginal rate.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Library itself has summed up the series of points which I have just been making which led the Liberal and National parties to judge that this Bill is fatally flawed. It is true, however, as I said earlier, that the concept is an attractive one, and certainly there is a need to examine other alternatives to find the best way to encourage Australians to stimulate savings. There have been various proposals put forward to try to boost aggregate savings. What is needed right now, rather than to decide upon a piecemeal measure that is quite ineffective, such as this put forward by the Australian Democrats, is to examine the series of proposals that might be sculling around the community, test them in the full light of day and apply the blowtorch to them to ensure that they could possibly work well and effectively without undue cost to the revenue.

I will instance the cases which the Liberal and National parties are examining which are on the public record at the present time. The first is that we would like to see an exemption of interest up to a certain amount. Of course, that amount would have to be determined and the details of eligibility decided. That is somewhat similar to this suggestion from the Democrats but it does not suffer from the same flaw, which is that the Democrats' proposal is virtually open-ended.

The second proposition is to apply a withholding tax of 15 per cent on interest in payment of the full tax liability. The effect of that would be to reduce the rate of tax from the marginal rate, which could be as high as 50.25 per cent, down to a maximum of 15 per cent. That would be a substantial incentive for people to save as they could then save on their tax liability to the extent of 30.25 per cent of the amount received. Of course, it could be a lesser amount depending upon the actual level of people's other income, as well as the interest income. That, again, deserves consideration and it is a proposal which we should send to a committee of the Senate to investigate further.

A third proposition could well be that we should apply a tax on only the real value of interest after taking inflation into account. In other words, whatever the interest level is, the inflation rate should be applied to it and the difference would be only that rate of interest described as real, which would be subject to tax. That would be very acceptable to potential savers in so far as they are inflation-proofed against that erosion from inflation which unfortunately is such a significant factor in investment management today.

I hope I have said enough to make the point that this is a very important issue. It needs the most careful and detailed consideration before anyone-least of all uninformed senators in this place-should suggest it as a major policy proposal.

That brings me to the line of action on this Bill that the Liberal and National parties intend to take. We seek to have this general question of the effects on savings of the present system of taxation, and the measures that should be adopted to increase Australia's private savings in order to increase Australia's medium to long term investment performance, referred to the Senator Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report. That inquiry is to be included by the last day of sitting in 1989. In order to achieve that, we seek to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of each of these Bills. In respect of the Income Tax Assessment (Savings Accounts Interest) Amendment Bill 1989, I move:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert''
``the following matters be referred to the Senate Standing on Finance and Public Adminstration for inquiry and report, on or before the last day of sitting in 1989:
(a) the effects on savings of the present system of taxation; and
(b) the measures that should be adopted to increase Australia's private savings in order to increase Australia's medium to long-term investment performance''.

That amendment is the right way to proceed with this Bill before us today. We should consider in significant detail the most important questions which are influencing people in this country in their decision to invest. There is no doubt that the country needs more investment through savings. The question is, how to get it. What is the best way of approaching this question?

When Senator Haines sums up at the end of this debate I would like to know just how deeply the Democrats looked at the issue of stimulating savings. Perhaps she can satisfy us on some of the points that I have just been making. I have to say that, judging from the second reading speech and the simple nature of the Bill, it is more than likely that the Bill represents a simple, knee-jerk political reaction to that very justifiable concern in the community about the taxes applied to savings. The bare attention that the Democrats have given to the drafting of this proposal can be seen from clause 4 of this Bill. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Bill refers to a savings account which is bearing interest at a rate of 12 per cent or less before the tax exemption would apply. Given the widely fluctuating interest rates that are applicable today, driven by this Government's monetary policies-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pompous posturing.

—Of course they are posturing. We have to take that into account and perhaps we can address ourselves to some of those political matters later. With the fluctuating nature of the interest rate, one would think that if the Bill is to be effective and deliver some kind of assistance to people, it should take account of the fluctuating interest rate structure we have today. The rate will move. It is moving every day. Consequently, this may or may not be an adequate way of addressing it, but our judgment is that it certainly is not, and is totally inadequate. If the threshold rate had to be changed, a Bill would need to go through Parliament every time that interest rates fluctuate. Interest rates are moving literally weekly at the present time. Perhaps Senator Haines can explain how she would proceed to right this difficult flaw in the legislation which she is proposing.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I would like to make is that as the Bill is drafted there will be a significant windfall for financial institutions, particularly banks. Approved financial institutions could accept deposits for tax free savings at a lower rate-that is, the institution would pay only 12 per cent rather than the current market rate which could be significantly higher-while lending to commercial or other customers at that market rate. This would merely result in the financial institutions making a huge windfall gain. They would be able to do it because their effective rate would be below that 12 per cent-it would be subsidised by the Government. We would have the Commissioner of Taxation or the Treasury giving a subsidy to the person who had lent his money to the bank, thus lowering the overall cost of money to the bank, which would then lend it out at market rates and make a substantially greater profit, to the extent of that Treasury subsidy.

Why have not the Democrats thought through those particular proposals and come up with solutions? Those are the sorts of things that have to be examined deeply. That is why we think that it is necessary to refer this question to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

Another point is that of cost. The cost of the Democrats' proposal, even by their own admission, would be very high. They say that the tax-free threshold proposal, on its own, could cost $1.1 billion. We have to assume, though, that that is a mere minimum. The other proposal-for a rebate for housing mortgage interest-could entail another $200m. The Democrats have given us no convincing financial statement to demonstrate in the first place how much this would all cost and, secondly, how the cost ought to be met from revenue or from the Budget generally. The cost would be colossal.

But our doubts go further. We in the Liberal and National parties are not satisfied that the proposal in the Democrats' statement is accurately costed. My colleague the honourable member for Mayo, Mr Downer, recently put out a press statement attacking Senator Haines's promise on housing interest rates calling it a popular stunt. On the question of the interest rebate for housing mortgages-the average rebate being, say, $20 a week-the honourable member pointed out that the annual cost throughout the community could well be over $1.6 billion, even at current interest rates, based on $1.6 billion worth of dwellings purchased by income units, as recorded in the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1988 housing survey. That compares with the Democrats estimate of $200m-some eight times greater. Just on these two proposals we are saying that, instead of $1.1 billion-already a highly significant figure-the Democrats proposals could well cost $2.7 billion. If there is anything that could be described as populist and political, it has to be the Democrats proposal to throw, in a quite irresponsible way, $2.7 billion at people in the form of these tax benefits in order to gain support at the polls.

Just to give some idea of the dimension of those two issues taken together, let us consider that the Government, in its latest announcements last month concerning tax cuts to apply from 1 July, said that the total cost of those would be $5.7 billion. This proposal from the Democrats would cost a little under half of that, which was already most significant. It is a far more costly proposal than this country could possibly afford. It is obviously not one that we could responsibly support.

During the second reading debate the Democrats answered that point by saying that more money would be available at lower interest rates through the savings proposal, that interest rates would fall and that people would therefore be able to buy more houses. As we pointed out earlier, these proposals would probably have the effect merely of directing funds from existing institutions, existing investments, into these new Democrat-designated institutions offering special tax benefits. As we have described, that would have other consequences, in the main not of direct benefit to those people whom the Democrats would like to see benefiting. In the digest of the Bill there is support for this point:
Unless there is a noticeable change in the level of total savings, and assuming demand remains constant, there will be little impact on interest rates through such a proposal.

I think that that sums it up. It is quite clear-and this comes from an independent source in the Parliamentary Library; we do not have to rely on the words of the Liberal and National parties-that that proposal is subject to very serious question. As usual, the Democrats are using populist rhetoric in an attempt to attract support for Senator Haines's campaign in Kingston, South Australia, rather than supporting their case by sound analysis-let alone providing some kind of financial statement using proper methods to show how they come to their conclusions. I have moved the amendment that would require this matter to be referred to the Senate Committee. That would be the best solution for the Senate to adopt, and we urge all her senators to support it.

In respect of the Income Tax Assessment (Housing Loan Interest) Amendment Bill, I want now to foreshadow an amendment in the same form as our amendment to the savings account interest Bill. It draws attention to the same problems and seeks to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The housing loan interest Bill would allow a rebate on the component of mortgage interest above 10 per cent per year for the first $80,000 of loans for first homes. We appreciate the problems that have been created by this Government for home finance borrowers. Quite significantly, that is a function of this Government's mismanagement of the economy. We are very sympathetic about the problems of those who cannot buy houses because of price rises and their inability to meet repayment responsibilities. Nevertheless, this kind of issue cannot be solved very easily by this kind of reaction-the examination of which can be described as having been incomplete. It is true that this Bill is very similar to the system that was introduced by the Fraser Government in 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been recycled.
—Yes, it has been recycled, but there is a major difference.
—Recycling has become very popular around here.
—I think I shall ignore that remark.
—A kind of retirement to the back benches.

—It is a possibility. The Fraser Government's income tax law had a sunset clause. There was a definite period. It did not offer the open-ended kind of relief that is envisaged in this legislation. We cannot support the Democrats' open-ended proposals. We therefore believe that the best solution is to send the question to the Senate Committee for proper examination and, later, report. It is quite possible, that, upon receipt of that report-an examination having been carried out in some significant detail-the Senate would be able to devise suitable legislation to put before the Government which the government might adopt in the lower House as a means of assisting people facing significant financial difficulty in the purchasing of homes. I believe that the issue could be thrashed out very effectively in that forum to provide the kind of basis which, unfortunately, the Democrats have omitted in the presentation of this legislation today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I officially represent the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this place I feel that I should say a few words. The two Bills which are before the Senate are the Income Assessment (Savings Accounts Interest) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Income Tax Assessment (Housing Loan Interest) Amendment Bill 1988. The first observation I want to make about them is that they are basically mutually contradictory. The first Bill purports to increase national savings. I will go into the reasons why it will not. But that is its stated purpose. The second Bill would unequivocally lead to dis-saving, or a lower savings effort, because of the revenue which would be forgone without any offsets or any possibility of offsets. Senator Messner has put an estimate on that of $1.6 billion. It is something that is very hard to cost but I would not argue too strongly against his estimate that there would be a dis-saving of $1.6 billion. Of course, it is just another piece of Australian Democrat populist posturing-the application of the magic pudding theory of politics to the business of trying to harvest votes in Kingston in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: The first Bill provides for a limited amount of tax exemption for interest paid at 12 per cent or less by institutions which lend money for housing. It is possible that that would reduce housing interest rates, although how it is proposed to ensure that all the funds lent to an institution would be on lend for housing purposes let alone on lend at significantly lower rates-a point that Senator Messner has made-is a matter for wide-eyed conjecture. If it reduced interest rates, there would be a direct cost in providing a hidden subsidy to house borrowers at a cost to the Budget and probably in a much less effective way than would otherwise be possible.

But it would not increase aggregate saving for a number of reasons: First, 40 per cent of Australian householders already have undischarged housing mortgages. For people in that situation the option is already open to repay their mortgages more rapidly and thereby achieve the same personal benefits-if they have personal savings from investment-that this Bill would provide. Secondly, those who have undischarged credit card liabilities on which interest is being charged have exactly the same opportunities. Thirdly, the self-employed and some non-self-employed who are currently paying less than $3,000 a year into a personal cover superannuation scheme also have the same opportunity to invest in an almost tax-free investment. It will not affect or have any influence on the investment effort of taxpayers who already receive more than $2,000 in interest payments, nor will it affect the behaviour of taxpayers below the threshold. When we put all those things together-people with housing mortgages; people with undischarged credit card obligations on which interest is being charged; a large number of self-employed; taxpayers with more than $2,000 of interest; and taxpayers below the threshold-we have the vast majority of the Australian population, the savings decisions of whom will not be affected whatsoever by this proposal.

In addition, we have target savers; that is, people who are running some sort of investment account in order to buy a car, an overseas trip or some other consumer durable. The fact that interest earned in that account would be tax free would bring forward the purchase of the item and, therefore, bring forward or increase total consumption; again, another result directly opposed to the ostensible purpose of this Bill. However, on the present volume and pattern of savings the concession will cost $1.2 billion in revenue. In other words, on the present volume and present patterns, public saving will be reduced by $1.2 billion if this legislation is passed.

However, the present pattern of cash investment would not last for a number of reasons. Many of those receiving more than $2,000 in interest payments will split their deposits in order to get a double benefit for the tax-free $2,000 of interest receipts. Revenue losses which will induce further revenue losses-that is, lower savings efforts in the public sector-will not be matched by any savings increase in the private sector. Those with cash investments presently in other institutions-institutions other than those named in the Bill-will shift their investment, at least to the extent that it enables them to get the benefit of the $2,000 tax free interest income. That will lead to further revenue losses and, therefore, to further dis-saving in the public sector with no offsetting increase in private savings.

The bottom line of all that is that the net effect of this legislation would be to induce a lower total savings effort in the country because the public dis-savings it would bring on would certainly not be matched by the possibility of there being some increase in savings effort by a small minority of people in the private sector. Of course, Senator Stone was well aware of this when he wrote for publication in the Sunday Telegraph last Sunday:
Thus we have various bright ideas being canvassed (including by some Opposition members who ought to know better) about so-called incentives for saving.

Senator Stone went on to say that most of them are intellectually disrespectable, and he is absolutely right. The popular impression that Australia has a low household savings ratio, or even a low total savings ratio, by world standards is not entirely correct. Indeed, the household savings ratio in Australia is much higher than in comparable countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States of America. We have a very high level of investment which would require a high domestic savings effort in order to be matched from internal sources. Our private savings effort is inadequate by quite a large margin to support the investment program currently being undertaken. To offset that deficiency in the private sector requires public sector saving and a continuing and substantial Commonwealth Budget surplus. That is a policy that the Government will continue to apply.

In the rhetoric that has attached to this second reading debate, the Democrats-as usual-purport to be looking after the little people. Senator Haines, who presented this legislation, has previously used her vote to allow tax evaders, such as the Kelly brothers and their cherry-picker scheme, to walk away with millions of what I regard as stolen taxpayers' money-ostensibly because she was absolutely committed to the principle of not voting for legislation which had a retrospective impact. That same Senator Haines, towards the end of last year, moved an amendment to Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3) which gave it a retrospective application.

As I have already said, and as Senator Messner has acknowledged, the second Bill recycles a 1982 Fraser Government piece of vote bait. Senator Haines claims that it will assist those most in need. In fact, it is extremely poorly targeted and provides that interest payments above 10 per cent on the first $80,000 of any loan will be allowed as a tax deduction no matter when the loan was taken out. The loan may have been taken out 10 years ago. At that time an $80,000 loan would have bought a luxury or near luxury home in most Australian capital cities.

Many of the loans were taken out more than 10 years ago. The people who have had loans for a considerable length of time have enjoyed that benefit, firstly, of a declining outstanding debt in real terms and, therefore, a declining interest payment to service the interest component of that debt. In addition, they are protected if they have bank loans by the grandfathering of the 13 1/2 per cent interest ceiling. It is an extremely poorly targeted measure, the costs of which are difficult to estimate with any precision. As I said earlier, I do not wish to quarrel too much with the $1.6 billion figure that Senator Messner suggested. There is no magic pudding. The magic pudding theory might be all right for those people who never expect that they will have to accept the responsibility of being in government and putting a Budget together. No concoctions of this type can be made available to one section of the community without imposing a penalty on some other section.

The Opposition knows very well that these two Bills are pieces of nonsense and they ought to be thrown out of the Senate at the second reading stage. It has chosen the intermediate or non-committal course of moving to refer them to a Senate committee. The Government will not support that move because it is a waste of taxpayers' resources, both those resources that are funded within the Parliament and, of course, the Public Service which will be called upon to supply submissions and information to the Committee. It is a waste of resources and a waste of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a certain amount of sanctimony and silliness this evening. Before I reply to Senator Maguire, I should like to make a response to Senator Walsh who, in his brief discussion on this legislation, complained that there was no time limit on the applicability of the tax concession to own-home buyers, that is, he complained that this concession would go back into the dim distant past and that people would obtain a benefit to which they were not entitled.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Walsh that, of course, that is what applies to the Government's negative gearing scheme and, what is worse in that scheme, there is no limit on the interest rate paid, for which people can obtain a deduction, nor is there a limit on the amount they can borrow for which they can enjoy some sort of tax concession. I am finding it a little extraordinary that Senator Walsh of all people should say that he will not support this legislation because it is basically flawed in an area which is an integral part of the Government's negative gearing scheme.

People who buy into the investment housing market at any level at all are able to get a total tax concession for it, not a partial tax concession, not a concession that is limited by the interest rate and not a concession that is limited by the amount of money borrowed. I am afraid that the comments of Senator Walsh were sanctimonious, silly and rather hypocritical.

For half an hour Senator Maguire delivered essentially a history of the Australian Democrats. He said it was very easy for the Democrats to parade around Australia in addition to parading around the Senate chamber suggesting tax cuts, concessions and so on. He said that we will never have to be in government; yet we are here putting up these proposals. I remind Senator Maguire and anybody else who wants to advance this argument that `the Democrats will never be in government and therefore it is easy for us to take these populist lines', in fact, we are part of the governing body in Australia. This Parliament consists of two chambers. Both of them have equal rights or virtually equal rights over legislation, and amending government legislation is as integral a part of being in government as taking the benches opposite is. We are as answerable for our actions as any other member in this chamber. We are part of government by dint of power and the position we hold in the Senate and we are prepared to stand on a daily basis and accept that.

We do not do what the Liberals do and see some specious difference between Budget Bills and all other legislation; so most of the legislation goes through because the Liberal Party supports the Government's legislation. The Australian Democrats look at legislation on its merits, whether it is our own or somebody else's, and at amendments whether they are our own or somebody else's, and vote accordingly. If that is not part of being in government and accountable, I do not know what it is.

Senator Maguire also suggested this was a ploy in my campaign bid for Kingston. That goes to show how little he knows not only about the campaign in Kingston but also the history of this legislation. One of these two Bills was introduced for the first time in 1981, the second time in 1983 and the third time in 1984. Even I was not contemplating a move from the Senate to the House of Representatives at that stage. It is very easy to sling these sorts of remarks around the chamber when a senator is as ignorant of the processes of this place as Senator Maguire obviously is.

Senator Maguire and other senators should accept that the fact of the matter is that people out there are hurting because of the policies of this Government and the approval, through the legislative process, that the Opposition has given this Government in areas of deregulation and foreign investment, in the approval that the Opposition has given to the Government whenever cutting expenditure in social welfare areas has occurred and where easing tax on the corporate sector has occurred.

It is no good Senator Maguire, Senator Messner and Senator Walsh saying that we must increase the amount of public saving. We are cutting revenue in this place all the time through the coalition between the Government and the Opposition in encouraging companies to pay as little tax as possible and not giving any sort of break to the ordinary Australian individuals or families. The fact is that the playing field in Australia is not level as it is in most other countries for people who invest in housing and people who want to buy a home for themselves and their children.

In the United States of America and Great Britain, home owners can get a tax concession. In Australia it is only investors in the housing market who can get a tax concession. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that, since the Labor Government, with the support of the Opposition, reintroduced negative gearing for investors in the real estate market, we have seen a massive change in the percentages of homes bought by the three groups who buy houses in Australia-the first home buyers, investors, and people who are selling one home and buying another. It should not surprise any honourable senator to learn that the proportion that has increased significantly since then is the proportion of the market going to investors. If Senator Walsh is concerned about an increase in the building industry, he has to look to his own policies and the part played in home purchases by investors as the cause.

We support equity. Senator Maguire carried on a treat about the need for all of this sort of thing to be equitable. It currently is not equitable. It is not equitable when it comes to purchasing homes. It is not equitable in many other tax areas. It was in fact our commitment to tax equity that led the Australian Democrats to support the Government's capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax legislation, Bills which the Opposition parties opposed at the time. Senator Maguire said that the Fraser Government bribed the voters by offering a tax rebate for home buyers. Yet the Australian Labor Party (ALP), which supported that original Fraser Government legislation, took it away from everyone but investors. I do know know who is bribing whom but I certainly do know who is not concerned with equity. The people who are not concerned with equity in this place are the two major parties. Investors are able to get a tax deduction but home buyers cannot. `Tax concessions', said Senator Maguire, `are bad. They lead to tax rorts. They lead to people avoiding their tax commitments. They lead to an inability by government to raise revenue. They decrease public savings'.

Apparently it does not bother Senator Maguire or anybody in the coalition parties either that we offer tax concessions to the corporate welfare sector hand over fist. Why does he suppose that the Alan Bonds of this world have been able to get their tax payments down to nothing, and at a time of a nominal company tax rate of 49c in the dollar? Now that, thanks to the Opposition supporting the Government's legislation, the company tax rate has gone down to 39c in the dollar, I presume that people such as Alan Bond will be getting taxpayers to pay money back to them.

The ALP has done nothing at all to end corporate welfare and has attacked ordinary Australian families as well as the social welfare sector instead. It has cut company tax by 20 per cent from 49c to 39c in the dollar, at a cost of $2 billion last year. It complains now about a piece of legislation of ours that would spend $1 billion-half the amount spent on companies-on hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australian families who cannot benefit from negative gearing and who do not benefit from the sorts of concessions that this Government and this Opposition have offered companies enthusiastically, although there is no perceptible benefit to the community at large by way of additional jobs, additional export markets or export replacement items.

The first home owners scheme that Senator Maguire got so enthusiastic about has had the heart cut out of it by this Government and it helps fewer people than the legislation before the Parliament today would. There was a lot of talk from Senator Maguire about the megarich benefiting. Certainly Labor Party policies to date have acted to help the megarich unless Senator Maguire believes that Alan Bond, John Elliott, Robert Holmes a Court and John Spalvins et al are not among the megarich but are among the deserving poor, which I find a little difficult to swallow.

Frankly, I do not care if a few of the megarich get $2,000 tax free, as long as savings increase and interest rates decrease as a consequence. I do not mind if the mega-rich subsidise the interest rates of ordinary Australian families who currently cannot afford to pay mortgage levels that they are confronting because of high interest rates. Senator Maguire carefully overlooked the fact that this $2,000 of interest tax free would be of particular help to pensioners, especially those who find themselves faced with a provisional tax payment once their interest hits $1,000. It would certainly be a more equitable way of going about encouraging savings than indexation, which has been put about by the Liberals courtesy of that intellectual giant Alexander Downer, which will help most those people who can afford to save most. Here is a system that will help the rich disproportionately to the less well off. I might add that Senator Maguire has never seen any need for consistency, having been, as I have said, perfectly happy to deny to revenue something like $2 billion through the company tax system.

There is an indisputable link between low levels of savings and high levels of interest rates. The greater the demand for money, the higher price the supplier of the money can charge for it. There is also a link between high consumer spending and a huge trade imbalance, given that large amounts of the expenditure go on imported goods. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is saying that because of these things, because of the link between low savings and high interest rates, because of the link between high consumer spending and our trade imbalance, people should be encouraged to save and not spend. Why should they when there is no incentive to save, when half the money they earn in interest goes in tax? Of course, they will not do it. A broad-based consumption tax is not the solution either because it will hit hardest those who can least afford it.

The most important thing we need to remember, however, in all of this is that, as a recent piece of research by BIS Shrapnel shows, more than 1 1/2 million Australians will be inadequately housed if the current trend continues. If that is not enough to liven up Senator Maguire, I do not know what is. Senator Messner in his contribution said, `Yes, there is a need to encourage savings and help home buyers'. He castigated the ALP for the proposals that it had introduced to put the country into the parlous economic state that it is currently in, forgetting how much help he and his National Party colleagues have given the Government in doing just that.

He said that the Democrats' proposal, in concept at least, was on the right track in wanting to encourage savings in order to cut reliance on foreign money. However, while the Opposition liked the principle, it did not like the method. If we spent time in this place looking for the perfect method to do anything, we would never get anything done. Right at the moment we have a lot of people out there hurting badly. We are now quibbling in here about whether it is better to give the first $2,000 tax free or whether it is better to do it by a cumbersome accounting method of indexing for inflation. I am sorry to see the dearth of speakers on the list to debate this Bill. Certainly there do not seem to be too many people on either side of the chamber who are interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Haines said that there was a dearth of speakers on both sides on this Bill. May I point out to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we were especially asked by the Democrats to get this legislation to a vote today and we have done everything we could to accommodate them. Senator Messner was our only speaker, on the undertaking that we gave that we would do our best to see that the Democrats got their Bills to a vote. So it is not for the Leader of the Democrats to come in here and start telling us that we are not taking any interest in her Bills or participating in the debate.
—Technically, there is no point of order.

—That did not alter the fact that, instead of hearing from Senator Messner a half an hour monologue which said nothing, we may have been able to hear 15 minutes from him and 15 minutes from Senator Short, who might have had something more intelligent to say, coming out of Treasury, as he apparently does. Senator Messner said that he was not sure whether savings would increase. However, he did not give any particular reason for holding that belief. He thinks savings would be redirected from existing investments to low interest accounts. Great. That is precisely what I would like to see happen, at least as part of the result of this legislation. If people take their money out of 15 per cent accounts and put it into 12 per cent accounts, the lending interest rate must also come down. That will be enormously beneficial to those people who are finding that they cannot afford to pay their mortgages or who see no point at all in saving money because they will never meet the deposits.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner said that piecemeal measures are ineffective. That is how this place operates. One should look at the number of amending Bills that come into this place. He said that we need to look at all the issues in the area, such as exemption of interest up to a certain amount with eligibility criteria, also a withholding tax of 15 per cent instead of the top rate. Why will these not lead to the so-called fatal flaws that he says are in my Bills? We had no explanation of that from Senator Messner. He said that we needed to look at the application of a tax only on the real value of interest after inflation was taken into account. That would produce a much more inequitable system than the one we have put forward. He says that we need to be informed about all of this and that it should all go to a committee. He has duly moved an amendment to that effect. We are not going to watch our Bills being defeated by the process of sending the issues to a committee. If Senator Messner wants to move tomorrow to send the issues to a committee we will cheerfully support him, but we want him to acknowledge that the Opposition is opposing two ways of helping Australian families under the guise of getting more information about the issues. There is plenty of information about the issues out there. We can have a look at what the Swedish Government is currently doing by way of compulsory savings and we can have a look at how successful the Japanese Government was in the last 40 years by not taxing savings at all and providing low interest loans for investment. There are plenty of ways of getting the information without denying for a further year or more the sort of assistance that ordinary Australian families need.

`Populist' is a word that has come up all over the place tonight. I have news for Senator Maguire and Senator Messner, who use it as if it were a pejorative term. The populace do not necessarily see anything wrong with a populist move coming up in this place; in fact, they would rather like it to happen from time to time. Instead of this chamber and the other place dealing only with what is good for big business, for foreign investors and for big investors, we got around to dealing with something that was in the interests of the populace; that is, was populist. Maybe we would see some significant changes to equity in this country; maybe we would see wealth distributed a little more fairly; and maybe we would not see 50,000 young people homeless.

We have to face up to a few questions in this place. Either we want tax equity or we do not; either we want to help ordinary families in the same way that we help wealthy companies or investors or we do not; and either we want to encourage savings or we do not. Frankly the Democrats want all those things. The vote on these Bills will tell us whether the Liberal, National and Labor parties want these things too.
Amendment negatived.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

upon which Senator Stone had moved by way of amendment:
At the end of motion, add `` but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's betrayal of the wheat farmers of Australia;
(b) condemns the Government for weakening the position of the Australian Wheat Board as a strong trader in the domestic wheat market; and
(c) regrets the Government's failure to negotiate adequately with State Governments over their respective responsibilities, including in regard to State statutory marketing authorities''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wheat Bills have led to a wide-ranging debate throughout Australia and much soul-searching by wheat growers, not least in my own State of South Australia where, for some 12 months, the Kerin package, as first proposed, was greatly debated in rural centres. Since that time there have been significant modifications to the original package of proposals and we have now before us the wheat legislation. From the outset I want to condemn the way in which the Government through the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has sought at every opportunity to play politics with this important industry. It may be that the Australian Labor Party is cynical about its very limited support in country areas. Whether we in this chamber can be cynical or not, it is the case that the Labor Government has not shown that it has at heart the interests of the industry, or the wheat growers and their families in rural areas. Rather it has tried to catch out the members of the Liberal and National parties who do have those industries, those growers and those families at heart.

SPEECH.PARA: At various points over the past six months the heartfelt concerns expressed by me, as a Liberal, and many of my colleagues in the coalition, have led us to be quite searching in our comments about the Kerin package. We have been aware that the Government failed to win the support of the industry and thus there have been many dialogues, meetings and deputations. Liberal and National Party senators and members have taken those discussions most seriously and have tried to understand the views being put forward by wheat growers. It is understandable that the Press and public observers have seen some tensions while we have tried to work out what exact form of amendments to the wheat package as proposed by the Government will be supportable by the main body of the industry and in the best interests of this country.

Even now there are some private judgments amongst my colleagues as to where that burden of amendment should lie. As is the case in any matter coming before the coalition, eventually all of those discussions percolate to a policy stand and a formal concluding debate and decision. The decision that concluded that 12 months of debate was the statement of our primary industry policy of 4 April this year which was adopted unanimously in the coalition. As it is a brief and quite formal public statement, Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave for this public statement of policy to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

As part of the restructuring and reform of the Australian economy, the Coalition is committed to the completion of the deregulation of the domestic wheat market. So that the burdens of restructuring are fairly shared, this deregulation should occur in conjunction with progress being achieved in certain areas which impinge on that market and which are mentioned below.

In addition, the Coalition is absolutely committed to all possible action being taken to minimise the impact on the domestic wheat market of extreme corruption in world wheat markets. This goal should be pursued in concert with the commitment to deregulation of the domestic wheat market.
The Coalition believes that complete deregulation of the domestic wheat market should proceed in conjunction with:

reasonable progress towards deregulation in the transport, handling, storage and waterfront areas to reduce the many cost burdens placed upon wheat growers by high levels of regulation, restrictive work practices and anti-market abuses in those areas;
a 95% underwriting guarantee to provide a satisfactory first advance or cash trading option for the Wheat Board;
the maintenance of the Wheat Board's existing powers in relation to exports; and
the Board having the capacity to remain a strong trader competing on fair and reasonable terms with other domestic traders.
Any legislation presented by the Government will be assessed against the position set out in the preceding paragraph.

If the Hawke Government is seriously committed to deregulation of the domestic wheat market on fair and reasonable terms, it will present a legislative package in accordance with the criteria we have set out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This conclusion is a genuine compromise on all of the representations that Liberal-National Party members brought to this concluding debate, taking into account all that we had heard and all that we had come to understand about the dimensions of the debate. There is an enormous priority in this country for micro-economic reform, for deregulation, for getting away from each industry in Australia a clutter that adds cost, or for removing barriers that restrict the choice of various elements in an industry. So, this was a major consideration in coming to this compromise statement. On the other hand, there is a legitimate concern expressed by any one industry to ensure that it is not being singled out to have some new heat of the marketplace, or some change from an orderly marketing system, thrust upon it in the name of the highly commendable micro-economic reform, if that is not going to be fully able to be coped with by that industry in the short term, or if it is unfairly a pressure being put upon that industry, but not all.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement which I have had incorporated in Hansard and which is the policy of the coalition, after a preamble, concentrates upon four criteria for the deregulation of the domestic wheat market. These are four criteria which all coalition members support. The first is that there should be reasonable progress towards deregulation in the transport, handling, storage and waterfront areas to reduce the many cost burdens placed upon wheat growers by high levels of regulation, restrictive work practices and anti-market abuses in those areas. Of course, we want to reduce the cost burdens upon wheat growers.

Let me give one example: In my State of South Australia, growers have a free choice, without restrictions, as to the form of transport that they use to take grain to a port. They can use their own truck to take their wheat 200 kilometres, say, to Port Lincoln, or they can use their own truck to take it five kilometres to, say, Woodener, to a silo, and there the silo, through the cooperative bulk handling company, transports the wheat by rail to Port Lincoln. Or they can contract a trucking firm to take their wheat either the short distance or the long distance. There is a free choice and in fact it is a market choice for the grower. If his vehicle is not strong enough or efficient enough to bear the strain of the long distance, he will choose to take on a trucking company. If he thinks, because of his proximity to a rail head, that there is a genuine advantage in using rail, he will use rail.

This is not the case in New South Wales, not only with regard to transport in these elements but also at the waterfront. There are barriers to the free and efficient use of the waterfront in New South Wales. In fact, I will come later on to some very sharp contrasts in other areas of grain handling between my State of South Australia, which is so very well developed-it has probably the best grain handling system in the world-and the eastern States such as New South Wales. Clearly, there is a pressing urgency to gain deregulation on the waterfront and in transport and other areas, such as we have outlined in that first criterion and, I must say, particularly in the eastern States.

Let me say something about storage. Even as a South Australian senator, who on perhaps only a couple of occasions a year, drives through the countryside in New South Wales and Victoria, compared with my 20 to 50 times in South Australia, I have seen, over many years now, temporary grain storage in New South Wales. On the side of the road, in someone's paddock, will be a great heap of grain lying on tarpaulins on the ground, with a tarpaulin on top and some car tyres holding it down. It looks highly temporary and one wonders whether or not the grain industry is in the twentieth century. Whereas, in my State of South Australia the growers themselves have paid for a $1 billion silo storage system which is systematically all over rural areas. We have a very large grain belt in my State and every town one goes to has its large silos. It is, as I say, the most efficient and best established infrastructure for grain storage and handling anywhere in the world. I commend the growers of my State of South Australia that this is the case, that they have achieved this. Moreover, no-one can allege that there is one government dollar in it. At no stage did the growers of South Australia gain one dollar from the State Government or from the Commonwealth Government-not one dollar from the taxpayers generally-to pay for that silo system.
