I am rising now to speak on this debate in support of Senator Lewis and also in support of Senator Stone, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, whose amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's betrayal of the wheat farmers of Australia;
(b) condemns the Government for weakening the position of the Australian Wheat Board as a strong trader in the domestic wheat market; and
(c) regrets the Government's failure to negotiate adequately with State Governments over their respective responsibilities, including in regard to State statutory marketing authorities''.

The three points in Senator Stone's amendment have been clearly brought to the fore in this debate. The main feature of the legislation is to remove the Australian Wheat Board's acquisition and price setting power for the wheat for domestic human consumption. The Bills retain the Board's export monopoly, reduce the underwriting guarantee from the current 95 per cent to 90 per cent next season and then phase it down to 80 per cent in 1993, after which this part of the legislation will cease to exist any more-it will be subject to a sunset provision. The major Bill-the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989-gives the Board the ability to negotiate better rail freight arrangements with the use of the export power. Clause 88 provides the Federal Minister with the ability to override or even terminate State commodity marketing authorities other than wheat. This, of course, was the subject of considerable opposition by the States and has now been amended due to the good work of Mr Bruce Lloyd in the other House.

I cannot pretend to like this legislation and I do not; neither do the overwhelming majority of wheat growers in Australia. Before I go any further, I might just say that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) spoke earlier in the debate and quoted some figures. The figures that Senator Walsh gave in respect of underwriting are completely wrong. They are misleading to the Parliament. I now seek leave to table the figures that I have.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The actual payout for 1986-87 on the three-year moving average formula of the 1984 Act was $140m in nominal terms. Therefore, how can the Minister say that there has been an increase in liability of some $300m in the subject year? The Minister told us that he was a fellow wheat grower; that he was one of the few people in this place to grow wheat. I might add that I grow wheat. I know that Senator Stone grew wheat. Senator Panizza grows wheat. Senator McGauran, who has a lot of other enterprises, also grows wheat. The Minister said that $300m would be necessary. In fact in 1986-87, the year he talks about, there would have been no payout whatsoever up to 99.8 per cent of the guaranteed minimum price. I would imagine that the Minister will tell us more about that in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is flawed; it is inappropriate in that it takes no account of present marketing arrangements; and I believe it is a political stunt. The wheat growers of Australia are the jokers and are being used as playing chips in this big battle by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and other people in the Australian Labor Party. Little has been said about the role of the Minister and I notice that his advisers are in the chamber tonight. I hope that Senator Walsh tells the Minister what he might hear in this debate. If he does, we might get a heap more amendments from the Minister before it is all finished. I notice that an amendment brought in by the Government was circulated here a little while ago. Maybe the Government is starting to see the light that the legislation is not well drafted in the first instance.

The current arrangements were due to expire in June 1989. This date has been known for five years. In the meantime, the Government conducted an Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) hearing into the industry. The McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport has presented a report. Those bodies made certain recommendations as to where the industry ought to be heading. McColl actually said, and I think this is very pertinent, that the identified savings are achievable with the existing marketing arrangements. So why is the Minister trying to change the whole thing and turn it on its head? Last July Mr Kerin flagged his intentions on the legislation to State Ministers for agriculture at a meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council. But they were not along the lines suggested by McColl or the IAC. In fact, the IAC, on page 6 of its report, said:
Difficulties may also arise in negotiations that would have to take place between the Commonwealth and State governments.

What has he done about it? He has not put that in the legislation or talked to the State governments about it. He has just gone ahead in his own bulldozing way with the wheat growers of Australia, as I said, being used as chips in this debate.

The States asked for more details when this legislation first was mooted and said that they would not pass complementary legislation without changes being made to the Bill. They asked again in February of this year for more details and more changes. The information and changes have not been forthcoming. As early as 12 July last year the New South Wales agricultural Minister, Ian Armstrong, rejected the Kerin wheat plan. A press release stated:

New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Ian Armstrong, today rejected the Kerin proposals for the restructuring of the wheat marketing arrangements. Mr Kerin would do well to listen to the industry as a whole on the matter and act according to what is best for the industry, and not the Federal Government bureaucracy. To open the doors to the commercial wolves would mean that producers' returns will once again return to negative figures. It is time for cool heads in the management of the Australian wheat crop, Mr Armstrong said.
And, of course, what has happened since then? Mr Armstrong repeated his objections as recently as February of this year in a press release which stated:

The New South Wales Government has expressed disappointment that full advice on Commonwealth wheat marketing legislation will now be delayed until mid-March, State Agriculture and Rural Affairs Minister Armstrong said.
He slammed the delay which he said only fuelled more uncertainty within the industry and jeopardised forward planning.
Just ask a few of the wheat growers. The press release continued:

Mr Armstrong and Queensland Primary Industries Minister, Mr Harper, both rejected outright today any complementary State legislation which could water down the export domestic marketing powers of the Australian Wheat Board.
The press release went on to say:
It is clear that if the Federal Minister continues on his present path, the domestic wheat market could end up under legal challenge.
What has happened about that? Has the Minister really made an outright effort to go to the States and talk this over with them? I should say he has not.

We sit here in the chamber at the moment debating this legislation on the day the New South Wales Parliament is due to rise for the winter break; the South Australian Parliament has already got up. There is no complementary legislation in place in any State. Victoria is talking about it today; there can be nothing done in South Australia because the South Australian Parliament has already risen; and the New South Wales Government has Buckley's chance of enacting legislation before it rises. The effect of this is going to weaken the capacity of the Australian Wheat Board to operate on a domestic market in a competitive manner. To exclude the Wheat Board-and Senator Stone made this very clear in his speech yesterday-from intrastate trading will make it ineffective and leave it open to the major grain traders. It will not be able, under the current legislation, to trade intrastate in a way which will make it competitive on the market. Senator Stone mentioned that there is a misleading paragraph in the second reading speech presented by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook). That paragraph reads:

The essential point is that compulsory acquisition is no longer needed for efficient marketing effort. I am confident that the AWB will remain the dominant force in a deregulated domestic market given its expertise and the additional commercial powers which I outlined earlier.
Tell me, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you can, how it can remain competitive, how it can remain as the dominant force on a domestic market, if it has had its legs cut out from underneath it.

The Minister cannot tell us. I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would like to tell me, but you cannot. I know that the Minister's adviser has now left the chamber. Obviously he has gone to find out how it is going to be done. Let us hope he can do it because if he cannot we will be in a lot of trouble. Senator Cook might help. He is into resources; maybe he might be able to help. He will say, `Look, it's not my fault. This is the fault of these State governments'. I say that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy stands condemned for trying to foist this on the Australian wheat growers without doing his homework and making sure that the whole lot is going to work properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook will help-his guess is as good as any!

—That is right. Senator Panizza is a wheat grower; he knows a bit about it. The Minister is engaging in political stunts. This legislation is flawed in a number of ways. In passing, I note that even in the passage of this legislation through the House of Representatives the Government found it necessary to tack on 45 amendments-this has been mentioned a few times-to the original draft. After all the time it has had to produce this legislation, the Government is still amending it a few weeks before it must be in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to some of the principles enshrined in the legislation. The first is the issue of deregulation. I have often said that I think the wheat market is deregulated now. We have direct delivery to the Australian Wheat Board. We have the grower to buyer method or grower to miller method, whereby we can negotiate a premium for handling and storage and transport costs. Last year we sold our wheat direct to the millers. We sold some to the Wheat Board at the local silo. We had some feed wheat; so we sold that wheat to a feed lot. We had other options. We could have stored some with the grain handling authority for payment at a later date. Also, we could store some on our own farm. So there is quite a bit of deregulation in that respect. I say that the market is pretty well deregulated already. So why do we have to take away the little bit of stability that the industry had by completely deregulating? I believe that deregulation is going to expose the industry to the corrupt world stage.

We have seen in the last week the United States' attitude to freeing up of trade, particularly in respect of grains. The Americans can see no danger to Australia of their protectionist policies. They applaud our moves to open up world trade and at the same time they subsidise sales of wheat to Russia. There are rumours of similar subsidised deals going to China. Australian wheat growers are already the lowest paid in the Western world. They are that way because they receive no hand outs and no government subsidies. They are not complaining about that, but I believe it is unfair. They sell their wheat on the world market against subsidised grain from the European Community and the United States. In 1985-86 we had nearly 20 per cent of the world wheat trade and flour trade. Today that has dropped to somewhere around 11.3 per cent. The European Community and the United States shares have jumped during that same period because of export subsidies. How can Australia compete with that? This legislation, I believe, will penalise them even further.
At present the price of wheat sold to Australian millers is set by the best export price paid based on the need for quality wheat and the continuity of supply.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are getting the best wheat; they should pay the best price.

—That is right. But under this legislation, this floor price, which is presently around about $225 per tonne, would be removed and the effective floor price would become the average export price which stands at around about $190 a tonne. After allowing for quality differences, the main reason for taking the best export price is that a high percentage of Australia's wheat is sold on the Egyptian, Chinese and Russian markets which meet the price of United States wheat subsidised under that country's export enhancement program.

SPEECH.PARA: This wheat industry, with which the Minister is playing Russian roulette, is in jeopardy. What is the Government doing about it? At a time of high interest rates, rising inflation and the removal of agricultural machinery bounties, the Government says to the growers, `Take less for your grain; you'll be better off with this arrangement'.

The Government claims that what growers lose on the difference between the best export and average-around about $10 a tonne-they will more than make up with the savings in grain handling, storage and transportation as a result of inefficiencies being removed from that system. They are very nice sounding words, but I believe that actions speak louder than words. We have already seen prices falling in other grain crops. I know that sorghum prices at the moment have fallen from something around $140 a tonne to $125 a tonne. The weaker seller syndrome is starting to set in in anticipation of a deregulated domestic market. We cannot allow the market to become further weakened because, as farmers, we depend too much on it to remain solvent.

Deregulation of the industry must be accompanied by reform in other areas such as the waterfront, restrictive work practices and transport. Senator McKiernan talked a little about this matter earlier in the debate. Senator Cook knows a lot about industrial relations. But I want to see the whites of the eyes of the Government senators who are sitting on the other side of the chamber. I want them to tell me what they are going to do about a few of their little tricks instead of just picking on the wheat growers and saying, `You deregulate. We want you to deregulate. We'll do these things'. All we get is a few smart words. Nothing has happened at all up until this particular stage. As Senator Knowles has mentioned, we have to free-up such things as coastal shipping, and rail monopolies and the closed-shop network must end. The Government says it will do these things. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President: When? How can we believe a government which says it will deregulate transport and the waterfront when it cannot control the unions?

Where are all those agreements which Mr Hawke and Mr Kerin say they will have with the unions? Only last week in Victoria the Australian Railways Union was drumming up opposition to the legislation because it claimed that 1,050 rail jobs in Victoria alone would be lost. If that is the case, there must be a lot of feather bedding going on-and I think we would all agree on that. The fact is that for years the railways have had a monopoly on the transport of grain and they are not going to give it up very easily. It will be interesting to see whether the Government capitulates. I believe it will. There have already been suggestions that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has promised the Victorian unions some special sort of deal. That suggestion has been widely touted around the place. The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) has said as much in the Bendigo Advertiser. In that newspaper he assured the V/Line employees that their jobs were safe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, he has said that before.

—That is right. To me that does not sound much like efficiencies in the railways. What he is basically suggesting is that the good old Australian Labor Party will look after its union mates-as it has always done-irrespective of what cost that might be to the community at large or to the wheat growers. This can be shown from the Bill that we are talking about. The Government cannot deny any of the things that I have just mentioned. But if that were the case, what is the objection to our addition to clause 88? I will not read the whole clause, but I do mention these few words:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 45, after clause 88, insert the following new clause:
Deregulation of labour practices
`No, no', the Labor Party says, `we cannot vote for that. You cannot have that amendment; no, no, because it says things like:

(1) It is the intention of the Parliament that the Board and any corporation engaged in the storage, handling, transport or sale of grain for export shall, in regard to any matter connected with the storage, handling, transport or shipment of that grain:
(a) be entitled to take no cognisance of any agreement, undertaking or other
arrangement . . .'
I seek leave to have this proposed new clause incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The clause read as follows-
Deregulation of labour practices

``88a. (1) It is the intention of the Parliament that the Board and any corporation engaged in the storage, handling, transport or sale of grain for export shall, in regard to any matter connected with the storage, handling, transport, or shipment of that grain:

(a) be entitled to take no cognisance of any agreement, undertaking or other arrangement which requires the employment of any specified number of persons who are members of a trade union or similar society or association of persons, and any such agreement and undertaking or other arrangement shall be void;

(b) be exempt from the operation of any enactment of the Commonwealth or of any State or Territory which would otherwise require the employment, or the giving of preference in employment, to persons who are members of a trade union or of a similar society or association of persons;

(c) be entitled to enter into voluntary employment agreements or undertakings with any employee or groups of employees, and such agreements or undertakings will override any awards of the Industrial Relations Commission;
(d) be entitled to enter into any agreement, undertaking or arrangement, with any person or body in regard to the loading of any vessel and the manning of any loading apparatus; and

(e) be entitled to claim damages in the Federal Court of Australia or the High Court of Australia against any person, trade union or similar society or association or associations or persons for any amount equal to the amount of any loss of a financial or contractual nature caused by any action of that person, trade union, society or association of persons which disrupts the activities of the Board or corporation, as the case may be.
``(2) A natural person, trade union or similar society or association of persons contravening subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable upon conviction:
(a) in the case of a natural person-$10,000 and $1,000 for every day that the offence continues; or
(b) in the case of a trade union or similar society or association of persons-$100,000 and $10,000 for every day that the offence continues.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second issue, of course, is the overriding of States' rights. This issue is very important. Senator Stone has been the person who has made the most-I was going to say `noise', but I will not say `noise' because he speaks in a very nice, modulated voice-telling points in this part of the debate. The Government would have allowed this legislation to trammel the State functions in the areas of transport, storage and handling. That is one of the ineptitudes of this Bill. Are we to be grateful to the Government for accepting the Opposition's amendments? I ask that question because I am a bit concerned about this matter. As far as I can see, the Government would have allowed this situation to proceed if it had not been brought to its attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, of which I happen to be a member and of which Senator Cooney is the Chairman-he does a good job on it-is also very concerned about different clauses of the Bill. For example, let me mention clauses 7 (5), 88 (2) and 88 (10). The Committee said that there are inappropriate delegations of parliamentary power. Effectively, those clauses mean that people involved in the industry, and governed by State and Territory laws, may be adversely affected if that enactment were rendered ineffective by the making of a regulation. That is something I think the Government should seriously look at.

A total of 37 amendments were moved by the Opposition in the other place; some of less importance, others of greater importance. We have proposed 22 amendments, plus one, which is the amendment that Senator Stone will move and which I mentioned earlier in this chamber. To me there are several that are basic to the acceptance of this legislation. The first is the underwriting. I have already tabled a document showing what the underwriting means. The Opposition has made it clear that it wants 95 per cent underwriting. The Government has offered, so we are told, 90 per cent reducing to 80 per cent over three years. This has the effect of leaving the Wheat Board weakened.

The question of the composition of the Board has also not been addressed satisfactorily. The Opposition has insisted that the chairman be a wheat grower and this amendment has been moved in the other place. It is fundamentally the right of the industry, surely, to have its own chairman of its own industry. The same condition applies for a majority of growers on the Board and again that is not happening. Again the Opposition has moved to correct that anomaly.

This legislation has caused pain to a great many people and not just to the wheat grower. It has involved many hours, days and weeks of discussions. I know that Senator Stone mentioned an Opposition committee I was on. I was very happy to see in a press release that has been put out by the Grains Council of Australia those terms that we set down with the Opposition. I take exception to what Senator Walsh has said about the agro-politicians and the people who represent the industries. He does not say the same thing about the Australian Council of Trade Unions, mind you, does he? But if we have a group of people representing an industry, the Minister is up in arms and says, `They are just those agro-politicians and we do not take any notice of them.'

I think that everyone has put a lot of work into this Bill and, as I said, particularly the Grains Council of Australia. It is disgusting that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has left this legislation so late and ignored the request of the State Ministers, some even from his own Party, so that they are unable to pass complementary legislation in the States although, belatedly, it looks as if Victoria might be doing something about it. What so many commentators and five-minute experts on wheat have forgotten throughout this entire debate is that the wheat industry is not a supply and demand situation. The wheat industry has never been a supply and demand situation. It has always been ruled by manipulation and speculation. Those are not my remarks; they are the remarks that a gentleman called Don Barwick made many years ago when he was on the Wheat Board. He said, `The major grain traders are manipulators and speculators'.

This legislation is going to put at risk those 40-odd thousand wheat growers of Australia by throwing them to the wolves, the manipulators and the speculators, the big grain traders. I have a little bit of knowledge of this because I have been a grain grower now for some 35 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very successful one.

—Thank you very much. That is why I object. Frankly, I am more fortunate than many growers because I grow a variety of crops. I grow sorghum, sunflower, faba beans and a lot of other crops. But I object to this legislation.
—All products of the soil.

—That is right, they are all products of the soil, which was a part of the original legislation as Senator Stone points out. The grower who only grows wheat-the sole wheat grower-is going to be left cruelly exposed by a government that does not give a fig for his future. One other point I of course meant to mention was the greater control of the industry fund, that $100m fund that the Minister is setting up. The growers must have complete control of that. The other thing I would like to mention in finishing is that it is not often that one gets Kenneth Davidson writing something good about the National Party. I am going to get a plug in for the National Party. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not often your correspondent thinks the National Party has a case but it is not difficult to see that the interests of the mass of wheat growers are not being served by the Hawke Government's decision to deregulate domestic wheat sales.

Senator Richardson is always trying to say, `Let us lock things up, do not let us have production going on in Australia, do not let us have export income being produced'. Now one of his own colleagues here is putting this industry in jeopardy. I get back to Kenneth Davidson. At the end of his article he said that unless the bulk of Australia's wheat growers have untapped attributes in marketing their own wheat, the real beneficiaries of the deregulatory proposal are the middleman and the end user. That is what worries me about this legislation. People have set up a Wheat Board so that they can have a united way of selling their grain. In other words, instead of being multiple sellers to single buyers, they have set it up so they can become multiple sellers to only a few buyers and they can protect themselves. This Government is callously taking that protection away from the wheat growers of Australia and throwing them to the wolves, the international grain traders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I note the long list of speakers-and I have not had the opportunity to hear most of them, sadly-but I am moved to feel rather like Elizabeth Taylor's last husband. He knew exactly what he had to do, he was just trying to find a way to make it different and interesting. Let me say this: my own view is that deregulation of the domestic wheat market is by definition far from the most consequential micro-economic reform necessary to provide the levels of efficiency and reliable, certain and appropriate returns to both the growers and the consumers of our product. I have to say for my part that I get no pleasure, and find it frankly offensive, that the coalition even begins contemplating marching to the beat of the Labor drum. Yet this Government is serious, and not being political. If it is genuine--
—He is another agrarian socialist.
—At least he is a decent one.

—No, I am not. I do not believe in capitalising the profits and nationalising the losses and I say that as a person who had a significant interest in the rural economy at one stage and found it easier to be elsewhere.
—You could not hack the pace, I suppose.
—I could not keep awake reading the accounts.
—Whom did you vote for? That is what I want to know.
—Senator Richardson can be certain of one thing: I did not go to the incumbent and say, `She'll be right mate', and slap him on the back.
—Neither did I.
—Yes, three days after the event.
—No, 12 months before.

—Senator Richardson has a much better memory than Mr Hayden. If this Government were genuine about its reforms, there are other matters of much more consequence that it would be pursuing. It would be dealing in a realistic and genuine and sincere way with the waterfront. What do we find it doing about the waterfront?
—You have had only two or three weeks on this. Your Government waited 30 years and did nothing.

—There is absolutely no prospect, Senator Schacht, of me holding my breath and surviving and waiting for this Government to commit itself in a genuine and real way to restructuring the fundamental faults and disfiguration and curves and distortions inherent and almost intrinsic in the economy as a result of the trade union movement running the Government and the Government not running the country.
—What did your Government do 30 years ago?

—With the greatest respect, 30 years ago I was barely entitled to vote. This Government talks of political courage. It has no political courage. Political expediency, yes; political deviousness, yes; political judgment varies from time to time; but at the end of the day when it gets down to making the hard decisions we heard Senator Richardson not 24 hours ago in this chamber saying to us, `Where would you cut?'. This Government has an ideal pristine opportunity to do something about the distortions in the economy and it does nothing except talk about deregulating the domestic wheat market in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view-in terms of the economy this measure is not a major step, but certainly for many wheat growers it is an emotional disruption and for the old people in the industry something of a trauma-this is a misconceived notion but one that I can understand. For those growers still alive who in the 1920s and early 1930s received advances from private buyers but found at the end of the year they had to hand back not only all their wheat but half the advance, there is naturally that memory, that recollection of events. But of course we live in a different day and age. In those days we could not pick up the telephone and ring up the commodity buyers. In that day and age we did not have instant access to world prices or domestic prices. So I understand and, while not empathising, certainly sympathise with those who have anxieties and concerns about this legislation. Frankly, if this Government were genuine, were serious, it would be approaching the areas of major consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the export market.

—Let us talk about the export market. Let us talk about where the world wheat industry is going. Let us look over the horizon at areas that ought to be of major concern, that are fundamental and intrinsic to the future of the industry in Australia. It is not the domestic wheat market, Senator Richardson, with respect; it is our capacity to sell into overseas markets. Let us look at China for instance. In 1966 China was producing about 26 million tonnes of wheat. It is now producing 88 million tonnes of wheat. I think, if my memory serves me correctly-and I am sure the experts in this chamber will tell me if I am wrong-that China is now the largest producer of wheat in the world. By the year 2000 China will be a net exporter of food. I was in Egypt two years ago and there was a Chinese delegation seeking to sell wheat into one of our traditional and major markets. It was not without consequence for me to note at that stage that our embassy did not have one single person even indirectly related to the Wheat Board. Yet we think that we are keeping our finger on the pulse of our overseas markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at India. In 1965-66 India was producing about 12 million tonnes of wheat. In 1986-87 it was producing about 46 million tonnes. That is the last figure that I have access to. Now it is the fifth largest wheat producer in the world. It was a significant market for Australia. Twenty years ago, 80 per cent of India's wheat production was lost in storage, for reasons that would be obvious to anyone who knows anything about the subject. The situation is now quite the reverse. It now loses 20 per cent of its wheat because of inefficiencies and, more particularly, inadequacies in the storage of its grain. It is not without significance to note that from time to time in the right seasons India is itself a significant exporter of wheat.

I have no doubt that the Australian Wheat Board is keeping its eye on these things but, clearly, some of our traditional markets will not exist in years to come. It is my view that if South America, for instance, ever gets its act together and some of that infertile country is provided with adequate and sophisticated trace elements, that country's capacity to produce wheat will be quite different from its present capacity. Perhaps we ought to be looking at new wheat markets in the Middle East and Asia, and I will come to the Soviet Union in due course. In the early 1970s those markets took up something like 50 per cent of our total exports and now they take up 80 per cent. I repeat that we in Australia should be concerning ourselves with fundamental micro-economic reforms with our overseas markets.

While we make much of the problem in terms of our blusterings and our protestations about the United States export enhancement program (EEP) and the common agricultural policy (CAP) arrangements of the European Communities (EC), it is my judgment that we cannot expect any significant relief in the next decade. Perhaps there are people more informed than I. Perhaps others are more optimistic than I am, but it would be absurd for us to think that representations from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or Mr Kerin, or by delegations from Australia to the United States or the European Communities, are going to change their fundamental attitude in respect of the subsidisation of wheat in particular.

I am sure that we all understand the fundamental political base that is made up by the grain growers in the European Communities, for instance. If we imagine that a French Government, or any European government, is going to cut the heart out of its political body by immediately abolishing, for the well-being of world trade, its present subsidy levels, we are kidding ourselves. If we imagine that President Bush or any other President of the United States is going to have the courage and the commitment to tell the mid-west farmers overnight, unilaterally, that as long as the European Communities has its program they are no longer economic, that the subsidy has gone, that the taxpayers' money that has kept them alive for the years it has will be taken away from them and that he is prepared to carry the political consequences, we are fooling ourselves. It is about as stupid as imagining that Bob Hawke would legislate himself out of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is doing a good job of it at the moment.

—Knowingly and wittingly, I mean. He will do it by ignorance steeped in stupidity. But if we imagine that there are going to be fundamental changes to those programs simply because of the squeaking of our wheel we are making a grave mistake. We ought to be, for our part, improving the efficiencies of our own production. But that seems to come very far down the track in this Government's order of priorities. It is more interested in putting up mischievous legislation to see whether it can be divisive and cause difficulties for the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's world share of wheat exports has declined by 50 per cent since the commencement of the export enhancement program. If I remember correctly it is down from 19.5 per cent to 11.3 per cent. Australia has seen a reduction by 31 per cent in areas sown since the year 1983-84. In that period 12.9 million hectares, and in 1987-88 8.86 million hectares, of wheat were sown. We ought to note that the gross value of production since 1983-84 is down by $1 billion in nominal terms, reflecting a massive drop in exports from 15 million tonnes to between nine million and 9.5 million tonnes.

It is difficult to determine the exact cost to Australia of the United States export enhancement program because the program is in competition with the subsidies provided by the EC in its program. Any subsidies that provide for production well above the level of market demand are bound to have the effect of driving prices down in terms of immediate sales or of creating storage levels which overhang the market, it also guaranteeing a significant reduction in real prices. I think it was Mr Dawkins, the then Minister for Trade, who estimated some time ago that the export enhancement program had reduced Australia's export earnings by in excess of $1 billion in 1986-87. Both programs are costing Australia about $1 billion each in exports. The Chairman of the Wheat Board has claimed that the United States EEP has halved Australia's world market share while those of the United States and the EC have increased significantly. As I said earlier, our market share has gone from 19.5 per cent in 1985-86 to 11.3 per cent in 1988-89.

The Soviet Union has in contemporary times been a significant market for Australia, but we have seen our share of that market crumble from 20 per cent to 3 per cent. We see that the United States has offered subsidies to no less than 35 countries since its export enhancement program began in 1985 and that it sold in excess of 59 million tonnes of wheat at a price, with subsidies included of up to $50 a tonne. Since 1985 when the EEP began, Australia's production has fallen from more than 18 million tonnes to about 13 million tonnes, and during that period wheat prices have continued to fall. There are, of course, a number of other countries that I will not canvass for the moment which have previously been significant buyers of our wheat and are no longer major importers of our product as a result of the subsidies offered to them by the United States of America and as a result of the CAP program.

I turn for a moment to what I see as an area of fundamental change which this Government would have the capacity to do something about if it had the moral and political courage, but about which essentially it has done absolutely nothing. Let us talk about the transport and handling in the wheat industry. The significance of wheat storage, handling and transport charges can be seen in the fact that the combined charges represent 18 per cent of the overseas customer's price. Storage, handling and transport charges vary widely from State to State. In 1987-88, for instance, the combined charges for these services ranged from $24.72 a tonne in South Australia to $42.53 a tonne in New South Wales. The State freight and handling monopolies' costs consume 22 per cent of free on board crop value. It is just not possible for us to compete on the world market as long as we have those levels built into our production costs. The McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport suggested that, from a national perspective, resource cost savings of approximately $10 per tonne could be achieved through greater efficiencies.

Let me refer to some restrictive practices as set down by the McColl report which give a clear and graphic example of some of the problems that we have in Australia. In talking about restrictive practices, that report tells us:

The `job and finish' or `nickaway' practice-the practice of leaving the plant after finishing an allocated task and refusing to accept any further tasks-has been named as one of the more blatant and damaging work practices affecting grain terminal activity . . .
Job and finish means that labour is being paid (usually at double time overtime rates on the premium afternoon shift) for non-work.
One common scenario is that of workers accepting only one job or task. The report states:

On completion, it is usual for them to shower and spend the balance of the shift in the meal room. If, as is often the case, the task takes only two hours, the balance of the shift (five hours) is totally unproductive for that labour.
In some port terminals the Australian Workers Union smokos and meals breaks severely limit productivity. The report states:

With start-up time at the beginning of the day and finishing tasks at the end of the afternoon shift . . . With an added five minutes on smokos, meal breaks and so on, it would be not uncommon to lose . . . two hours and fifty minutes from a 14 hour period.
The report refers to absenteeism at the Newcastle port terminal, stating that between 1986 and 1987:
. . . an average of 22 men, nearly 18 per cent of workforce, were absent on any one day.
Nearly 18 per cent of the total workforce are absent on any given day. In respect of disputes at the Newcastle grain terminal the report states:

Between October 1986 and September 1987 . . . 69 shifts were lost due to industrial stoppages and stop work meetings. This represents approximately 14 per cent of the total shifts available during the year.
The total cost of ships times lost due to industrial stoppages during that period was $915,000. The report continues:
This estimate does not take into account the indirect costs such as harm to Australia's reputation and the charging of a premium by overseas shipowners over and above normal freight rates.

That total is estimated to be $1,065,000. The report goes on to outline in a graphic way the most gross abuses. This is one area in which, in my view, the employees' acceptance of wages from the employer verges on the criminal, and this Government has done absolutely nothing about it. It does not have the courage to do anything about it because it is its natural constituency that it may have to impinge upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do for 30 years? Your Government did nothing.
—Let me tell Senator Schacht about Wyndham, that port in the north-west of Western Australia--
—That is not a big wheat growing area, is it?

—It is symptomatic of that which is intrinsic to productivity in Australia and inimical to the well-being of Australia and its export capacity. It happens to be, or it was, a major export port for the beef industry. But it is no different from any other port. It highlights in a clear and precise way the fundamental problems that confront Australia in respect of shipping, for example. It explains to me at least, if perhaps not to Senator Schacht, why it is cheaper to get superphosphate from Florida to Fremantle than it is to get superphosphate from Christmas Island to Fremantle; why it is cheaper to have a ship travel from any port of the United States to Australia than it is to have a ship travel between Fremantle and Sydney.
—What did the Fraser Government do about all of these points? It did nothing.

—This Government has been stagnating and failing for six years, and the best Senator Schacht can do is to offer to me the explanation that the Fraser Government did less. That is hardly an excuse or justification for this diabolical performance, which verges on the criminal in terms of the Government's lack of responsibility and commitment. Let me tell the Senate about Wyndham. The cost per man hour at the port of Wyndham in Western Australia is $101.99, while at Walcott the cost per man hour is $3.92.
—What has that got to do with wheat?

—Senator Richardson asks what labour costs at ports throughout Australia have to do with the cost of the export of wheat to wheatgrowers, to the balance of payments, to consumers, to our export market and to our overseas consumers. I am horrified. I cannot imagine whatever could be in the mind of Senator Richardson when he asks what the level of manning at Australian ports has to do with the cost to Australia of competing with overseas markets. There are on average 27 registered waterside workers in the port of Wyndham. Their average working week is made up of 7.8 hours.
—How many tonnes of wheat go through Wyndham?

—If I duplicated that example in referring to another port, would Senator Richardson think it was relevant? If he wants another example, let us talk about Albany, which Senator Richardson would probably mispronounce, because he does not come to Western Australia too often. The number of registered waterside workers at Albany is 22. They work on average 24 hours a week. That is their contribution, for which they are paid a minimum of about $500 a week-and we wonder why we cannot begin to compete!

SPEECH.PARA: I see I have about two minutes of my time remaining. Let me say this in conclusion: if this Government were serious, and committed in a very genuine way to reform, so that there would be a certainty of major changes and a significant reduction in costs to the growers of Australia which was reflected in our export sales and in the price paid by the consumers of Australia, we would see fundamental changes right across the Australian economy.

Micro-economic reforms should be made. There is an urgent need for change. Yet this Government stands silent on its commitment to do something about the problems. It is prepared to deregulate the domestic wheat market which in my view is a trivial matter and which I personally cannot get terribly emotional about. But when it is confronted with the real issues necessary to change the landscape and the economic horizons of Australia, it does not have the courage, the commitment, the fortitude but most of all, sadly, the Government does not have the will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for too long on this wheat legislation. The time has gone on, there have been many speakers and I think we should get to the committee stage as soon as possible in order to get as much of this legislation as possible passed tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation contains the following main features: first of all it contains provision for a more commercial structure and operating basis for the Australian Wheat Board (AWB), including the ability to buy wheat for cash, market other grains, trade in wheat produced in other countries, and operate grain handling and storage facilities. The legislation also empowers the AWB and other grain trading operations and service organisations to enter into contracts unencumbered by State legislation.

Secondly, the AWB is to remain the sole exporter of milling and industrial quality wheat but the remaining restrictions on the operation of private traders on the domestic market are to be removed. Thirdly, membership of the AWB is to comprise 11 people including eight nominated by the selection committee. There is no requirement for the AWB chairperson to be a grower nor for all States to be represented on the Board, apart from the presiding member. The members of the selection committee are to be nominated by the Grains Council of Australia.

Fourthly, there will be an end to compulsory acquisition and administered domestic pricing methods. Fifthly, pool will identify the actual charges incurred by growers for storage, handling, transport and port services. Sixthly, a government loan guarantee on AWB borrowings will be provided to fund advance payments based on the estimated current season net pool return. The guarantee is to apply initially to 90 per cent of the net pool return, then phase down to 80 per cent over five years. Seventhly, there will be a termination of the levy which funds the shipment of wheat to Tasmania. Finally, a wheat industry fund will be established to provide a capital base to fund activity including the AWB's commercial operations making advance payments above the borrowing guarantee and providing insurance on credit sales. That is a brief summary of the legislation.

I want to refer to a couple of points that previous speakers have made. First of all, the Opposition parties seem to be getting themselves into a considerable knot about the change in the membership of the Australian Wheat Board and the background of the members. There seems to be a view that the Government is not cognisant of the contribution of wheat growers themselves and that the wheat growers feel that the change in the nomination process will diminish their voice.

One thing that I want to point out to the Opposition is that the Australian Wheat Board is not a production board; it is a marketing board. Wheat farmers in Australia are excellent producers of wheat. They are not bad at marketing and over the last 20 years individually wheat farmers have acquired considerable sophistication in being able to make judgments about the price of wheat and about determining how much wheat they should sow according to the price that they might be able to obtain in the forthcoming season.

However, one should recognise that the Australian Wheat Board's function is to market the wheat the farmers produce. It is not the other way around. It is not the Wheat Board's function to produce the wheat for the farmers to market and I believe that what the Government is proposing is quite reasonable. It is to ensure that the marketing functions of the Australian Wheat Board are strengthened and that, therefore, its ability to sell the wheat the farmers produce is strengthened. That, I believe, should be accepted by the Opposition. The Australian Wheat Board has done an excellent job over nearly the last 41 years. I acknowledge the fact that the Australian wheat farmers who have been elected to the Australian Wheat Board by and large have done an excellent job. Obviously their representation will continue, but we should not weaken the Board's primary function of being a marketing organisation.

I think it is interesting to reflect on the history of the Australian wheat industry and which party in government has done the most to change and improve the wheat industry in this country. There have been a number of major phases when the Government has intervened in legislation in the wheat industry in Australia. The first occasion was 1915 during the First World War under wartime regulations. That was, of course, under a Labor government. The first time there was intervention in the wheat industry occurred under the Fisher Labor Government. When the war ended, the then National Government ended that involvement and the wheat marketing system went back to the free-for-all of a free market. A Labor government in 1930, to overcome the problems of the wheat industry, attempted to introduce legislation to guarantee payments to wheat farmers in Australia. It is interesting to note that in 1930 that legislation to guarantee payment to farmers failed in this very chamber. A Senate dominated by conservative parties rejected the legislation to stop farmers getting a guaranteed income.

Through the rest of the 1930s there was chaos and a mishmash of legislation attempted at both State and Federal level, none of it of much benefit to the wheat producing farmer. The next major step, of course, was in the 1940s, again a Labor government introducing legislation in wartime for the sake of the nation to regulate and guarantee prices for wheat farmers. That led ultimately to the Chifley Labor Government introducing the Australian Wheat Board legislation in 1948 to start the stabilisation program. It guaranteed prices for wheat farmers and ensured orderly marketing. It was a Labor government that did it. It was not the Country Party, the National Party, the Liberal Party, the United Australia Party or any other party. The history of rural affairs in Australia and in politics in Australia until 1948 shows that it has been Labor governments that have made the big interventions, the big decisions to change an industry for the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was 40 years ago.

—Yes, I am just coming to that. It certainly was 40 years ago. The legislation of 1948 established the wheat industry in Australia and gave it the stability to last 40 years, with amendments to the Wheat Stabilisation Act every five years. Neither the National Party-previously the Country Party-nor the Liberal Party moved away from the fundamentals of the legislation introduced by the Chifley Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the Hawke Labor Government introduces in 1989 further significant amendments to the operation of the Australian Wheat Board. But the legislation does not destroy the Australian Wheat Board; it does not remove its overriding powers. In fact, it will be the major influence in the wheat industry. As I outlined in the beginning of my remarks, it will enable features that will make the Wheat Board more flexible, more commercial and able to provide a better marketing service to Australian wheat growers. It also enables wheat growers in the domestic market to have some wider options about what they can do.

As I said before, one of the encouraging features in Australian agriculture over the last 30 years is that farmers have become a lot more sophisticated, have access to a lot more information and make judgments about the way they run their rural activities-whether it be wheat growing, wool growing, beef production, and so on. So we are not dealing with a wheat industry of the 1920s or 1930s where farmers were isolated through lack of communication, did not have access to information on prices and so on.

The Opposition parties have raised some queries about this legislation. I am not quite certain, after hearing some of the speeches tonight from Opposition members, whether they actually support this legislation or oppose it. I understand that they will be supporting it in general and proposing certain amendments. But the way they speak it could be thought that the legislation was designed to destroy the whole marketing arrangements of the Australian Wheat Board. The point I wish to make is that farmers are able to make much better judgments than they were 40 years ago, 30 years ago or even 20 years ago about--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why you want them on the Board.

—Senator Powell interjects about why we want them on the Board. They will certainly be on the Board. If the honourable senator reads the legislation she will see that the selection committee will still be putting names forward from the Grains Council. I would be very surprised if the names of a number of farmers were not put forward. But, as I said before, the Australian Wheat Board is a marketing board; it is not a production board. There ought to be people on the Wheat Board who have some expertise in marketing and in financial management.
—I thought they were all wheat growers.

—The balance has to be there. I think the Government proposal is quite sensible. The Hawke Government has recognised that Australian wheat farmers are without doubt second to none in wheat production.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1987, as a member of a delegation to the United States of America, I met a number of members of the American Congress. One in particular, Charles Stenholm, a Conservative Democrat congressman from Texas and a leading figure in agricultural politics in America and in the Congress, openly admitted that Australian wheat farmers were, if not the most efficient, certainly second to none and he did concede that in some ways they were more efficient than American wheat farmers. So even Americans recognise that Australian wheat farmers are outstanding in their ability to produce top quality wheat. What we have to do is provide them with a marketing mechanism for the 1990s that will enable them to get the highest possible return for their efforts. This Bill does that.

I recognise that some older members of the farming community who experienced the dreadful times of the 1930s are very concerned that the introduction of this Bill and its proposals could in some way, inadvertently even, return them to the mercy of the private grain buyers of the 1930s. When wheat farmers have a chance to study this Bill in detail they will see that that is not the case, that the Australian Wheat Board maintains its absolute monopoly on exports. It will still be the major force in marketing in the domestic area. And because it will set the prices for the export market, which is 80 per cent of the production, it will be the determining factor of price in the domestic market.

Does anyone believe that Australian wheat farmers will deliberately sell wheat to a private wheat buyer at a price less than what the Australian Wheat Board will offer either in the export market or even in the domestic market? Of course not. No wheat farmer in Australia will be that stupid. I think it is derogatory of the Opposition and some elements of farmer organisations to imply that farmers would do that. They are not that stupid; they will make intelligent marketing decisions to their own benefit.

This legislation represents the fourth time since Federation that major changes to the benefit of the industry will be made and it is the fourth time that they are being made by a Labor government. Despite all the protestations by the Liberal Opposition, the National Party and its predecessor the Country Party, they have squibbed all the times they have been in government making any significant changes to the wheat industry in Australia. I think it ought to be remembered by the wheat farmers of Australia that they cannot rely on the Opposition parties to deliver the goods, to tackle the important issues in their own industry.

When Senator Crichton-Browne spoke he stirred himself up a little about this Government not tackling major issues of micro-economic reform. I could not help but interject. I asked him to tell the Senate when, during the 30 years of the last 40 years that the Opposition was in government in Australia, it ever attempted the range of micro-economic reforms that the Hawke Labor Government has instituted since 1983.

We have come up not only with this present wheat board legislation; we also have coming before the Parliament in the next few weeks major legislation to implement the recommendations of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. I am very interested to hear the attacks made on the inefficiencies of waterside workers, on Australian Workers Union members and other workers in Australia within the grain storage and handling industry. Certainly, the McColl Royal Commission identified those inefficiencies. For 30 years out of the last 40 years since 1949 the Opposition was in power. It never held a royal commission into these matters. It never tackled these issues or identified the problems. It just ignored them. It was slothful and in a long slumber on these issues. It let the industry accumulate these inefficiencies.

This Government is going to take on a major issue of reform of grain handling and storage. It is already being attacked by conservative State governments and, I must say in my view unfortunately, some aspects have been criticised by State Labor governments. But I have no hesitation in saying that on this matter the Federal Government must be supreme because of the importance of our export wheat industry to the world. For the good economic health of Australia also, the legislation must be carried. I trust that when it comes before the Parliament the National and Liberal parties will support it.

We know that within the next three or four weeks the Government will also announce a micro-economic reform package for the waterfront and maritime shipping industries in Australia. Again, when that announcement is made there will be numbers of vested interest, both employee and employer, who will complain. But I ask Opposition members what they did about this for the last 30 or 40 years. They did nothing. They were not game to tackle it because it was just too difficult. So when we come to consider the range of micro-economic reform it is this Government that has the guts to do it. It will never be the Opposition because it is beholden to too many vested and special interests. Though this Labor Government has a base in the trade union movement, we have been the government-even at times of strong political criticism from our trade union base-that has been willing for the national interest to take on those issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —What-take on the trade unions? When?

—I am sure that when Senator Stone looks back he will see that since 1983 we arranged micro-economic reform in a whole number of areas-the car industry, the steel industry, the heavy engineering industry. In each of those areas this cost large numbers of blue collar workers their jobs, but we did it in a way that they were not thrown on the scrapheap; 300,000 were not put out of work as happened when Senator Stone was head of Treasury in the early 1980s--
—They were put out of work by the trade union leadership-by John Halfpenny and Laurie Carmichael.

—Senator Stone is a remarkable person in this Senate because not one other person here, or even senators collectively, has his record of putting into practice policies that cost 250,000 to 300,000 Australians their jobs in 1981-82. It is a record that he will have to bear for as long as he is in public life and even in his retirement. That is the outcome of his policy. It cost people their jobs. He put people on the bread line. He put people on the unemployment benefit and he thought that was a good policy.
—And you kept them there.

—No, we only created one and a quarter million jobs. The previous Government put hundreds of thousands of people out of work; we put people back into work, because we have had the guts to take on major economic reform in this country, unlike the Opposition parties.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is just one of a number of Government commitments to micro-economic reform. I look forward to hearing the debate to take place in this chamber in the coming weeks when we deal with other issues such as handling and storage in the shipping and waterfront areas. I believe this legislation ought to be supported by all members of this Senate because it means that the Australian wheat industry will become more efficient, more effective, but, above all else, give higher returns to the wheat producers of Australia. It is one of Australia's most important industries. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Relatively buoyant commodity prices have kept this Government in office. Yet the Government, despite the protestations of Senator Schacht, has no interest in primary industry. The only interest this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has ever had in grain was in the by-product of its fermentation. In contrast, in entering the debate on this Wheat Marketing Bill and associated Bills, I do so from a background of personal involvement. Indeed, I suppose it is appropriate to declare a personal interest in this legislation as I am a partner, with my parents, in a wheat growing property in the mid-north of South Australia. Indeed, I am descended from generations of wheat growers in the mid-north area. My father, in fact, was President of the Australian Wheat Growers Federation in 1946 and 1947, on the eve of the introduction of wheat stabilisation.
—By a Labor govern-ment.

—It was introduced, as I will explain, as a result of the hard work and efforts of wheat growers of that time. Coming from that background, I suppose it is not surprising that I was weaned on the benefits of orderly marketing-the system which is going to be changed as a result of this legislation. Therefore I understand the concern, indeed the fear, of many wheat growers concerning these changes. This Labor Government must accept full responsibility for the extent of fear generated among wheat growers. No wonder farmers are confused and afraid of change. The main problem for the rural industry is not drought, flood or rabbits; it is the kangaroos Mr Kerin has loose in his top paddock. His proposals remained vague and imprecise for more than a year until this legislation was introduced a month ago. This lack of precision about the detail of the changes, understandably, encouraged fear of them and allowed that fear to rage like a bushfire among wheat growers. Unfortunately, when the legislation was introduced those fears were shown in large measure to be justified.

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers are all in favour of fertiliser, but they would rather see it in their paddocks, not in the Government's legislation. The Government preaches good management and efficiency to the rural sector, yet its own legislation reeks of gross mismanagement and inefficiency. When was the last time the Government proposed as many amendments to its own legislation as the Opposition proposes to make? George Bernard Shaw said:
Men are not governed by justice, but by law or persuasion. When they refuse to be governed by law or persuasion, they have to be governed by force or fraud.

That is an accurate description of this Government's approach. How does the Government expect growers to be persuaded by a Bill to which it has attached some 40 amendments? The fraud is evident in that these amendments fail to address the central concerns of wheat growers. It has been left to the Opposition to ensure that benefits will be achieved-benefits which logical analysis shows are offered by further deregulation of the domestic wheat market. Our amendments will ensure that those efficiencies in marketing, which will be demanded by marketing deregulation, continue right down the chain of storage, transport, handling and distribution. We are moving 45 amendments to ensure that the legislation is beneficial to growers by removing the shortcomings which even the Government's own amendments fail to address.

The point of our amendments is to separate the wheat from the chaff in this Bill. The producers are efficient, it is the middle men who are not. I refer to the unions and their cosy deals with State governments and other utilities; the rorts in the ports; the snails on the rails; the go-slows in the silos. Producers are being railroaded by the railways and conditions at the terminals are just that: terminal. As the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Handling, Storage and Transport concluded, an end to all this would save growers $10 per tonne.

While a deregulated domestic market offers potential benefits to growers through increased returns, it also obviously involves risks, as any competitive, free enterprise system does. Growers are therefore entitled to have those risks offset by that $10 per tonne benefit to be gained by deregulating those other sources of costs to growers in the grain distribution chain. That must, above all, include the deregulation of the labour market within this industry. Let us see the efficiency for which growers themselves are renowned translated to other sectors of this important industry. Our amendments will ensure this, but if they are not passed, there is some justification for the fears of growers. Those fears arise largely from the experience of wheat growers during the Great Depression of the 1930s.

I have discussed this issue with wheat growers throughout the length and breadth of my own State of South Australia over the past year at public meetings and in private discussions. A major concern has been that the Government's proposals will return growers to the bad old days of the 1930s. Of course, they will not, but it is to this Government's eternal discredit that, as I said earlier, its proposals were so vague for so long that those fears could be allowed to be generated.

Several government inquiries in the early part of this century referred to the existence and impact of price and shipping cartels, whose collusive actions depressed prices and controlled transport. This exploitation of farmers was facilitated partly by difficulties experienced with storage and transport arrangements during a period of rapid expansion and technological advances.

The Great Depression severely impacted on Australia's external trading position. In 1930, the Commonwealth Government sought to overcome these economic difficulties through an expansion in primary production, especially wheat growing. Early in 1930 Australian wheat growers were urged to grow more wheat. The appeal was instigated and supported at the highest levels of government. This was the first time that politics interfered with farmers' production decisions. The `Grow More Wheat' campaign was accompanied by obvious patriotic overtones and included the particularly attractive offer of a price guarantee of four shillings per bushel. Political leaders were unable to keep their end of the bargain, with the Senate rejecting Australia's first wheat marketing Bill on 4 July 1930-during the period, of course, of a Labor government; promises made by a Labor government that were unfulfilled. It reminds me of the promises which were obviously made to our media moguls a year or two ago about changes to the legislation with regard to media ownership, which again were not able to be delivered. So this party presently in government has a history or making promises to industries that it cannot deliver. As I said, it was not able to deliver the promised four shillings a bushel.

During 1930, of course, world wheat prices declined significantly. As most wheat producers in the eastern States were already in a financially weakened state, the industry entered a severe economic slump. Several other legislative initiatives providing for assistance to the wheat industry were attempted during 1930 and 1931. Although one of these, providing for a price guarantee of three shillings per bushel, was actually enacted, it was stillborn because no funds for the bounty were available. The result was that growers fought long and hard throughout the 1930s and into the 1940s for comprehensive marketing arrangements. As I said earlier, my own father was heavily involved in that process. Those marketing arrangements have become a feature of the Australian wheat industry. They were first brought together in the Wheat Industry Stabilization Act 1948.

The Act embodied four main features arising from concepts of price stabilisation and orderly marketing which have remained fundamental objectives of all subsequent legislation. Those four features were guaranteed prices, a home consumption price, the Australian Wheat Board, and stabilisation arrangements. While the present proposals abandon some of those features they do not abandon growers to the deprivation of the 1930s. First and foremost, the Australian Wheat Board is retained and although losing its monopoly power in the domestic market, its commercial capacity is strengthened by this legislation, which gives it the capacity to buy wheat for cash, to market other grains, to operate grain handling and storage facilities, and to enter into contracts unencumbered by State legislation.

Most importantly, as a result of Opposition pressure, the Wheat Board will remain the sole exporter of Australian wheat. Maintaining this monopoly means that it has more than 80 per cent of Australia's crop tied up and that gives it sufficient market power to remain a major and effective player in the domestic market, which comprises the remaining nearly 20 per cent of the Australian crop. This dominant position will enable the Wheat Board to maintain a floor price in the domestic market. In other words, it will have the capacity to ensure that growers will not succumb to any collusive tendencies on the part of traders. The present day capacity for the sort of collusion which existed in the 1930s is further constrained by restrictive trade practice laws which, as we have seen in the recent court decision on section 56 of that legislation, do have effective teeth. The continuation of the Australian Wheat Board, combined with the Trade Practices Commission and legislation, is sufficient to ensure that changed marketing arrangements for the 1990s are not a return to the 1930s.

Another concern of growers has been that these changes are the thin end of the wedge towards removing the export monopoly of the Australian Wheat Board and eventually to doing away with the Board. I cannot speak for the Government on that issue, but certainly that is not on the Opposition's agenda. We would oppose vehemently any such initiative by the Labor Party. The Opposition has demonstrated its bona fides with regard to the continuation of the Wheat Board and forced the Government to withdraw its proposals to remove its monopoly on the export of feed wheat. Many of our customer countries have single buying agencies and there is no benefit to be gained from increasing the number of sellers in these markets. So the export monopoly will remain.

A further concern of growers is that with the abandonment of the human consumption price for wheat on the domestic market, returns from that market segment will fall from the best export price to the average export price. While there is ample evidence that this will not occur, it is always easier to identify negatives from a removal of protection than positives. It has been ever thus on a whole range of protection issues, including tariffs and quotas. We should remember that these changes to wheat marketing were recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission which has been a great friend of the farming community for many years through its advocacy of the reduction of tariffs and other forms of protection to other sectors of the Australian economy.

It is also relevant that the concept of the human consumption price was established in the late 1940s when more than half our crop was sold on the domestic market. With growth in production and exports over the years since then, that figure has now declined to less than 20 per cent. In other words, the domestic price premium now has only a small effect on overall returns when averaged across total production, compared to the benefit it gave in the late 1940s and early 1950s. The Australian Wheat Board has acknowledged that the maximum overall price effect, if the average export price becomes the benchmark rather than some higher figure, would be $2.50 per tonne and in my own State of South Australia, between $1 and $2 per tonne. Against this must be weighed the fact that since the 1984 deregulation of the feed wheat market in Australia, on average, growers are $13 per tonne better off by marketing oven wheat. This demonstrates the great likelihood of getting a higher rather than a lower price, similarly, for human consumption wheat, on the domestic market.

Quite simply, in the future, as now, the major determinant of returns for wheat growers will be world wheat prices. Orderly marketing does not achieve a higher price; it simply causes a lag effect. In a falling world market, the decline in returns will be slower than otherwise, but equally, in a rising world market, returns will rise slower than otherwise. That is why the major responsibility of this Government is to lobby effectively in world forums for freer trade and the removal of subsidies. If only this Government was as good at selling off the crop as it is at selling off the farm. But it has failed dismally in international forums. At a time when Australia's balance of payments reads like the balance sheet of the National Safety Council, this Government has presided over a fall of 45 per cent in our share of world wheat markets over the last four years, while the United States has increased its share by 48 per cent.

A short time ago the Prime Minister wept on television over his success with the birds. What success? He had no luck with Quayle; he will have even less with Peacock. He told us Mr Quayle had got the message. Some message! A week later the United States announced a sale to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) of 1 1/2 million tonnes at a subsidy of $18 to $20 per tonne. Last year the United States spent $760m on its export enhancement program subsidies. This year it will spend $1.1 billion. Our Prime Minister failed to impress the United States Vice-President because he was either too clever by half or poorly briefed. He cited the figures I gave a few moments ago-Australia has suffered a 45 per cent decrease; the United States has enjoyed a 48 per cent increase over the last few years. Unfortunately for our Prime Minister, Mr Quayle was a little better briefed and by referring to market share figures for the 1980s was able to show that our share four years ago was an atypical high and the United States share an atypical low. Our Prime Minister should have been better briefed.

The real damage which is being done to Australian wheat growers by the United States export enhancement program can be shown by looking at market share figures for the whole decade of the 1980s for our two major markets-China and the USSR-rather than looking at our total share of the world wheat market over the last four years. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing respective market shares since 1982 of Australia, the United States and the European Economic Community, in China and the USSR.
Leave granted.
