TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Reference to this table clearly shows a dramatic rise in the market share of the United States and the European Economic Community since the introduction of the export enhancement program over the last four years, compared not just to 1985-86 but to the average share for the first half of the 1980s. In contrast, in the same period there has been a massive fall in Australia's market share. In China the change has not been so dramatic until this year. Our share has fallen to 9 per cent, from an average for the 1980s of 20 per cent, while the United States share has arisen from around 30 per cent to 47 per cent and the European Economic Community's share has risen from around 4 per cent to 12 per cent. The table shows a much more extended period of change in the USSR, but again, only since the introduction of the export enhancement program. This is the message which this Government must ram home to the United States in particular, and to the European Economic Community. It is in our two key markets that our Western allies are doing demonstrable and serious damage to our wheat growers and hence to our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Before concluding, I will highlight the major reasons for deregulating the domestic market. Firstly, to ensure the deregulation of the transport, storage and handling sectors and to achieve those savings of $10 per tonne which, I mentioned earlier, had been identified by the McColl Royal Commission, it is important to deregulate the domestic market. While McColl acknowledged the possibility of achieving these savings under current marketing arrangements, the Royal Commission concluded that marketing reform would enhance the likelihood of improved efficiencies being obtained in the transport, storage and handling sectors because of the effect of competitive pressure in the marketplace. Because my home State of South Australia has enjoyed the benefits of deregulated transport for many years, thanks to the foresight of the Playford Liberal Government of earlier times, and has grower-owned bulk handling facilities, savings there may be somewhat less than the figure of $10 per tonne. But there are still savings to be achieved in South Australia as a result of deregulation, most notably on the waterfront.

The second reason for supporting deregulation of the domestic market is that it is already partially deregulated. Since 1984 the permit system has allowed private trading in feed wheat. That deregulation of the feed wheat domestic market has been so successful that over 90 per cent of domestic feed wheat now bypasses the Australian Wheat Board. It is doing so because growers are getting better returns through private trading. The gloomy predictions in 1984 have not been realised. Of course, the feed wheat domestic market represents 40 per cent of our domestic market. So we are only talking about deregulating the other 60 per cent of the domestic market, or about 12 per cent of our total crop.

The third reason for domestic deregulation is to encourage the development of specialist varieties and niche marketing. The development of the organic wheat market, for example, has been hindered by the regulated system. As an example, for the privilege of growing and milling his own wheat and not selling the wheat to another buyer, one producer has to pay the Australian Wheat Board $40 per tonne. This is clearly a nonsense; hence, the benefits of this legislation, provided it incorporates the Opposition amendments, are demonstrable. The Opposition amendments will ensure that the fears of growers will not be realised and it is important that those amendments be carried.

I am confident that over the next five years growers who have yet to be convinced of the benefits of domestic market deregulation will see and come to realise the benefits of competitive marketing opportunities. Of course, if they do not wish to avail themselves of those opportunities, the Australian Wheat Board will still be available. They can deliver their wheat to the Board, and the Board will be able to market on their behalf.

Our amendments will test how dinkum this Government is about micro-economic reform. There is no doubt the legislation should include the deregulation of the labour market within this industry. The Government, particularly with regard to the waterfront, has now been given a blueprint for deregulation of the labour market with the publication of the Inter-State Commission report. I want to see some action on that front and in other sectors of this industry as far as the labour market is concerned. The Liberal Party has shown its bona fides with its support of this legislation. Let us see some bona fides on the part of the Government with its support for our amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is some desire in the chamber that we continue this debate to its conclusion. I think that desire has merit. However, I do not think it should be an open-ended debate. The Government will support, therefore, a negating of the adjournment at 10.30, the debate can proceed to 11.30 and, if we have not completed the debate by then, we will move for the adjournment and conclude proceedings for this evening.
—That wasn't what you said last night.

—Is is for the managers of Senate business to sort out these details, and advise me, but that is my understanding of the position, and I am acting on that basis. Therefore, I do not propose to deliver what is traditionally the Government's reply to the points raised in the debate in an exhaustive fashion, as I am prepared to do and as I would like to do. I do, however, for the Hansard record, note that many of the points that I have heard canvassed in debate here tonight are points that were canvassed in the debate in the other place. I believe that if I were to adopt the reply by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, to all those points, and present that reply to the Senate, that would at least cover my reply to those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Some issues, however, have been raised specifically in this chamber and are unique to the debate here. I think they require some comment. The first of those, in the order in which they appear before me, is the frequent comment by Senator Stone-by way of interjection or, indeed, in his speech-about the definition of grain in clause 3 (1). Grain, according to that provision, means wheat, barley and any product of the soil declared by the Minister by regulation. Senator Stone has sought to try to cast aspersions that the Government was trying to insert a definition that was improper. Senator Stone might not know that what he is attacking is a definition which was lifted directly from the Queensland Act and he, as a Queensland senator and Leader of the National Party, should be aware that it is a definition that we have taken and applied because we think it is the proper definition in these circumstances. But the origin of that definition is the Queensland Act-an Act provided by a National Party government. If Senator Stone has difficulty with that, he ought to speak to his Party in Queensland.

The Australian Democrats have indicated a series of amendments. I do not propose to address those amendments in this debate or, indeed, the points that have been raised by the Australian Democrats, because it has been pretty hard to follow the ever-altering trail of motive or argument that the Democrats have put up. One could now say that the Democrats are performing a throwback to the old, heavily regulated days. The would-be suburban trendies do not have much of an agricultural or primary industry policy. They are now trying to capture the cocky vote on an issue about which there is anxiety among wheat growers, and this seems to me to be the basis of all political activities and one that is easily unmasked. The amendments that the Democrats are proposing are amendments similar to those moved by some National Party members in the other place, and I will deal with them in the appropriate way.

There have been many references to deregulating the labour market. The debate, as I have heard it-and I have followed it whether I have been here or outside of the chamber-has been marked by, I think, many fine contributions from the Opposition. I think I am obliged to pay that compliment. That is not to say that I have agreed with 100 per cent of the content of all Opposition speeches. But in terms of the perception of what the Government is trying to do-to deregulate the domestic wheat market to provide greater choice for wheat growers and, indeed, to open the prospect for wheat growers to make significant savings for themselves-the strand of the debate has been equalled only by the contributions from our side of the chamber.

The debate by Liberal Party senators has mainly fallen down when they have tried-and I know they are obliged to do this by the Party commitment-to embrace the whole question of deregulation across the board. In that regard they have fallen into deep water. I do not want to relate, chapter and verse, the record of this Government on deregulation, but it can be compared to that of any other government since Federation and is certainly better than the record of the Opposition. Indeed, ours is an enviable record. I do not want to attempt to argue that, somehow or other, the Opposition, if it were in government-an event that I am sure the Australian people will conspire at the ballot box to prevent-if the Democrats were in government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Slip!

—It is getting late; I apologise for the freudian slip. There is no hope of Senator Haines's Party winning government, no matter how many lower House seats she and other members of her Party run for, including Kingston. If the Opposition were in government I do not believe there is any credibility whatsoever in the allegation that it would succeed in deregulating the labour market, even though it has summoned up the image of the old confrontationist days under Fraser, which it believes it could copy to force things through. The most eloquent put-down of that line of argument was given, I believe, by Senator Schacht, when he said that the Opposition, since the war, had been in government for some 30 years, it has not yet succeeded. There is no reason why the people of Australia should believe it would succeed now.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the amendment moved by Senator Stone to the motion for the second reading of the Wheat Marketing Bill. I am not sure the amendment is widely supported by those on the Opposition benches. Indeed, if it were, it would mean that those Liberals who have spoken to this Bill-those whose insight and incisiveness I have commended-would be turning against the very principles they have espoused so eloquently in their speeches.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also note that the amendment moved by Senator Stone is factually incorrect. It seeks in paragraph (a) to deplore the Government's betrayal of wheat farmers of Australia. That is not a fact. In fact, what this Bill does, as many of the coalition speakers have pointed out, is give greater flexibility, greater choice and an opportunity for farmers to indeed earn more. That is hardly a betrayal; it is an enhancement of their prospects. In paragraph (b) of the amendment, he refers to the Government weakening the position of the Australian Wheat Board as a strong trader in the domestic wheat market. The Wheat Board is a monopoly trader in the domestic wheat market. We propose by our amendments to make it a strong trader in the domestic wheat market. The amendment Senator Stone has moved demonstrates the antithesis of reality in paragraph (b). In paragraph (c) he talks about regretting the Government's failure to adequately negotiate. That is a perceptional problem. Honourable senators may wish to pretend that that is the case. We have taken note of the findings of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport, and since the Industries Assistance Commission report, we have engaged in exhaustive consultation on these Bills. I am now advised-and I think just today the Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia, Mr Ernie Bridge, has announced-that Western Australia will be passing complemetary legislation. I understand Victoria will be doing the same. I expect so will South Australia. The recalcitrant States will be Queensland and New South Wales, and they seem to have a political motive for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I assert that the a's, b's and c's of what Senator Stone proposes to add to the second reading motion are not true. They go against the principles espoused in many of the speeches from the Opposition senators, and indeed as a summary of points they lack total credibility in the eyes of the community. I commend the Bills.

I simply point out to the Committee, as I did in the second reading debate, that the purpose of these amendments is really to reinstate the Australian Wheat Board in a fashion that the Democrats believe is in the best interests of the wheat industry and represents the desire of the wheat growers of Australia. The amendments represent the technical necessity to do that. Although there are other amendments to be dealt with which will, if passed, ameliorate the end result, the amendments which I am moving are the only amendments before us tonight which will, in fact, do what the wheat industry wants with this legislation. I quote from the Grains Council of Australia, which has written to the Department to this effect:

. . . while the Grains Council has pursued other amendments, it is the industry's strongly held view that the domestic wheat market should not be further deregulated than currently exists. Consequently, the Australian Wheat Board's acquisition power should be restored, as should the domestic human consumption pricing arrangements, with the modifications suggested by the Grains Council some months ago.

That in fact is the effect of the amendments en bloc which I am moving now. I commend those amendments to the Committee and note that these amendments were moved at an earlier time in another place by Mr Peter Fisher, the honourable member for Mallee, and are moved in the same spirit here, in the interests of the wheat growers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments would restore a regulatory regime that is unacceptable to the Opposition parties and would remove the many advantages to the grain growers incorporated in this Bill. Accordingly, the amendments are opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I signal my support for these amendments. I point out, as Senator Powell so kindly did, that these amendments, in exactly the same form, are the amendments moved in the other House by my National Party colleague, the honourable member for Mallee, Peter Fisher. That very much has been my motivating force in supporting these amendments. By the mere fact of Senate procedure, a spirit of cooperation and this late hour of sitting, the amendments are being moved by the Democrats. They do restore the Australian Wheat Board's compulsory acquisition powers in respect of the domestic wheat market.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be clear to honourable senators that these amendments are exactly the same as those moved by Peter Fisher. I pay tribute to him for the very strong stand he has taken on this issue. It has not been an easy issue, but he has never flinched in his very genuine representation of the seat he holds, the seat of Mallee. His stance can be a very proud one in the history of his stay in Parliament. The Fisher amendments, as they have now been called and even recognised by the Democrats, are very much the legacy that he has made in this Parliament and will leave behind for a long time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak in support of the Australian Democrat amendments. From the line-up that we had in the divisions on the second reading, it looks as though the package of Bills will be passed. Therefore, it is crucially important that amendments such as these be passed through the Senate so that the least possible damage is done to wheat and grain growers. I rise to speak on this occasion as a senator who represents Western Australia because in that line-up for the divisions I was, in fact, the only Western Australian senator to vote against the deregulation of the wheat market.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw to the attention of honourable senators the fact that the State of Western Australia is against wheat deregulation. As reported in the West Australian on Friday, 14 April of this year:

The State Government and Opposition have joined forces to oppose the Federal Government's plan to deregulate the domestic wheat market. In a move which saw the State Liberal and National Parties rebel against their Federal counterparts, the Legislative Assembly yesterday passed a National Party motion calling for all-party support to retain State control of the industry and they threatened to challenge in the High Court the Federal Government's power over State transport and grain handling. The Deputy Leader of the Western Australian National Party, Mr Monty House, told the Legislative Assembly yesterday that many Western Australian farmers would be disadvantaged by the plan. Western Australia already had one of the most efficient grain handling and storage systems in the world. `The grain handling system in Western Australia is unique and it has been handling grain at a cheaper cost per tonne than in any other country', he said.
That is the reason, I wish to place on record, for my support for the Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I oppose the Democrat amendments. I really cannot improve on the succinct way in which Senator Lewis opposed them equally. I guess Senator Lewis and I are in heated agreement on this tonight. Let us hope the alliance continues. I am afraid it will not. All I need to say is that there are 14 pages of Democrat amendments. What we have here is the re-birth of the regulators in the form of the Australian Democrats. It is interesting to see that they are vying with the National Party for what is the reactionary end of wheat grower anxiety. The amendments that have been proposed would subvert the purpose of the Act. For those reasons, they are opposed by the Government.

(5) Page 6, subclause 7 (4), line 16, after ``subsection (3)'' insert ``, after consultation with the Grains Council, and''.
(6) Page 8, after subclause 8 (3), add the following new subclause:

``(4) Where the Board has incurred loss because of obeying directions given by the Minister in accordance with this section, and the Minister is satisfied that the Board has taken all reasonable steps to minimise or recover the loss, the Minister for Finance shall pay to the Board, out of money to be appropriated by the Parliament, the amount of the loss.''.
(7) Page 10, paragraph 15 (1) (a), line 25, after ``Chairperson'', add ``who shall be a wheat grower at the time of appointment''.

The purpose of all of these amendments in many respects is to correct the worst flaws in the Government's legislation. I deal now with the first seven of the coalition's amendments. As to the first one, the Government agreed to change `grain' in two places in the Bill but left wheatgrowers only with the choice of marketing options. As to the second one, under the Bill as written, it is illegal for the Board to trade intrastate. By making the legislation less specific, the Board should be able to trade intrastate without complementary legislation, until challenged in the High Court. Of course, we do not know what the High Court might do with it. It might approve it. In any event, by that time, if the High Court were unhappy, the States would have had the opportunity to pass complementary legislation.

As to the third amendment, this provision is already covered by the Australian Constitution and the intent that the Board operate on a commercial basis makes these clauses heavy-handed. Amendment No. 4 is necessary because clause 2 is removed. Amendment No. 5 should further protect the States' concerns about their State marketing boards by requiring consultation with the Grains Council on grains other than wheat. Amendment No. 6 provides for compensation to be paid for losses in obeying directions of the Minister. Amendment No. 7 ensures that the Minister's commitment in the second reading speech that the chairperson is a wheat grower at the time of appointment is met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to add one point to support Senator Lewis in this regard. The Minister said-and I quote from Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: I have made a commitment in my second reading speech to appoint a chairperson who is a grower.

In terms of interpretation by a court, that has the power of law. I merely want to maintain the consistency. I would like to make this little comment here: `Where a right is uncertain, there is no right', or in Latin `Ubi jus incertum, ibi jus nullum'.
I am supporting Senator Lewis on this amendment because section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act says that extrinsic material may-and the main point of this is the word `may'-be used:
(a) To confirm that the meaning . . . is the ordinary meaning . . .; or
(b) To determine the meaning . . . when-
(i) the provision is ambiguous or obscure; or
(ii) the ordinary meaning . . . leads to a result that is manifestly absurd or is unreasonable.

If it was left out of the Act, the second reading speech suggestion of the Minister would be basically worthless. The Bill is silent on the matter of the grower-chairman. Therefore, there is no meaning to be conveyed. So it definitely has to be put into the Bill as in this amendment that has been moved by Senator Lewis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my voice in support of all the amendments that have been moved to date-that is, to No. 7-especially on the point of the Chairperson being a grower at the time of appointment. I believe that it would be the final insult, as I said yesterday, to the 45,000 Australian wheat growers if the Chairman or Chairwoman were not to be a grower. We have heard in this place tonight and yesterday many statements that this is a marketing board rather than a producer board. Then the same speakers have gone on to contradict themselves by saying that some farmers, or a lot of farmers, have marketing skills and managerial skills. So I would certainly like to add my weight, as a representative of Western Australia, to the proposition that the Chairperson of the Wheat Board certainly be a grower at the time of appointment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply rise very briefly to say that, particularly in view of my separation from my colleague Senator Lewis a little earlier in the evening, I now want to make it quite clear that all National Party senators will be supporting entirely all the amendments he will be moving on behalf of the Opposition from now on, and I do so. I will not speak further on the amendments during the evening; but I would not wish my silence on those occasions to be thought to be in any way separating me from Senator Lewis.

—The Australian Democrats are supporting this block of amendments on the basis that, as I said earlier, they are amendments which the industry believes will ameliorate the worst effects of the legislation in the event of its passage. I particularly point to our support of amendment No. 2, which allows, at least until a challenge-if that should occur-intrastate trade on the part of the Wheat Board. About 80 per cent of grain which is used within the State of Victoria is grown within the State. Not to have clear provisions at this point to allow the Wheat Board and, perhaps even more importantly, to allow grain growers a real choice to use the Wheat Board, as the Minister's staff and departmental staff have been saying around the country at meetings of growers they would be able to and everyone is confident they will, and not to have these provisions in the absence of State enabling legislation-which we do not have-would be chopping the Wheat Board off at the ankles.
—I do not think the intrastate trading point needs to be elaborated on any more from this side of the chamber, because we have definitely been elaborating on that the whole way through the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are coalition amendments Nos. 1 to 7. I hope I do not shock the chamber too much by saying that the Government will oppose all of these amendments. We opposed them in the other place; we won there. I see from the round-up of forces that we are not likely to win here. Nonetheless, we oppose the amendments. Since there are seven of them, I want to quickly cite for the Senate record the Government's position on each one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the first, the current objectives of the Wheat Board provide, inter alia, that the objectives of the Board are, by participating in a commercial manner in the market for grain and grain products, to provide Australian wheat growers with a choice of marketing options. The intention of the proposed amendment is to change the objectives of the Board's commercial operations so that they are directed not only to wheat growers, but to all grain growers. To change this last reference from `wheat' to `grain' would change the whole basis of the Act and essentially amount to the establishment of a grains corporation. This is a direction which the Government has not considered and would raise concerns if it lessened competition in grain marketing. I think that is probably enough on our position on that.

Let me move to amendment No. 2. Our basic problem with amendment No. 2 is that we believe that it goes beyond the Commonwealth's constitutional power and therefore ought to be opposed. I make the observation on that, in passing, that creating a clouded legal situation, if this were to carry, is not the answer since it puts the Australian Wheat Board then in an impossible position. As I say, we believe that it is against the Commonwealth's constitutional power to do what this amendment proposes.

As to proposed amendments Nos 3 and 4, this is a standard provision which states the constitutional position that the Australian Wheat Board not exceed its powers. Its exclusion would put the whole Act into question. We oppose Nos 3 and 4.

On amendment No. 5, the Government has amended clause 10 (2) (b) to refer to the consultation on the marketing of grain rather than wheat. The second reading speech also refers to an expectation that the Australian Wheat Board consult with the Grains Council of Australia on general policy issues relating to trading in other grains and wheat of other origin. In view of that, we oppose amendment No. 5. On amendment No. 6, the current Act does not have such a provision and it is not normal government practice to include such a provision in legislation. The question of compensation would normally be taken into consideration by the Minister in considering issuing a direction.

Finally, on amendment No. 7, it is not appropriate to put this provision in the legislation, given the new, more commercial orientation of the Wheat Board. However, in recognition of the industry's concerns, the Minister's commitment to appointing a grower-chairperson was made clear in the second reading speech.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Page 10, paragraph 15 (1) (d), line 28, after ``members'', add ``5 of whom shall be wheat growers''.
This amendment will ensure that five members of the Board are wheat growers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support this amendment. I reiterate our approach to the Government's argument: It has, for as long as the Democrats have been in this place, been our policy that growers should control their own operations as far as possible. The Government is saying that, because we are now moving into a commercial situation, we should not be having wheat growers in a controlling situation. That is a contradiction of its argument for the whole legislation in the first place, which is that growers can go out and do their own marketing, that they do not need the Board to do it for them. If that is the case, every grower is an expert. We accept that we do want good expertise on the Board. We believe that we can best get it, in the interests of the wheat industry, from wheat growers themselves. This is a consistent policy position for the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We also oppose this amendment and perhaps with a degree more vigour than we have opposed the others. We say that the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) now has a broad commercial charter. The Board needs to comprise the best people who are available, with a balance of production, marketing and finance skills. If it does not have this expertise, this will be detrimental to the growers' returns. I think, therefore, that to argue as Senator Powell has argued is in fact to put people without the necessary skills to maximise the returns for growers in a position of marketing for the Board. The wheat growers are able to determine board membership through their majority representation on the AWB selection committee. We oppose the amendment. We would not want to see the incorporation of a wheat growers' club running the AWB. We believe that it needs a wider commercial membership and that is why--
—You would not want to see trade unionists running the trade union movement, would you?
—This has wider community interest than that. We oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 21, subclause 44 (2), line 27, leave out ``Subject to subsection (3), persons'', insert ``Persons''.
(10) Page 21, subclause 44 (3), lines 29 to 33, leave out the subclause.

These amendments allow the Board to determine salaries for employees without a non-commercial restriction. For example, the right person as a financial director may earn or save the Board much more than his salary. The result may very well be that such a person is employed at what might in normal circumstances be considered to be an extraordinarily high salary, but that will be his worth to the Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, for the record, opposes these amendments. We moved an amendment to this matter earlier and we lost, but we still oppose these.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support these amendments, again on the basis that the Government says it is moving the Australian Wheat Board into a commercial position but has not inserted in the legislation the appropriate passages, which these amendments would help to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 23, clause 48, line 23, before ``Act'', insert ``or any other''.
This proposal is to put it beyond any doubt that the merit principle will override any equal opportunity requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support this amendment. This is the usual nonsense that we get from the Opposition whenever equal opportunity elements are involved. It is the nonsense that equal opportunity legislation as it is coming through has anything at all to do with quotas, and the amendment is therefore entirely unnecessary. I am disappointed that the Opposition has persisted with this amendment since I thought that a journalist who said yesterday morning that wets and women might be the ones to benefit from the turmoil and changeover in Liberal Party leadership might have been correct. Obviously, that journalist was not correct and the Opposition persists in this madness.

—The Government opposes this amendment. The vigour of our opposition is such that, in the normal course of events, we would ask for a division to be called. I do not propose to call for a division tonight but I want to record in the Hansard record that we would have done had the vote been called against us and there was a need to divide. Otherwise, I just say to Senator Powell that she made an excellent speech and we support those sentiments absolutely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —As everyone seems to be making their positions clear, the situation is that we are the ones who would have called a division here to demonstrate that the Democrats and the Government are once again joining together to overcome merit as the principle for advancement. I will not be calling a division because of the lateness of the hour.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 28, after clause 61, insert the following new clause in Division 2:
Non-application of Trade Practices Act 1974 to pools

``61a. The provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 do not apply to purchases of wheat by the Board under section 60 or to pools for the marketing of wheat established by the Board under section 61.''.
(13) Page 29, subclause 64 (4), lines 28 and 29, leave out the subclause.
(14) Page 29, subclause 64 (5), line 30, leave out ``The payment'', insert ``If the Board grants an application made under subsection (1), the payment''.
(15) Page 30, subclauses 64 (6), (7) and (8), lines 1 to 9, leave out the subclauses.
(16) Page 33, after paragraph 69 (b), insert the following new paragraph:
``(ba) in making payments of an amount or amounts, not payable in pursuance of a law or under a legal liability, as an act of grace payment or as act of grace payments;''.
(17) Page 34, subclauses 71 (2) to (5), lines 14 to 21, leave out the subclauses.

Amendment No. 12 prevents provisions of the Trade Practices Act from applying to wheat pooling arrangements. This exemption would not apply to subsidiary companies but would allow the sale of the pool on both the domestic and export markets. Currently section 51 (1) (a) of the Trade Practices Act is ambiguous and could apply to domestic activity and not export activity. It could also provide the Australian Wheat Board with logistical problems if export and domestic stocks needed to be segregated.

Amendments Nos 13, 14 and 15 compel the Board to take certain action in relation to an application for payment in lieu of final payment instead of leaving this to a commercial judgment. Amendment No. 16 allows the Board to make ex gratia payments in special circumstances and amendment No. 17 enables to Board to raise money which does not have a government guarantee without written approval of the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support these amendments. I comment quickly on amendment No. 12 to exempt the pools from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. The Trade Practices Commission itself is concerned about the position of rural producers in the marketplace in general and its discussion paper The Rural Guideline makes some very cogent points in that area. The committee which produced this report has been very concerned about the need to enhance producers' bargaining power where there are very many small producers in a market with many fewer large buyers. Therefore I think this amendment in particular is essential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes these five amendments Nos 12 to 17. Advice from the Attorney-General's Department on amendment No. 12 is that such a specific exemption is not required. The Bill provides, after all, clear authority to the Australian Wheat Board to operate pools and such operations are therefore automatically authorised under section 51 of the Trade Practices Act which provides specific exemption for the activities of statutory marketing authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of amendments Nos 12 to 15, while growers do have a wide range of marketing choices, the export monopoly remains and the Australian Wheat Board is still a receiver of last resort. Some growers will still have no alternative but to deliver to the Board and on these grounds it could be argued that the offer to cash-out from the pool should remain mandatory. The act of grace payments are a matter for the Board's commercial judgment in our view and for that reason we oppose amendment No. 16 proposed by Senator Lewis.

In respect of amendment No. 17 I say that Government policy recognises, even in the absence of a formal guarantee, the potential ultimate liability of government if statutory authorities proved unable to meet their borrowing liabilities. For those reasons we oppose this block of amendments.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 18 ensures an underwriting guarantee of 95 per cent and it is indeed the cornerstone to the coalition's amendments. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Page 39, subclause 78 (14), lines 9 to 14, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(14) The appropriate percentage, for all seasons commencing on or after 1 July 1989, is 95%.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been pointed out, this is the cornerstone of the four conditions for the Liberal Party to agree to the deregulation of the domestic wheat market. I also want to put on record that I agreed to not cross the floor of the Senate on the basis that we would stand up solidly for this. We do not intend to back away from it. I am not going to go into the reasons why the guaranteed minimum price (GMP) should remain at 95 per cent. Despite what anyone might say, the GMP will be the floor price on the domestic market.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to point out where Senator Walsh this evening misled the Parliament when he spoke about the GMP being higher than the Government proposes. He gave figures on what the Government would have paid out in 1986. Since he spoke I have obtained figures here from the Australian Wheat Board. In 1986, when the GMP was set at $125.72, the pool returned $125.50 which is 99.8 per cent of the GMP. In other words, if the trigger was to be set off under this sort of legislation at 95 per cent estimated GMP, it would have had to be set at 99.8 per cent for the Government to pay. I think that Senator Walsh needs to give an explanation to the Committee because he had his figures badly mixed up.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support this amendment on the basis that underwriting is fundamental to the industry. Indeed, should this amendment be passed, the chances of government liability are very small. If we had time we could go into it, but simply on the basis that underwriting has scarcely ever been used we believe it ought to be set at the 95 per cent level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government resists with all the passion that is equal to that expressed from the Opposition, but with a little more to overwhelm it, the amendment that has been moved by Senator Lewis and supported by the Australian Democrats. This for us is one of those issues that we would contest strongly, and I have no doubt that when this legislation now goes back to the House of Representatives the Government will be defending its position again. However, I do not propose to call for a division but note for the record that had the call gone against us, as I would expect given the remarks around the chamber, we would have sought a division to record our position on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say in passing as well that Senator Panizza made a statement that Senator Walsh, my ministerial colleague, misled the Senate. I would have normally raised a point of order. I did not due to the lateness of the hour, but I would assert on Senator Walsh's behalf, absent as he is, that that is not the case, and allow the argument between Senator Panizza and Senator Walsh to flourish at another time.

Let me now address myself to the reason why it is that the Government feels so strongly about this amendment. Government policy is to phase underwriting down, consistent with its broader policy of reducing government involvement in statutory marketing, industry taking greater responsibility for its own risk management and greater commercialisation of the board. it should be remembered too that that level is initially 90 per cent, phasing down to 80 per cent, the reduction in the level is therefore gradual. Even with underwriting at 80 per cent the wheat industry is favourably treated compared with other industries.

Provision is also made for the industry to fund advances in excess of the underwritten level. I understand however that the industry is not disposed to do this because it considers it is not worthwhile.

If it is true that in pre-Gorbachev Russia some of the best novels remained in the drawers of their authors for fear of persecution, it is also true in the way in which we are dealing with this legislation that some of the best speeches that could be made in the Senate remain in our drawers. I would have liked to have made a good speech on this subject. I will not tonight; maybe I will get an opportunity later. But we indicate that we resist this amendment with the energy equal to that which would take it to a division if necessary.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Page 39, subclauses 78 (18) and (19), lines 25 to 29, leave out the subclauses.
(20) Page 40, after subclause 82 (2), add the following new subclause:
``(3) Regulations for the purpose of subsection (1) shall not be made without agreement by the Grains Council, after consultation with the Board.''.
(21) Page 41, subclause 83 (3), lines 18 to 20, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(3) Regulations for the purpose of subsection (1) shall not be made without agreement by the Grains Council, after consultation with the Board.''.

Our amendment No. 19 deletes the review provision. As the Government is unlikely to contribute any money under 95 per cent underwriting guarantee, there seems little point in disrupting the industry for a review of clause 78. Amendments Nos 20 and 21 allow for Grains Council approval when it comes to use and management of the levy fund and the levy, which is of course contributed by the grain growers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support these amendments. In respect of amendments 20 and 21, we believe that the Grains Council, as the voice of the industry, ought to be an integral part of these operations and therefore these amendments are essential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is my normal wont, I intend again to mark the spot. The Government opposes these amendments. In respect of amendment 19 the Government is not prepared to commit itself to guarantee Australian Wheat Board borrowings beyond five years. In respect of amendments 20 and 21, it would be untenable for the Minister responsible to the Parliament for the activities of the Wheat Board to have an industry body placed in a position to exercise direct and potentially conflicting control over the Board. For those reasons I oppose Opposition amendments 19, 20 and 21.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Page 45, after clause 88, insert the following new clause:
Deregulation of labour practices

``88a. (1) It is the intention of the Parliament that the Board and any corporation engaged in the storage, handling, transport or sale of grain for export shall, in regard to any matter connected with the storage, handling, transport, or shipment of that grain:

(a) be entitled to take no cognisance of any agreement, undertaking or other arrangement which requires the employment of any specified number of persons who are members of a trade union or similar society or association of persons, and any such agreement and undertaking or other arrangement shall be void;

(b) be exempt from the operation of any enactment of the Commonwealth or of any State or Territory which would otherwise require the employment, or the giving of preference in employment, to persons who are members of a trade union or of a similar society or association of persons;

(c) be entitled to enter into voluntary employment agreements or undertakings with any employee or groups of employees, and such agreements or undertakings will override any awards of the Industrial Relations Commission;
(d) be entitled to enter into any agreement, undertaking or arrangement, with any person or body in regard to the loading of any vessel and the manning of any loading apparatus; and

(e) be entitled to claim damages in the Federal Court of Australia or the High Court of Australia against any person, trade union or similar society or association or associations or persons for any amount equal to the amount of any loss of a financial or contractual nature caused by any action of that person, trade union, society or association of persons which disrupts the activities of the Board or corporation, as the case may be.
``(2) A natural person, trade union or similar society or association of persons contravening subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable upon conviction:
(a) in the case of a natural person-$10,000 and $1,000 for every day that the offence continues; or
(b) in the case of a trade union or similar society or association of persons-$100,000 and $10,000 for every day that the offence continues.''.

This is one of the most important amendments to come before this chamber in a long time. It deals with the deregulation of labour practices which affect the storage, handling and transport of grain. I will not delay the Committee as long as I would like in relation to the deregulation of labour. But this is where the Hawke Government has absolutely failed this country. It is failing the nation by not addressing this major handicap to our industries overcoming the massive debt burden that the country is suffering. In this amendment the coalition parties set out how the Hawke Government could go about the deregulation of labour practices. It sets out quite clearly what we will do when we get into government, and it sets out what should be the future course of this nation in relation to labour practices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats vehemently oppose this amendment, as indeed we vehemently oppose those additional aspects of clause 88 which deregulate the transport, handling and storage of grain. In clause 88, amended or unamended-and it will be unamended-we find an odious situation. In proposing to extend deregulation beyond what the Government has as a result of the deal it did to get deregulation of the wheat marketing system, the Opposition has exercised an interesting political ploy, to the extent that Senator McKiernan had to get up in this place during the second reading debate and object to the union bashing that was going on. As I pointed out at the time, that was only to be expected because here we have a piece of legislation that is the result of a deal between the Liberal Party, the privatisers of the New Right, and the economic rationalists of the Labor Party. The legislation flies in the face of the interests, certainly of the rail unions and therefore of employment generally, especially in small country towns and surrounding areas.

SPEECH.PARA: A recent study by the Bureau of Transport Economics, which is part of one of this Government's Federal departments, found that the damage caused by the average truck cost over $35,000 more than the freight charges that are being paid. Yet the Government and the Opposition are saying that they are levelling the playing field, that they are getting some real competition and, worse, that they are going to save grain growers $10 a tonne. If some save any money it will only be in their grain marketing. They will have to pay the taxes to cover the high cost of accidents on the roads, and that is only because of the deregulation of transport.

The Opposition now puts before us an amendment which proposes to deregulate the whole of the labour market associated with grain transport, handling and storage in a highly confrontationist way. As with amendment No. 11 that was moved earlier this evening, that shows us that, although there may have been some cosmetic changes at the top in the coalition leadership recently, there is certainly no fundamental change, that we are in for industrial confrontation should the electorate go down that path at any stage in the future. The Australian Democrats totally reject Senator Lewis's amendment to clause 88 and most vehemently object to the other deregulation aspects of clause 88 which are part of the legislation as a result of a deal done with the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party and acquiesced in by the National Party as a party within the coalition. Were there more time, not only would we have more brilliant speeches but we would have another division on this. But because of the lateness of the hour we will not call for a division.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would have gone to the barricades on this and, from the remarks of the Australian Democrats, accompanied by a majority this time. Justice would therefore have been done, although I must say that I do not think there is ever any likelihood of us, on the merits of our case, persuading the Opposition to support our labour market reform. I recognise that the Opposition is not able to assess the real change objectively because of its philosophical commitment. I could make a long speech on this but I will not. I just say that this amendment would jeopardise the entire labour market strategy of the Government. The Bill would be rendered totally inappropriate if this provision were included. Therefore I oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to note that the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats are apparently joining to oppose this amendment. I will not call a division, but I note their opposition for the record. The Government is quite clearly prepared to deregulate the wheat industry but when it comes to deregulating the labour market it is not prepared to act. Whenever we raise this subject or have any sort of debate on it the only thing we can get from the Labor Party and the Democrats is that we are union bashers. There is no bashing of the union movement on this proposal. What we are talking about is trying to get this country up and running, trying to get this Government to act to affect the sort of micro-economic reforms that all of its rhetoric is about but none of its actions.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Page 49, clause 94, at end of clause, add the following new subclause:

`(2) Regulations shall not be made in respect of any of the matters permitted to be prescribed by section 7 and section 88 of this Act unless the Minister certifies that he has advised the members of the Australian Agricultural Council in writing of the subject matter of the proposed regulations.''.

This amendment will require the Commonwealth Minister to consult with the State Ministers for primary industries or agriculture through the medium of the Australian Agricultural Council before any regulations are made to prescribe State laws for the purposes of section 7 or section 88 of the Act, that is, to ensure that the States have at least some forewarning of any Commonwealth attempt to override State legislation in regard to the storage, handling, transport or marketing of grain. While it would be desirable to require the Commonwealth Minister to advise State Ministers at a formal meeting of the Agricultural Council, an acceptable compromise might be to require the Commonwealth Minister to advise the members of the Agricultural Council in writing of any proposed action in regard to sections 7 or section 88. In order to put the proposition the way we see it I have moved amendment No. 23.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment. Despite the sort of exercise that we have seen with this legislation and the fact that I find this an interesting amendment to be coming from the Opposition, especially once the wheeling and dealing got going between the Government and the Liberal Party, we believe that this proposal has some potential as a cushioning effect and would provide better information to rural industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose this amendment on the grounds that it is not necessary and that it will happen anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Lewis on the passage of this legislation through the chamber and make it clear that I would have liked to have spoken on a lot of the amendments and put my point as a wheat grower but refrained from doing so to expedite the passage of our amendments and the Bill through this chamber tonight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 3 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the decision handed down in February 1989 by Arbitration Commissioner Baird, described in the Financial Review of 23 February 1989 as a `landmark', allow Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education the right to dismiss staff.
(2) Is it now possible, as claimed by the Australian Universities' Staff Association, to make redundant academic staff because of their political or ideological beliefs.
(3) What measures are available to the Federal Government to ensure the Baird decision will not be used in this way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision enables higher education institutions to dismiss staff on the grounds of redundancy. However, the academic unions have appealed against the decision. No date has yet been set to hear the appeal.

(2) No. Commissioner Baird indicated in his decision that dismissal on the grounds of redundancy would be `rare and unusual', and would only be considered when other options such as relocation and retraining are not applicable.

(3) Measures are available to guard against misuse of the provisions. Commissioner Baird preserved the right to appeal to the Commission. In addition, the parties to the dispute were directed to prepare an award redundancy provision which should see the development of safeguards similar to those existing in relation to termination of employment on the grounds of ill health, serious misconduct and unsatisfactory performance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 7 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: In relation to the former Minister's answer to a Question without Notice on the ignition temperature of the new camouflage uniforms (House of Representatives Hansard, 22 November 1988) being higher than the jungle greens they replaced and that overall the fire hazards of the new uniforms are not greater than those of the current greens:
(a) Are the effects on the wearer worse from burning polyester than from burning cotton.
(b) Does the new polyester material melt and adhere to skin before ignition temperature.
(c) Does this new polyester when it burns create more difficult wound healing and scarring than burning cotton.
(d) Is it a fact that the United States Navy prohibited the wearing of polyester uniforms on its combat ships years ago.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Material made of 100% polyester has worse burn effects on a wearer than cotton. However, this has no relevance to the new camouflage uniform as it is made from a 50/50 blend of cotton and polyester. There are significant differences in fire resistance between cotton/polyester (CPE) blends and 100% polyester. When comparing the burn effects between cotton and 50/50 CPE, the difference is minimal. In fact, some research has indicated that cotton fabrics can cause slightly worse burns than CPE blends.

(b) The CPE material used in the new camouflage uniform does not melt and adhere to the skin at all. In the CPE blend, the ash formed from the burning cotton holds the molten polyester in place. This is known as the `scaffolding effect' and prevents the melt-drip phenomenon which occurs in 100% polyester material.

(c) The CPE blend material used in the new camouflage uniform does not create more difficult wound healing and scarring than burning cotton material. At worst, the new camouflage uniform would perform in a similar manner to all cotton fabrics of the same mass.

(d) An answer to this part of the question cannot be provided at this time. It has been necessary for the Australian Defence Force to contact the United States Naval Attache in Canberra and request an answer. The Attache, in turn, has requested an answer through the United States Department of Defence in Washington. The United States' response is still awaited. No firm indication can be given by the United States Naval Attache as to when a response will be available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the length and minimum depth of the entrance channel through which RAN vessels enter and leave HMAS Stirling.
(2) What is the distance from the seaward end of the channel to deep water (having a depth of 100 metres).
(3) Is dredging of the entrance channel required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The length of the entrance channel to HMAS Stirling is 4.55 nautical miles. Its minimum depth is 13.7 metres.
(2) The distance from the seaward end of the channel to the 100 metre contour is 22 nautical miles by the most practical route.
(3) Dredging of the channel is periodically required and this is conducted by the West Australian Marine and Harbours Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 3 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of recent media reports, will the Minister reveal whether or not homeless children are the next potential target for the AIDS virus.

(2) As it has been implied by the Human Rights Commission that there is neglect at both Federal and State Government level of the plight of the young, what action is being taken to alleviate the problem.
(3) According to Federal Government research, how many Australian children between the ages of 12 and 17 are on the streets at night.
(4) How great, according to Federal Government research, is the problem of male and female prostitution in this age bracket.
(5) What action is being taken between State, Territory and Federal authorities to stamp out the problem of (a) homelessness, (b) drug taking, and (c) resultant prostitution.
(6) Is it true, as it has been claimed by young people on television recently, that young drug addicts are being turned away from rehabilitation centres simply because they are drug addicts.
(7) What Federal measures are in place in the Territories for the rehabilitation of homeless drug addicts, regardless of sex or age.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Overseas studies, particularly in New York, indicate that the lifestyles of the homeless young place them at great risk of exposure to AIDS. While there is little information on the risk of exposure to AIDS among the homeless young in Australian cities, measures are being taken to co-ordinate agencies in Australia working with homeless youth. A national workshop of policy makers, youth workers and youth held in Sydney recently, reviewed current programs and established mechanisms for evaluation, co-ordination and development of AIDS education and services.

The AIDS Working Group of the Council of Social Welfare Administrators has recently completed a detailed examination of programs and policies required for youth as clients of social welfare departments. Their report was endorsed by the Council of Social Welfare Ministers at Burnie on 20 March 1989.

(2) Although the provision of health and welfare services, including for the young, is primarily a State responsibility, the Commonwealth provides funds to State/Territory Governments through a number of major programs designed to alleviate homelessness, AIDS and drug abuse. These include:

Supported Accommodation Assistance Program: From 1989-90, support for homeless people over the next three years will be increased by $40 million bringing the total Federal Government support to $220 million over the next three years. The new Program will provide a wider range of assistance to those in need, by providing better access to training, employment assistance and other Government services and place greater emphasis on medium and long term accommodation in the mix of accommodation services available;

AIDS Program: Through the Inter-Governmental Committee on AIDS (IGCA) formed in 1987, youth networks are being expanded and drawn upon to combat high risk activity. Many educational and support programs are now well established including crucial outreach programs. These include streetwork, mobile clinics and needle and syringe exchange programs;

National Campaign Against Drug Abuse: Young people have been identified as a key target group under the Campaign. Under the NCADA cost-shared program, funds are provided to the States and Territories for treatment, rehabilitation and counselling services as well as for drug prevention education programs. At the national level, during the next triennium of the NCADA there will be campaigns directed at young people targeting alcohol and heroin. A comprehensive national statement on school based drug education curricula development and implementation will also be developed.

Following receipt of the Report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Burdekin Report)-Our Homeless Children, Federal and State Governments have established a joint working party to address the problem associated with youth homelessness.
The working party will assess the Report and report back to a special meeting of Welfare Ministers in June 1989.

(3) Reliable estimates of the number of children on the streets at night are not available. There are an unknown number of young people who, for a variety of reasons, do not use available accommodation services.

(4) Information is not available on the number of homeless young people resorting to prostitution. Outreach programs directed towards young male and female prostitutes are achieving promising results.
(6) Drug treatment and rehabilitation services are administered by the States and Territories.

(7) Establishment of rehabilitation centres for drug addicts in the Territories is a matter for the Northern Territory Government or the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in the Australian Capital Territory.
